talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
talker.name: Mr McGAURAN

talk.start.para: âI move:

motion.para: That these bills be now read a second time.

speech.para: Today I am bringing forward into the chamber for consideration two telecommunications bills. The bills are an integral part of a comprehensive package of measures designed to enable the Commonwealth to sell its remaining equity interest in Telstra and to give Australians access to first-class telecommunications services now and into the future. Three further bills with additional measures and appropriations make up the package.
Together, this legislation forms a broad, integrated package that is designed to:

item.para: provide an appropriate framework for a Telstra sale scheme;
provide a settled regulatory framework that promotes an open, competitive telecommunications market;
address concerns, particularly of rural and regional Australia about the adequacy of telecommunications services; and
reinforce the universal service obligation, digital data service obligation and the customer service guarantee.

speech.para: This package of legislation builds on the strong foundations that the government has already laid for the telecommunications sector. This includes enhancements of an already robust pro-competition regulatory regime and further measures that support the strongest telecommunications safeguard arrangements in the world.
The government has demonstrated that it remains fully committed to this approach regardless of the ownership of Telstra.
This legislative package will also give effect to a number of Connect Australia initiatives that were announced by the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts on 17Â August.
The four key planks of the Connect Australia package are:

item.para: an investment of $1.1 billion in services;
a perpetual $2 billion Communications Fund to generate revenue for rural telecommunications services into the future;
improved competition regulation including a requirement for the operational separation of Telstra to deal with ongoing concerns about Telstraâs high degree of integration; and
enhanced consumer safeguards which build on the existing universal service obligation, the customer service guarantee and the digital data service obligation.

speech.para: Connect Australia is an initiative for both now and into the future.

It is designed to address gaps in the provision of mobile and broadband services. The program will facilitate the roll-out of affordable broadband connections to people living in rural, regional and remote areas; extend mobile phone coverage; build new regional communications networks; and set up vital telecommunications services for remote Indigenous communities.
The Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 2005
There is a close interplay between competition, consumer safeguards, targeted assistance and the governmentâs commitment to sell our remaining share in Telstra.

The government believe there is an inherent conflict of interest in the government being an owner of the nationâs largest telecommunications carrier while at the same time being the policy maker and regulator for the industry.

The Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 2005 amends the Telstra Corporation Act 1991 to repeal the provisions that require the Commonwealth to retain 50.1 per cent equity in Telstra Corporation Ltd.

While the government is moving to establish the legislation immediately, it has undertaken not to proceed with any further sale of Telstra until it is fully satisfied that arrangements are in place to deliver adequate telecommunications services to all Australians, including maintaining the improvements to existing services, and that there is value for taxpayers from any further sale.
The bill provides for the timing of the sale to remain open.

To assist in achieving this objective, the bill also gives the Commonwealth the flexibility to develop detailed arrangements for the sale process which will protect and optimise the Commonwealthâs interests.

The governmentâs policy on foreign ownership of Telstra is unchanged. Telstra will continue to remain an Australian owned and controlled corporation. The maximum foreign ownership allowed in Telstra will remain at 35 per cent, whilst the maximum individual foreign ownership will remain at five per cent.

Telstra will be required to continue to comply with its reporting obligations and remain subject to a ministerial power of direction under the Telstra Corporation Act 1991 until the Commonwealthâs direct shareholding in the company falls below 15 per cent.

The Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill reaffirms the cornerstone requirements of the universal service obligation, the digital data service obligation and the customer service guarantee. These requirements will continue to apply to Telstra and other carriers, regardless of their ownership structure.

Changes in Telstraâs ownership status, however, will not affect the governmentâs ability to protect the interests of consumers, competitors and the public generally. Consumer regulatory safeguards such as the universal service obligation, the customer service guarantee, price controls, network reliability framework and the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman will be maintained into the future.
The Telecommunications Legislation Amendment (Competition and Consumer Issues) Bill 2005
The government is strongly of the view that competition provides the best means of delivering greater choice and improved and more innovative and affordable telecommunications services for consumers.

The competition reform measures in the Telecommunication Legislation Amendment (Competition and Consumer Issues) Bill 2005 that I will be bringing forward shortly into this chamber strike an appropriate balance between the need for regulation which promotes competitive services and investment in new infrastructure and allowing Telstra the scope to meet changing market conditions and demand for services.

Telstra will be required to introduce operational separation between its retail and wholesale businesses. Operational separation is designed to ensure that Telstra, as the dominant carrier, treats all other carriers on a fair and transparent basis. The model has been developed with expert advice and in consultation with Telstra and the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC). The model provides a sound approach to achieve transparency, without the risks of forced structural separation.

Compliance with operational separation will be enforced through a legislative framework that imposes a licence condition enforceable by both the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts and the ACCC.

A number of consumer protection measures, such as retail price controls and the customer service guarantee, will be strengthened. These measures build on the comprehensive system of consumer safeguards that are already in place.

The bill also amends the Telecommunications Act 1997 to make changes to numbering plan consultation requirements and repeal provisions relating to industry development plans, and it includes measures to encourage any-to-any connectivity. The bill will increase the range of enforcement mechanisms that are available to the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) to ensure compliance with telecommunications regulation.
The Telecommunications Legislation Amendment (Future Proofing and Other Measures) Bill 2005
The bills that will be considered in the chamber this morning are complemented by an equally significant piece of legislation.

The Telecommunications Legislation Amendment (Future Proofing and Other Measures) Bill 2005 provides the necessary appropriations, on passage of the Telstra sale legislation, to commence funding of the governmentâs commitment to Connect Australia and allows for long-term funding to be available for telecommunications services into the future.

The future requirements of Australiaâs 21st century telecommunications services are still an unknown quantity. No-one knows what services will be required. What is needed is to put in place an effective process that will both assess needs as they arise and provide the necessary funding as required.

To achieve this, the Telecommunications Legislation Amendment (Future Proofing and Other Measures) Bill implements one of the key recommendations of the Estens inquiry to establish regular independent reviews into the adequacy of telecommunications in regional, rural and remote parts of Australia.

The independent reviews will be conducted by an expert committee, the Regional Telecommunications Independent Review Committee (RTIRC), appointed by the minister for communications. The bill requires the first review to be commenced before the end of 2008.
The government has already imposed a licence condition on Telstra requiring the company to implement and maintain an effective local presence in rural, regional and remote Australia.

The bill will also create a dedicated and perpetual Communications Fund of $2 billion. Revenue generated from the fund will be spent on implementing the governmentâs responses to recommendations contained in the reports of the independent review committee to respond to identified market failure in the provision of additional telecommunications services in regional, rural and remote areas.
The amendments proposed to this bill:

item.para: make clear that the Communications Fund can only be used to implement a government response to recommendations of the RTIRC that relate to telecommunications in regional, rural or remote Australia;

provide that the statement the government is required to make and table setting out its response to the recommendations of a review will explain how that response will improve telecommunications services in regional, rural and remote Australia;
require that at least one member of the RTIRC must be nominated by an organisation that represents the interests of people in regional, rural or remote Australia; and

require future reviews to be completed within three years of the tabling of the governmentâs response to the previous review. This will ensure that the time between the beginning of one review and the beginning of the next is no more than three years and six months.

speech.para: The future-proofing bill will also include amendments to the Telecommunications Act relating to the development by telecommunications industry bodies of industry codes that deal with consumer related issues. The amendments made by the bill will require the Australian Communications and Media Authority to reimburse industry bodies for their costs in developing consumer related industry codes, as long as certain conditions relating to consumer participation in the code development process are met. This measure will provide for more equitable financing of consumer related industry codes and will allow more consumer participation in code development.
The Telecommunications (Carrier Licence Charges) Amendment (Industry Plans and Consumer Codes) Bill 2005

This bill gives effect to the requirement that industry be reimbursed for the costs of development of consumer codes in the manner I have just outlined and that those costs can be recouped through carrier licence charges.

I draw my remarks to a close and state on behalf of the government that we believe this is a comprehensive and forward-looking package and a significant demonstration of the governmentâs ongoing commitment to ensuring that Australiaâs telecommunications system combines the best elements of competition, customer service and government assistance in the face of market failure.
It represents the biggest commitment by any Australian government for telecommunications servicesânot only for rural Australia, but for all Australians.

The legislative package will allow the government to focus on its core business of setting the rules for the whole telecommunications industry. Telstra will be able to focus on being competitive and delivering the best services to its customers. Consumers can be confident that telecommunications services will continue to improve, service quality will be maintained at high levels and existing consumer rights protected, regardless of Telstraâs ownership. Rural Australia can be assured that ongoing targeted funding will allow them to access 21st century telecommunications services that are comparable with those in metropolitan areas.
All Australians will have the opportunity to share in the benefits from this legislative package.
I commend the bills to the House and present the explanatory memorandums.

talk.start.para: âWe oppose the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 2005 and related legislation in its entirety, as we have done consistently since the government first brought this forward. This is a shameful moment for the transparent political process in Australia as the government bulldozes through the sale of Telstra legislation. It is a sad moment for the Australian people, who are overwhelmingly opposed to the sale. We witnessed both in this chamber and in the other chamber an almost obscene dance by our political opponents when this legislation passed throughâobscene against the fact that there is a note of sadness in its carriage for ordinary Australians because they do not want this to happen and they are obliged to witness an arrogant government triumphant on the subject.

speech.para: It is a day when our countryâs national interest has been sacrificed for one manâs old extreme ideology. The whole shameful saga has been characterised by deceit, cover-ups and backroom deals, presided over by a Prime Minister who cannot be bothered to be in the country today to witness the final shabby episode. As his decade-long obsession approaches realisation, where is he? He is strolling in Central Park and spending night after night at the luxurious Hotel Pierre in a cloud of self-aggrandisement, phoning home occasionally to issue instructions to his henchmenâthe Treasurer, the Minister for Finance and Administration, the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, and his fumbling deputy. The Prime Minister is thousands of kilometres away in New York, but he is up to his neck in the political manoeuvring to complete the deal to sell off Telstra, whatever it takesâmore pressure on Barnaby Joyce; more bullying and sledging of Telstra executives; more buck-passing, trickery and deceit, culminating in yesterdayâs disgraceful Senate gagging, arrogantly ramming the legislation through as Telstra service complaints hit the 14 million mark. Secret documents reveal thousands of Telstra jobs will go, and the share price continues its inexorable decline.

In a last desperate plea, regional and rural Australians trapped and now forever imprisoned by ancient technology begged their elected representatives to stand up and say no. It was a call unheeded by Barnaby Joyce, who rolled over like an old kelpie yesterday. After building his election campaign on a âno saleâ platform, he is now the puppet of the faceless delegates of the Queensland National Party conference. But the plea from the bush is not too late for the member for Hume and the member for Riverina, both of whom contrived to be absent on 14 occasions when we voted on this legislation. Today they have a chance to win back the trust and respect of their constituents and not go AWOL but cross the floor and vote with us. The deceitful manipulation that has characterised these last few weeks reveals an obsessive government determined to implement its extreme proposals at any cost to Australian consumersâmum and dad shareholders, small shareholders, the thousands of Telstra workers now fearing for their jobs and the integrity of the parliamentary process.

Over the past months Australians have flooded talkback radio demanding that the PM, his deputy, the Treasurer, the communications minister, National Party senators and coalition backbenchers get on with the job and fix Telstra, not sell it off. But the Prime Minister says there is nothing he can do and that the only way he can sort out the bushâs problems is by selling Telstra. He does not have any ideas to help people in regional and rural Australia. He says it is a $3 billion package, but he is fiddling the figures. When you look at the detail of the Telstra plan, the so-called $3.1 billion, you realise it is all an illusion. There is $1 billion and then a slow drip off the earnings of a $2 billion base. That means it will take 20 years before they have spent $3 billion on the communications infrastructure from the fund.

While the Prime Minister may have succeeded in pulling the wool over Barnaby Joyceâs eyes, most of the western Queensland farmers will be shaking their heads in bewilderment that the National Party has been sold a very mangy looking pup. And all the time there has been the relentless noise of the Prime Minister incessantly protestingâhe has repeated this hollow claim 19 times since November 2001âthat services in the bush are âup to scratchâ. It has been something for us on this side of the House. We know the National Party spokespeople are actually Liberalsâlike their leader and like the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. You see them constantly pulling the wool over the eyes and putting the pressure constantly on those who represent something old and authentic in the National Party, and there are not many of them left. It has been a not particularly edifying spectacle for all of us here. But what you know is this: whatever concerns anybody has about the bush as far as communications are concerned and whatever concerns, frankly, there are in Telstra, cease today. It is all overâfinished. What you see now in regional Australia is what you get. That recordâthat which infuriates those people in the bushâincludes the thousand exchanges that are obsolete and in desperate need of upgrading to ensure basic landline services; the prime ministerial spin that provokes the New South Wales Farmers Association to describe bush telecommunications as âa jokeââthe drivel that drives 80 per cent of farmers in New South Wales to oppose the sale.

The only way we can guarantee that all Australians can get decent standards of phone services is to hang on to Telstra. All Australians know this, especially the 1.6 million shareholders who have been deliberately kept in the dark about the true financial position of the companyâthe mum and dad small T2 investors who have suffered a 41 per cent loss since listing, representing a $3,580 loss on the purchase of 2,000 T2 shares in 1999âand the consumers, who have made a whopping 14 million complaints about services; fourteen per cent of lines are faulty. And then there are those who know as a result of reading the documents that we saw leaked last week that for $5.8 billion they could have had a first-class communications service, but they will never have it. It will never happen.

What have we learned in the last few weeks about government manipulation and deceit over Telstra? We know that at the 11 August secret briefing to the PM, his deputy, Treasurer, finance minister and communications minister, the new Telstra boss, Sol Trujillo, blew the whistle. It was a crucial briefing for the majority shareholderâand one denied the rest. The rest had a legitimate right to know that Telstra was borrowing billions of dollars to pay dividends. They had a right to know that Telstra had not made the investments that it had needed to make and that it had underinvested in its core infrastructure and capabilitiesâthat the government needed to invest an estimated $2.6 billion to benefit 1.1 million families and businesses predominantly in rural and remote areas. All that information was denied to shareholders and the bush.

How did the Prime Minister and his ministers respond to Mr Trujilloâs revelations? Did they immediately recognise that they were in possession of price sensitive information that every shareholder was entitled to share? Did they acknowledge that on the brink of the sale the company was engulfed by financial weaknesses and infrastructure failings that they were obliged to fix before any sale? No, not at all. They did not say a word. They stayed mum. They took a gamble that this explosive information would not leakâat least until they got their sale legislation through. But once the word was out, they squirmed in their lame attempts to explain who knew what and when. Take the Prime Minister on the 7.30 Report:

quote.para: Well, Kerry, the question of what precisely my ministers knew in relation to particular things, I would have to speak to them in relation to those particular things before I could answer that question.

speech.para: A decisive Prime Minister sharing the burden with the community! And then the communications minister and the finance minister, both present at that infamous meeting, were at serious odds with one another. Questioned specifically about whether she knew that Telstra had underinvested in infrastructure, Senator Coonan said:

quote.para: Well, no, of course not. I mean, thatâs not something that the Government is privy to as Telstra rolls out its capex expenditure.

speech.para: In a way you hope she was misleading. In a way you hope that the sort of briefing that she had received she had understoodâshe is, after all, the communications minister. It is almost a worse story if she is out there not misleading than if she is out there misleading. Finance Minister Minchin appears much better informed, anyway. He said:

quote.para: And of course, theyâ

speech.para: Telstraâ

quote.para: kept us fully informed, as they did the whole market of what their capital management plans were ...

speech.para: And then when the briefing document is leaked, what does the Prime Minister do? He blames the whistleblower. He denounces the Telstra executives as a disgrace for talking down the companyâs share price and campaigning against government regulatory proposals. He makes this extraordinary remark:

quote.para: I think it is the obligation of ... Telstra to talk up the companyâs interest not to talk them down. That is a view which I have communicated very directly to the chairman of the board on behalf of the government.

speech.para: In other words, what the Prime Ministerâs ill-judged words did was to tell the chairman of Telstra to commit an illegal act. That is basically what the Prime Minister was instructing the chairman of Telstra to do. It is an extraordinary thing. I thought it was such a delight yesterday to watch the Treasurer mince around that particular proposition. But he let us all know, and more particularly let his backbench know, exactly what he thought of the Prime Minister on that subject. In reality, he was delighted to do so. He was absolutely delighted to shaft the stiletto into the Prime Minister. The only thing that upset him, of course, was that the Prime Minister was absent from here to witness the stiletto sinking in.

talk.start.para: âSend him the video.

âAs you say, no doubt he will send the video. There is no doubt about that. Now those ill-judged words of the Prime Minister are under intense scrutiny and ought to be part of a thorough ASIC investigation of Telstraâs compliance with its continuous disclosure obligations.

speech.para: Leadership means having a vision to carry the nation forward. There has been nothing visionary about the spectacle that we have witnessed here over the last week, just a dishonest dash to sell Telstra before anyone finds out just how bad things are and a Prime Minister who resorts to lawyers and bureaucrats for cover, who bullies Telstra management, instructing them to lie to the Australian people, and whose government has sucked billions of dollars out of Telstra and ripped the guts out of its services. Any Australian can tell you that Telstra services are nowhere near up to scratch. We know that Telstra is paying dividends out of reserves, and that is unsustainable.

We know that the Prime Minister knew what was going on but did not tell the other 1.6 million investors. At first, he righteously opined that he would be breaking the law if he told them what he and his ministers knew. The next day, he completely changed his tune, claiming it was all public knowledge that has been known in the marketplace since July last year. The public certainly did not know about the faults. They did not know about the extent of the looting of Telstraâs reserves. They did not know about the underinvestment. They did not know about the developing obsolescence of the work force. The Prime Minister can waffle on about legal obligations all he likes. He can wriggle and make excuses and resort to hiding behind his lawyers. But today he has not only failed all Australians; he has failed their children and grandchildren. He has carved up Australiaâs greatest national assetâdeath to public process and bereft of any vision for our future.

As I look ahead to where we can be in 2025, I see a nation that is bigger and stronger than it is today, a nation that lives within its means, that produces quality goods and services that the world wants to buy, a nation whose imagination is energised by Australiaâs global leadership in surging industries like alternative energy and biotechnology. I see a nation that says to its young people: âYou can be whatever you want to be. Weâll invest in your skills and know-how and weâll back you all the way.â I see a nation that says to its regions and towns: âYouâre part of the country, just as much the strength of this nation as people living in our suburbs and big cities, and weâll never leave you behind.â I see a nation where there is less politics and more vision and ambition from government, a nation characterised by respect and decency that can believe in itself, a nation that is good, does good and feels good about itself.

Our nation faces economic change and external threats, and some want us to change who we are and what we stand for, but we know who we are. We are Australians, we are all equal, and we will look after each other. In the Labor Party now, as we confront the consequences of this legislation passing, that means making absolutely certain that, as the government struggle with what they have chosen to do, as the government sell outâbecause there is only one way that they can sell this between now and the next election and that is a fire saleâwe hold up before them all the information that is out there now on what is absolutely needed in communications in the bush and in our suburbs. We are not going to let this issue go. We are going to campaign on this issue right down to the next election. We know this absolutely: whatever proportion of Telstra is sold, it will not be the lot. There will be the hope in the public mind and in the mind of regional Australia that somebody will be there to make a stand for them, to make sure that they still have a capacity from governmentâ

talk.start.para: âIâll be there; donât you worry about that!

âI note the Independent member: he will be out there doing it too, absolutely. They will understand that there is somebody prepared to take a stand to ensure that they get decent services in regional Australia. I know this as a former communications minister, and I know it absolutely: if regional Australia and our suburbs do not have access to high-speed communications, they are out of the world. Nobody can build a business in the bush on the basis of the type of communications that will be put in place by this package and the direction in which this company is now going.

speech.para: You know absolutely that everything here was done so cynically that, now that there are no more votes in this placeâthere is an issue of a campaign out thereâTelstra from this day forth will forget regional Australia. The government from this day forth will forget regional Australia. The National Party from this day forth will suffer from the consequences of their shameful neglect of their constituents, and there will be plenty of people around to remind them.

I give this undertaking on behalf of the Australian Labor Party: we are going to be in the lists on this from this day down to the day of the next election. The day after that election, we will have an opportunity to do something about realising the vision for the bush that we have and that we know they absolutely need.

talk.start.para: âI rise to support these two important bills, the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 2005 and the Telecommunications Legislation Amendment (Competition and Consumer Issues) Bill 2005. Before doing so, I intended to rebut the arguments that I heard today from the Leader of the Opposition, who opposes our policy of selling the rest of Telstra. I have just sat here and listened to him speak for about 17 minutes. Sadly, I heard only one argument that he has put to us today about why the government should not sell the rest of Telstraâthat is, the Australian people oppose us doing so. I think that is a relatively poor argument, considering that this is the fourth time we have been re-elected with selling the rest of Telstra as part of our platform to govern.

speech.para: My friend the member for Bowman has said to me todayâand I always take his counselâthat it would be something akin to cartoon violence to attack the opposition leader today, because he is already having a very bad day. There is something a bit gratuitous about standing up to slip the boot in when it has already been done to him on such a grand scale.

talk.start.para: âHis worst day would be better than your best; Iâll tell you that.

âI doubt that very much, Member for Cowan. But I would like to address the two bills that we are discussing here today: firstly, the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 2005, and then, following that, the Telecommunications Legislation Amendment (Competition and Consumer Issues) Bill 2005. (Quorum formed) Both of the bills that we are looking at today are part of a package of measures that I was very proud to campaign for during the last election campaign. It will be a good day for the residents of Stirling when these bills are passed. I am genuinely pleased that the passage of these bills will bring to an end one of the most absurd aspects of public policy in Australia today, where the largest telecommunications company in Australia remains in a hybrid form of ownership, half owned by the private sector and half owned by the government. That, plainly, is a ridiculous situation.

speech.para: We have heard from the Leader of the Opposition today about how services will suffer as a result of the passage of these bills. When you are in opposition, and you cannot seem to work out what you stand for, all that is left is opposition for its own sake. We have heard fearmongering on a grand scale in this debate and in the industrial relations debate, and we will continue to hear it until Labor comes up with some positives for Australia.

If Labor, under their current leadership, knew why they wanted to governâif they had a set of coherent ideas that they could take to the Australian people about improving the countryâit is just possible that they could have contributed in a constructive way to the creation of a new regulatory regime of telecommunications in this country. Alas, what they chose instead was blanket opposition, which contributes absolutely nothing to todayâs debate. What we have heardâand what we will no doubt hear, drearily, from speaker after speaker todayâis an ideological argument against privatisation. Amazingly, that argument was put this morning by somebody who championed privatisation when he was last in government.

The reality is that the continued health of telecommunications services in Australia has absolutely nothing to do with Telstra remaining half-owned by the government. When the Prime Minister addressed this chamber on 6 September this year, he said:

quote.para: The reality is that, until we get the burden of majority government ownership off Telstraâs back, it will not be able to operate as a fair dinkum company in the Australian telecommunications market. That is the reason why we are going to sell it. It has nothing to do with budget proceeds; it has nothing to do with ideology.

speech.para: Government ownership will not provide all Australians with access to first-class telecommunications. This has never been the case and never will be, whether the industry we are talking about is telecommunications or otherwise.

Perhaps the best example of this is the woeful situation that existed when Telecom Australia, as Telstra was then known, was 100 per cent owned by the government. When Telstra was 100 per cent in government hands, it took up to two years to get a telephone service connected. Now, no matter where you live in Australia, whether it be in the remotest part, the longest you will wait to get your phone connected is 20 daysâ20 days as opposed to two years when Telstra was 100 per cent in government hands.

The quality of services will be determined by the regulatory framework that the government will establishâa framework that will guarantee all Australians a base level of services. The government will retain the right to intervene when market failure does occur and to either enforce individual companies to remediate the problem or to fix the problem itself. Not only does this system of oversight allow a base level of services but it also ensures diversity within the market, which will result in more competition and therefore better services for all Australians. Government ownership does not ensure this; proper regulation does. I will continue to maintain that government ownership of Telstra detracts from its ability to provide services effectively when it is competing against up to 100 other competitors. The reality is that, since we came to government in 1996 and half privatised the company, telecommunications services have continued to improve.

Privatising Telstra is part of a longer term agenda to increase competition and efficiency in Australia and to strengthen our economy. Effective rules and regulations will guarantee services. Since 1997, telecommunications expenditure and commitments by the Australian government have exceeded $4 billion. Of this, $1 billion has been invested directly into telecommunications services in rural and regional Australia. This targeted funding investment has supported the provision of important telecommunications infrastructure and services. The new targeted funding package recently announced by the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts and the Prime Minister, which comes on top of all that has been done to provide services already, is a key element in the governmentâs strategy to future proof regional Australiaâs telecommunications services. The underlying message of this package is that it is the governmentâs priority to ensure that all Australians will have access to world-class phone and internet services.

I also rise today in support of the Telecommunications Legislation Amendment (Competition and Consumer Issues) Bill 2005. This forms part of the package of telecommunications legislation which gives effect to key components of the governmentâs Connect Australia telecommunications package. It gives effect to the competition and consumer regulatory changes that the government announced in August. I commend the governmentâs commitment to strengthening competition and consumer protection measures.

The bill guarantees that full privatisation of Telstra will be preceded by strong regulatory safeguards to protect and stimulate competition and encourage growth and diversification within the industry itself. The government will strengthen the framework to continue to promote an open and competitive telecommunications market to ensure that competition continues to develop now and into the future. The changes will beâvery sensiblyâtechnologically neutral, avoiding the mandating of any particular technologies in what is a very rapidly changing sector. The changes strike a balance between the need for regulation that promotes competitive services to consumers and the need to invest in new infrastructure. This is a twofold mechanism, allowing Telstra the scope to meet changing market conditions and the demand for services.

Since 1997, competition has already delivered tangible benefits to consumers in the form of lower prices and a greater choice of service providers and products. There are now over 100 companies providing telecommunications services. The benefits of this competition are most evident, I believe, in the area of international phone calls and mobile telephony. I well remember that it was a big occasion to make an international phone call when I was growing up and Telecom Australia was in charge of all the international calls going in and out of the country. Nowadays, due to competition, it is a lot cheaper and the benefits to consumers in that area and in mobile telephonyâwhere we have seen prices consistently reduce over the past decadeâshould be obvious for all to see. Competition has revolutionised our telecommunications market. We should remember these great advances when we are here today debating the benefits of competition. It is grossly unfair for players within this market, apart from Telstra, who are forced to compete against their own governmentâa situation in which true competition on an equitable basis can never occur.

There are many aspects to the governmentâs new regulatory and competition reforms that will benefit consumers. The bill will introduce operational separation to ensure that Telstra treats its wholesale customers fairly. It will also provide greater certainty for companies looking to make new investments in infrastructure, and clarify and speed up decision making by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission.

Perhaps the most significant advancement in all of this is the objective of operational separation, which will achieve transparency for Telstraâs wholesale customersâwho are of course their competitorsâso that they can be confident that they are getting a fair deal, compared with Telstraâs own retail businesses. This will work through the government introducing processes that ensure Telstra does not unfairly favour its own retail businesses over wholesale customers by imposing separation measures. This robust and effective measure is necessary to police Telstraâs behaviour post sale and will further make sure that collusion will not affect the market environment.

The requirements will mean that Telstra will have to implement separate retail, wholesale and key network business units, including separate premises and staff incentive programs based on the performance of those business units. This process will ensure that price and non-price terms and conditions are provided on an equivalent basis to Telstraâs retail and wholesale customers and that the government and the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission have oversight and enforcement. This model provides a sound approach to achieving the objectives without slicing and dicing Telstra into pieces. It is credible, cost-effective, durable, enforceable and tailored to Telstraâs business. The government are committed to ensuring that competitors get opportunities in what is a fiercely competitive market. We are determined to make Telstra accountable for their actions.

Other measures of this bill give the minister power to direct Telstra to amend the plan, if it is found not to be complying with that plan, and the power to rectify its behaviour. The minister also has broader powers to direct Telstra to amend the plan if it is found not to be operating effectively. By committing Telstra to an open and fully consultative process, it ensures fairness and transparency for Telstraâs competitors.

I would like to take this opportunity to make mention of the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Coonan. Her commitment, along with the commitment of others in the government in providing better telecommunications for all Australians, has been relentless. Recently she visited my electorate of Stirling, which is suffering from some broadband black spots. She announced a renewed commitment from Telstra through additional funding which will go a long way towards eradicating those black spots. I would like to thank the minister for doing that.

talk.start.para: â$200,000 will not go very far! It will not pay for much.

âThat is not true. You will find that all those black spots will be filled. I am happy to discuss that with the member for Swan afterwards. While the details are yet to be finalised, this extensive plan is going to strengthen competition and regulation through other measures.

speech.para: Also as part of this bill, the government will amend telecommunications-specific access and anticompetitive conduct provisions of the Trade Practices Act to provide greater certainty for new investment. This will ultimately improve the operation of the telecommunications access regime for competition, creating more options for consumers. To provide greater certainty to investors in new networks, the ACCC will be required to consider the costs and risks associated with new network investment when making access decisions. This builds on existing provisions which allow companies to seek certainty about how they will be treated by the ACCC prior to making investments. Obviously, our providing that certainty within the market is vitally important when they are making business decisions.

To improve and speed up decision making by the ACCC, the government will be providing additional resources to that body to enable them to fulfil their mission effectively. Also, by streamlining the ACCCâs processes and requiring the ACCC to make procedural rules for declaring new services, assessing access undertakings and arbitrating access pricing disputes, the federal government is further enhancing the body that will effectively regulate the telecommunications sector. This will be reviewed again in 2009, which will ensure telecommunications competition arrangements keep up with the demands of consumers and the market.

Furthermore, the current price controls on Telstra expire at the end of the year. The government will introduce new price controls on Telstra, to commence from 1 January 2006. These price controls will maintain the 22c cap on untimed local calls; ensure parity in local call prices offered to regional and metropolitan customers; cap increases in the charges for connecting phones, in line with inflation; ensure that, on average, there will be no price increases across a basket of Telstraâs line rentals, local calls, STD, international and fixed-to-mobile calls; protect consumers from major line rental increases by allowing only basic line rental products to increase to match inflation; and, finally, require Telstra to have a package of services targeted to low-income consumers. However, the new price controls will no longer cover services provided to large businesses. This ensures that the benefits of all call price reductions are passed through to consumers and small businesses. This is an important aspect of the governmentâs commitment to protecting its current and future customers and making sure that their hip pockets are safeguardedâanother avenue where the Australian government protects its taxpayers.

Recognising that continued evolution of competition may place pressure on Telstraâs national pricing structures, the government will be looking further into the interaction between the current approaches to wholesale and retail pricing, in consultation with Telstra and the ACCC. These changes will ensure competition continues to develop in Australia and will continue to bring benefits to consumers in the form of lower prices and new and improved services.

The Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 2005 forms part of a package of legislation that coincides with the Telecommunications Legislation Amendment (Competition and Consumer Issues) Bill 2005. The bill will enable the Commonwealth to sell its remaining shares in Telstra, and it is imperative that this happens. Passage of this bill will trigger our commitment to providing $1.1 billion in funding for broadband, mobile and Indigenous community services, as well as the establishment of the $2 billion Communications Fund, to be maintained in perpetuity for funding future upgrades as determined by regular reviews. Despite owning Telstra, the government does not control Telstraâs operations. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âLabor opposes the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 2005 and related bill. These bills do not just sell Telstra; they sell out Australia and they short-change Australians. There are two related elements to these debates, and both of them lead to the same conclusion: Telstra must not be sold. The first element is a consideration of the parlous state of the network. I have just heard the member for Stirling talk about how good things are, but this is a network that this government and successive Telstra boards have brought to its knees. The second element is the treatment of small Telstra shareholders, who have been short-changed by this governmentâs unhealthy obsession with the Telstra sale.

speech.para: This is a government that ought to be ashamed of itself for what it has done to Telstra, not just by these bills but over the last nine years. It is a cumulative disgrace. We are dealing with not just another broken election promiseâa promise that the government would not sell a further share in Telstra until the system was up to scratchâbut the fact that the government has overseen massive underinvestment in the Telstra network, which has denied many Australians access to a world-class telecommunications system. Everyone knows that the economic future of this country has to be built around participating in the services economy, in particular, and having access to world-class telecommunications. If the regions, in particular, cannot get hooked up to world-class broadband services, they will not be able to compete and cannot be part of the growth opportunities, and that is where a government that owns and controls what is almost a public monopoly in terms of the provision of this infrastructure quite frankly has to play a role.

I remind the House that, for the whole of the past nine years, the government has been the majority shareholder. It has been able to influence decisions of the board. As the national government, it has had the capacity to directly invest in the nationâs infrastructure, but it has failed on that task. If in fact the system is not up to scratch now when the government has owned and controlled the company, how does anyone seriously expect the system to improve when it is fully privatisedâexcept at a price? And that is the rub. That is one of the aspects this government will not tell you about. On top of all thisâon top of the failure to invest, on top of the fact that the company has massively underinvestedâthe government just did not tell us; it failed to disclose, and it failed to allow to be disclosed, the true state of the network. It took a new CEO straight off the plane from America to reveal the state of Telstraâs network and the boardâs unsustainable dividend policy. What was the Prime Ministerâs response? His response was to attack the management of the company. But attack them for what? He attacked them for telling the truth.

The Prime Minister had form in this regard. Remember the ânever, ever manâ in terms of the GST? This is a person who does not want the truth told when it does not suit the governmentâs interests. This is a failing that has not only held back the economic development of the nation; it has ultimately hurt the company. Largely forgotten by the government have been the T2 investors. Those investors have been horribly burnt. They have seen a 40 per cent decline in the value of their investments.

I have heard the Prime Minister talk in this House about one of his so-called proudest achievements: the way in which ordinary wage earners have been able to get real wage increases. How proud is he of telling people to buy the T2 sharesâthe second tranche of Telstraâand to have faith in the government, only to see their value decline dramatically by 40 per cent? The truth of it is that these investors paid more for their shares because the government did not tell them the truth. They were told by the government that the Telstra share value was growing strongly and that investment would help them plan for their future. Some future! They have lost 40 per cent in value. Thousands of dollars have been lost by these investors.

Apart from the fact that the government has not got the system up to scratch, it should not have brought these bills into the House before it answered these two critical questions in relation to the investorsâthe mum and dad investors. First, how was the T2 price calculated or substantiated? Second, why did the subscription price drop so dramatically? The government has an obligation to answer those questions. These are the questions that matter, not only to the T2 investors, who have a right to know, but to the potential victims of the T3 float.

The bills purport to future-proof regional and rural Australiaâs telecommunications. They do not. They consign regional Australians to a second-rate telecommunications future. We now know by virtue of the secret dossier that was presented by Telstra that the government has overseen underinvestment to the tune of $2 billion to $3 billion in the Telstra network over the past three to five years. Rural and regional Australians have been by far the biggest losers. Telstra reveals in the secret document that one in seven lines is faulty. Just think of itâa government telling us the system is up to scratch, but Telstra telling us that one in seven lines fails. How can the government say the system is up to scratch when one in seven lines fails?

The worst of the worst exchangesâa list that I released last weekârevealed that the extent of Telstraâs network failings was worst in rural and regional Australia. The overwhelming majority of Australiaâs failing exchanges are located in regional Australia. I have talked before about how regions will not be given the opportunity to grow, to create jobs, to take part in the prosperity, unless they get access to world-class communications. The system is failing all around the country, but the biggest failures are in the regions. Many of those areas are located in the electorates of National Party and Liberal Party members. They have sold out their constituencies.

Senator Joyce capitulated, but at least he had a go. He asked the questions. He pushed the government. It is a huge disappointmentânot only to us but more importantly to the constituents in Queensland he claims to representâthat he was mugged, bruised and bullied and that he conceded. He voted with the government. The members for Riverina and Hume have abstained from voting in this chamber. They know how poisonous this decision is within their electorates. They should have a bit more courage and come in and vote with us against the sale. As for the rest of The Nationals, they might as well be members of the Liberal Party. These days the National Party is just a paid-up sub-branch of the Liberal Party.

talk.start.para: âItâs a disgrace.

âIt is an absolute disgrace. So great is this betrayal by the National Party that this vote will do to them what the GST did to the Democrats. The government said that they would not sell another share in Telstra until it was up to scratch. I have already said that one in seven lines fails, and that the worst of the worst are in the regions. But this was not a promise that was made once by the Prime Ministerâit was certainly made before the last electionâit was a promise made on at least 20 other occasions where we have access to the records. The Prime Minister promised the country not to sell a further share in Telstra before services in the regions were up to scratch.
âHeâs sold out.

âHe has sold out. The government has sold out. These were members of parliament who went to the last electionâforget about the Prime Ministerâs word; we know that it is worthlessâin each of their seats with the same promise: âWe wonât sell another share until the system is up to scratch.â We have just heard the minister for communications praised in this House by the other side. What did she concede recently? She conceded that services outside the capital cities are not as reliable as other services. That is straight from the horseâs mouth, straight from the person praised. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Mr Pearce, who is at the table, laughs. This is the governmentâs responseâthey gloat, they smirk. They have all taken smirk lessons from the Treasurer. They think it is so effective. The fact is they have made lying an art form. They have gone to the electorate and continued to tell untruths and they expect the Australian public will not catch up with them.

speech.para: By no objective assessment can it be said that regional services are up to scratch. Even the National Farmers Federation, in the course of its pathetic capitulation on the Telstra issue, has restated its views that regional services are not up to scratch but, unlike the Labor Party, the NFF leadership has joined the National Party in rolling over and selling out its constituency.

talk.start.para: âIt is the National Party.

âI wonder about that. Certainly the leadership seems to be in that camp. It makes one wonder at what point Mr Corish and his colleagues were themselves mugged, like Barnaby Joyce. I remember Mr Corish in the Senate inquiry, in the one-day assessment the government allowed the Senate to undertake. We have one day for debate on these bills in this chamber, today, and the debate has been guillotined to three hours, and there was a one-day review. The biggest company in the country and the government allows scrutiny by the parliament for two days. What a disgrace!

speech.para: But even with that the NFF were not convinced. What have they got? I would like to see the letter that is referred toâthe set of undertakings that the government has given. We have seen letters from this government on policy positions before; they are worthless. The National Farmers Federation will find, to their everlasting shame, that this government will dud them.

But the House will be pleased to hear that not all farm organisations have rolled over. The Western Australian Farmers Federation and the Queensland Farmers Federation publicly maintain their opposition to the sale. Good on them. They know what is in the interests of their members, and it is not the sale of Telstra. The South Australian Farmers Federation are also standing firm. Let me read a statement issued by them in the wake of the NFFâs sell-out. I ask the members for Grey, Barker, Mayo and Wakefield to take note. This is what the South Australian Farmers Federation had to say:

quote.para: Some rural and regional areas in South Australia have some of the oldest and poorest telecommunications infrastructure in Australia. If this is not fixed before the full sale of Telstra, we will be passing on substandard infrastructure to generations to come, which will make their farm businesses and rural communities unsustainable.

speech.para: I can understand the government not caring about rural Australia but not the National Party. What is its base, if it is not the farm sector? We have a circumstance in South Australia where the farmersâ representatives are saying, âWe will have unsustainable businessesâ, but the National Party does not want to hear that. It turns a deaf ear; it turns against its constituency. I tell you: no party will survive if it ignores its base. The National Party has ignored its base and will pay a heavy price.

âUnsustainableââindeed! The word âunsustainableâ is not my word; it is the word of the farm sector in South Australia. Why do they say that? They say it with good cause, because we now know that Telstra estimates that investment of $5.7 billion is necessary to deliver next generation broadband to households and businesses across Australia. How can farms survive and sustain themselves in the future unless they are going to have access to that? How do they get up-to-date weather reports? How do they follow where the prices are? How do they make those sorts of decisions that are so vital to modern businesses? How do they do it if they do not have the services? They do notâthey suffer; they go out of business; they are forced off the land. Well done, National Party! That is the sort of future you are consigning your base to.

The governmentâs sale package, whatever it says, will not deliver that investment. It will not even fix the current holes in the network. The proposed Connect Australia program falls far short of what is needed. We have seen the examples of the rorts programs. There is absolutely no guarantee that the funds will not fall victim to the same sort of rorting that the government has turned into an art form.

Let the House understand this: returns from the proposed Communications Fund will not begin to flow until 2008âthat is three years awayâand will provide only a fraction of the existing Telstra dividend stream, which, on most estimates, is $100 million a year. Forget about the $2 billion; that is what is being invested in a trust fund. The only thing that will be available from it for telecommunications improvement is the earnings on the fund. Do you think $100 million is going to be enough per year, especially set against a dividend stream that has been producing in the order of $1.3 billion to $2 billion a year? What nonsense. How could the National Party fall for this stupidity? The simple truth is that the investment in telecommunications infrastructure has been funded from Telstraâs existing dividend stream.

The Acting Prime Minister yesterday, in his answer to a dorothy dixer from the member for HinklerâI recall this wellâchallenged Labor to say what policy it had ever put forward to fix the infrastructure problem in telecommunications. I will tell him. Back in 1998 Labor proposed the establishment of the Telstra reward fundâa fund that would see not all of the dividend from Telstra but 35 per cent of it paid into a fund to improve rural, regional and other infrastructure particularly associated with telecommunications. We repeated that policy on a number of occasions. I got the Parliamentary Library recently to calculate what that fund would be worth today had it been invested in. Do you know what it would be worth? $5.3 billion. What does that tell us? It tells us that the problem in telecommunications can be fixed without selling Telstra. That is the point. If you have the will, determination and preparedness as majority shareholderâas a government that actually believes that investing in our future and telecommunications is important for regional Australiaâyou make sure the investment happens. You either do it as the majority shareholder sitting on the board and reinvesting the companyâs profits or you do it as a government from the dividend stream that it gets.

But we have seen that the government has only had two purposes for the dividend. One is to prop up its budget surpluses. We know back in 2001-02 that, if it had not been for the Telstra dividend stream, the budget would have been in deficit. The Treasurer does not like deficits; the Treasurer does not want them, so he will do anything. He will raid Telstra. He will tell it that it cannot invest again in the system; it has to invest in us, the government, and in our survival! The second reason that it has been keen to get these dividends is to keep the share price fattened, to keep it up, and to make people believe that this payment of dividends means that the company is travelling well and therefore the share price is worth something. Why was that important? Because it had to con people even more that T2 was worth something. We now know that T2 is worth lessâa lot less; 40 per cent less.

This is a government that has not had a vision for telecommunications and the layout of its infrastructure. I say this to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, who is at the table: read Laborâs policy and understand what could have been achieved in this. It is a policy that demonstrates that you do not need to sell Telstraâjust fix it, and you can fix it without selling it.

The policy that we proposed was important not just in terms of the infrastructure. We have also demonstrated that selling Telstra is bad for the budget. We have done this on a number of occasions, and our calculation has been confirmed by the Treasury. There is an excellent article by David Uren in todayâs Australian that shows that this sale of Telstra, on his calculations, is bad for the budget. Even on his most generous forecast, it will cost the budget at least $290 millionâand, having sold it, you do not have the dividend stream which comes year in, year out; you lose that forever.

Not only is it bad for the bush; it is bad for the budget. Why would you do it? That is the point in terms of this governmentâs obsession. They say it is not ideological. What is it? It is not based on any sense that it is going to improve regional infrastructure. It is not based on any sense that the investment is going to be guaranteed in a world-class telecommunications system in this country. It is not based on anything that says that it is going to be great for the budget. There is more pain for the T2 shareholders. They have seen their share price drop even further since the release of the secret document.

There is a very interesting question here in relation to a class action if in fact, on 11 August, Telstra came here and said, âWe have a shocking system; we have a system that has been underinvested in; we have an unsustainable dividend practice,â and the Prime Minister said, âOh, thatâs no good; keep that hidden; donât tell anyone about that.â But then it got out. I think there is a very interesting question. What about the people who invested in T2 between 11 August and the time of the revelations in the document? Donât you think they are entitled to action against the board of directors of Telstra for having been kept in the dark and making an investment believing what was out there in the marketplace when the deceit of what was out there in the marketplace was different from what was being said in the secrecy of the cabinet room?

The Prime Minister gets a secret briefing but he does not want the truth out. But it gets out. Indeed, when it gets out, the Prime Minister is asked to release it and he says no, it was a secret briefing. So concerned is the Securities and Investment Commission, the watchdog, that it is now investigating Telstra and, as I understand it, investigating the Prime Minister and his statements. Well, it should. The legislation that we are passing today in this parliamentâcourtesy of the Liberal Party and the sell-out National Partyâis bad for the bush, bad for the budget and bad for investors. That is what it is about. We will campaign on these issues around the country, day in, day out, to make sure that people understand not only the lost opportunity but the dudding that they have been getting. That is a solemn promise.

The value of T2 shares has fallen by 40 per cent since the listing. This week the shares are languishing at a two-year low. How does the government explain that fact? How does it explain the collapse of share value for mum and dad investors who believed the government when it told them that T2 was a good deal? Quite simply, it cannot, and it does not. No company engaged in such deception would be allowed to get away with it, but, as always, there is one rule for this arrogant government and one rule for everyone else. It is clear that the interests of small shareholders have been the last thing on this governmentâs mind. The government has sold out the bush and it has sold out small investors. A good government this one! Just remember it next time you are asked to vote for it. It is in the clear interests of small shareholdersâ

talk.start.para: âWhat about the Commonwealth Bank?
âWhat about the Commonwealth Bank? Here is this rabbit talking about the past. We are talking about the future.
Mr Pearce interjectingâ
âYou can take offence at that, but you are a rabbit if that is all you can come up with. I am asking you to answer these questions honestly.
(Hon. BK Bishop)âI remind the member that he should direct his comments through the chair.
âHow does the government not disclose this information?
âHop up and down?

âYes, go down a hole; I think that is the best solution for him. These shareholders deserve the truthâthe truth about their investment. At the briefing on 11 August, Telstra revealed that its network is crumbling from massive underinvestment, one in seven of its telephone lines is faulty, the staff are undertrained, its IT systems are hopelessly inadequate, and its dividend stream is built on unsustainable borrowings. Well, that is a good scoresheet! I wonder what the market would think of that. I know what it already thinks, and it means another loss to T2 shareholders. Customers deserve this information; T2 investors deserve this information. They only got it because Labor forced the governmentâs hand. As I say, the Prime Minister was perfectly happy to keep it hidden.

speech.para: This government does not want the sale subjected to any scrutiny. That is why we have seen this dreadful guillotining, this shameful abuse of the democratic processesâno scrutiny. There are questions that still need to be answered. What will happen to the share price now that Telstraâs dividend policy has been exposed and, according to its own board, is unsustainable? We need to know the answer to that. We also need to know how a toothless local presence plan will stop Telstra packing up and deserting regional communities when it cannot turn a buck. And we need to know how the government will stop a rampant privatised Telstra putting the interests of its shareholders first and the interests of the customers and employees last. On the employee issue, it is not just the secret document the other day but also another document that the government will not releaseâ14,000 job losses.

Yesterday Labor revealed a chilling email written by Mr Greg Winn, another one of the amigos, in which he said that they âDo not expect any radical moves to strip people out until we are readyââin other words, until the bills are through the parliament. Once it cannot be held up to anymore scrutiny, then we will sack them, then we will cut more services, then we will disinvest in the company. All for the purposes of getting this grubby deal through the parliament, they will sit quiet on it. It is little wonder Australians oppose this sale. They oppose it in droves and they will have that opportunity when we campaign around this. I said that we oppose these bills. But I believe it is important to record the basis of our opposition with an amendment. I move:

para.inline: That all words after âThatâ be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
âthat this House declines to give the bills a second reading and:

item.para: condemns the government for failing to honour the Prime Ministerâs Telstra election promise that âwe wonât sell another share until weâre satisfied, completely satisfied that things in the bush are up to scratch,â and
