speech.para: This legislation should not be passed. It is a disgrace. It is a broken promise. It sells out Australia. It sells out Australians. It should be opposed.

talk.start.para: (Hon. BK Bishop)âIs the amendment seconded?
âI second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

âThe member for Hotham may be a good swimmer, but as an economist he really belongs to the Moscow central branch. His policies and his economic foresight really belong to the old Fabian socialist school, or more likely the Trotskyite school of central Europe.
âThis is withering stuff. You didnât even listen to the speech!
âIf you actually visit central Europe, they will tell you in places like Hungary, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Poland, Estoniaâ
âHere we goâthe old Cold War lives on in the Liberal Party.

âOf course, they donât want to listen. We listened in quietness to the member for Hotham, with his old-fashioned Fabian socialist ideas of how he wants big government to own every enterprise in the whole model that was shown to the world as being one of failure. Point to a socialist system that has worked effectively and that provides for its workers, for the members of the country, a very significant increase in their standards of living. I will show you one on the other side of the agenda where real growth occurs, where the private sector is the one that runs the economy, not the government owning large enterprises. It cannot respond to market changes in a whole different, dynamic world. That is the fact.
âYou live in Sydney, Bruce.

âI have heard the member for New England arguing before his old-fashionedâ(Quorum formed) As I was sayingâand I thank the Chief Opposition Whip for drawing the attention of my colleagues to what I am sayingâthe members opposite are living in this brave new Fabian socialist world, where big government controls big business and everything that happens in it, rather than in a free market economy, where the governmentâs role is to get out of business and to be there simply as regulator. That model has proved successful in those countries around the world that have adopted it. That model, which responds to modern economic conditions, has delivered to those countries the right economic returns with growth in GDP, significant improvements in real living standards and reductions in unemployment and in inflation.

speech.para: The member for Hotham has outlined the model of previous days at great length. We know that today, with the Latham diaries dominating the events of this House, all those opposite are following the line, regardless of what they actually think. Mr Latham has highlighted the fact that those opposite are finished as a political forceâand this, the Telstra debate, is a prime example of why they are finished. They live so much in the past, with past ideology as to the management of the economy. In contrast, this side of the House is concerned with appropriate management of the economy and with providing real results for the people of Australia.

Let us look at the results in terms of GDP growth. Since this government has been in power, we have had an average GDP growth of 3Â½ per cent per annum. We now have the lowest unemployment rate that we have seen in this country for over 25 yearsâdown to five per cent. I know, Madam Deputy Speaker Bishop, in your seat and in mine, those figures are down to about 2Â½ per cent. So the people in our areas know that this government delivers. Then there are real wages. Whether they be blue-collar workers, white-collar workers or management people, the real income of people in Australia has risen by over 15 per cent since this government came to power. With all your unionist mates and their Fabian socialism, under your government real wages only rose by three per cent. It highlights the fact that, under a free market economy under appropriate management, we have real growth for the average worker of this country. This is what we have in terms of the privatisation bill before us. This bill is about allowing government corporations to compete in the private sector without being trammelled by the numerous regulatory constraints of a government body.

There is some degree of hypocrisy in this exercise. If we go through past speeches, as I have been doing, we find out what those opposite did when they were on this side of the House. On 17 September 1990, in speaking about the privatisation of various bodies, Mr Beazley said:

quote.para: When someone raises such a matter we are entitled to expect that person to come into the chamber with a coherent privatisation strategy.

speech.para: They were the words of the Leader of the Opposition in September 1990âand how he changes his tune pragmatically when Leader of the Opposition. Then in October 1990, in praising Bill Kelty, Mr Keating said:

quote.para: He has been powerful because, basically, he has moved the trade union movement to this policy. But he has stood in support of the sale of Australian Airlines Ltd and Qantas Airways Ltd. The Opposition could never do these things.

speech.para: There they were, privatising Qantas, as they privatised Australian Airlines and the Commonwealth Bank. When they were on this side of the House, it was all okay. They spoke about the great moves they were makingâthe great economic reforms. Mr Hawke, in a speech on this issue, said:

quote.para: These decisions are yet another instalment of the Governmentâs drive for micro-economic reform, a process that is creating a more dynamic and efficient Australian economy, an economy that can take on and compete with the worldâs best.

speech.para: Precisely; that is the type of government we want in this country and the type of economic reform we want to see in itâbasic microeconomic reform which moves this country forward. We compete in a globalised world, where corporate bodies are out there looking for every opportunity. Unless we move forward by taking the advantages of reform, we will slip further down on the table of economic performers. We are very proud that, within the range of OECD countries, we sit amongst the top economic performers in the world. What a great achievement that is.

Turning to this bill, let us look at some of the comments appearing in the newspapers. Do they support the opposition in its stand? Let us take the editorial in the Australian. About the sale of Telstra, it says:

quote.para: This is good, if long overdue, news, a result The Weekend Australian has advocated for many years ... By getting out of telecommunications, the Government will release about $30 billion. Treasurer Peter Costello has talked of using this money to pay for public service pensions, which would free up tax revenues to be spent on useful social programs. There is no reason not to do it.

speech.para: It goes on to say:

quote.para: There is no longer any need for the public sector to own telecommunications infrastructure, anywhere. Rural rent-seekersÂ ...

speech.para: may have their commentsâ

quote.para: But as The Australianâs Newspoll showed this week, 79 per cent of people outside the capital cities are satisfied with their phone service, 6 per cent more than the comparable city figure.

speech.para: But we were not content with that. With this proposal, the government is putting in $3Â½ billion to improve our telecommunications network around this country and in country areas. So the Australian strongly supports our proposal to privatise Telstra.
The Financial Review says:

quote.para: Notwithstanding the tortuous nine-year path to this point, the prospect of finally privatising one of Australiaâs biggest companies is relief.
Telstra will be free to chart its own course, subject to regulation. And the governmentâs paradoxâbeing both owner and regulatorâwill disappear.
Let the market make its verdict on the performance of the company. And let management and shareholders do the work of grappling with the regulator.

speech.para: That is the advice of the Financial Review. I am sure that very few members opposite bother to read what the financial sector has to say about the governmentâs proposals. The Financial Review says: âThis is a good idea. It is long overdue. It is important for microeconomic reform and it is important for the reform of our economy.â

What a great contrast with the speech we have just had from the member for Hotham, who is back in the pastâback controlling and owning these large government corporations; never mind the marketplace. He talked about the share value. If the government had had its way, we would have seen the privatisation long ago and in a different market situation. The question is: what do the editorial writers say? They are fully supportive. What do the newspapers say? They are all fully supportive. Who says anything different? The only people who say anything different are the unions, who are living in the past, living in their own Trotskyist little cells out there and saying, âLetâs take over the old companies, letâs put our mates on the board and letâs run them as a public service network.â This is what they want for the future.

The Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 2005 will empower the government to sell its remaining shares in Telstra at some point in the future when the government deems the conditions to be right to proceed with the sale. It will remove the requirement in the Telstra Corporation Act 1991 for the Commonwealth to maintain a 50 per cent plus one share in Telstra. This is all supposed to be very radical, according to the opposition, but this is exactly the same requirement and bill that they put through in relation to Qantas when they diluted the amount of government ownership in that. We supported that move totally, but all you people on the opposite side can do to show how irrelevant you are is say: âWeâre against it. No matter what the government proposes, weâre against it. No matter what our track record is in privatisation, weâre against it. No matter what it might do to free up the economy and improve competition from other telcos, weâre against it.â

This bill has been designed to allow as much flexibility as possible in setting the terms of the sale. The Future Fund is so important in allowing us to prepare for the futureâthe future requirements of the government in the area of superannuation liabilities and infrastructure building across the country. How important is that? If you look at the United States, they expect there will be a significant gap. In 10 years time, 23 per cent of the economy will be required for or involved in their social security payments, their superannuation liability for public servants right across the board and their Medicare obligations. The current government take is 15 per cent, and there is a lot of concern about how they will bridge that gap. But this government has recognised the problems of the future, including the demographic changes that are occurring, and is preparing for the future through the Future Fund, which is a very significant, innovative step forward and one to be supported.

The bill will remove a number of ministerial discretionary powers and reporting obligations once government ownership falls below 15 per cent. It also affirms the universal service obligation and the customer service guarantee, which are so significant. It is not as if we are cutting and running. The government will continue to look at community service obligations and at what we need to do to look after the interests in the bush.

Despite the protestations from the member for New England, telecommunications service in the bush under this government and Telstra has improved dramatically. We have seen the provision of $1.1 billion in funding for broadband, mobile and Indigenous communications services. A further $2 billion Communications Fund is to be maintained in perpetuity for funding future upgrades, as determined by regular reviews into regional communication. This bill will also allow the government to remove and redress the conflict of interest that arises from having the government as both the regulator and the largest participator in the communications marketplace.

In conclusion, may I say that the members opposite continue to live in the past, in an old socialist world of the government owning all the major companies. This government is moving forward in response to the demands of the time and providing a competitive environment so that Telstra, cut free of the obligations of being government owned, will service the community and have competitors. At the same time, through the amount that is received from the sale of the shares, we will achieve a significant plus in terms of looking to the future of this country. We will put that amount into infrastructure and into paying off liabilities. Of course, members opposite have no concern about future liabilities. We know how they racked up some $96 billion in debt. Their economic responsibility is clear for everyone to see, and their hypocrisy is clear for everyone to see, given what they did with the sale of the Commonwealth Bank, the sale of Qantas and the sale of Australian Airlines. The government have said consistently that we aim to sell Telstra as part of our move for microeconomic reform in this country. I support the sale strongly, and I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: âToday we see the government ramming through its ideological obsession with the full privatisation of Telstra in less than a morningâs debate. It has had this ideological obsession, shared by John Howard and Peter Costello, for a long time. In ramming through its ideological obsession this morning in less than half a dayâs debate, what do we find? We find the Howard-Costello governmentâthe Liberal and National partiesâdoing that in breach of an express election commitment made to the Australian people. That commitment was not just made on one occasion, in the run-up to the 2004 election. There was an express commitment made in the 2004 election, the 2001 election and the 1998 election that the government would not further privatise Telstra unless there was a guarantee of adequate services to rural and regional Australiaâunless, as the Prime Minister has put it, services were up to scratch. And that faithful promise, that faithful commitment to the Australian people, is being broken today.

speech.para: I have been a member of this parliament since 1993, and at every election since thenâ1993, 1996, 1998, 2001 and 2004âthe Liberal and National parties have gone to the Australian people with a commitment to privatise part or privatise more of Telstra, and on every occasion the Labor Party has gone to the Australian people opposed to any or any further privatisation of Telstra. Today we meet that faithful undertaking that we made to the Australian people at successive electionsâ1993, 1996, 1998, 2001 and 2004. Today the government is pursuing its ideological objective. In the course of pursuing its ideological objective, in the course of pursuing its obsession with the privatisation of Telstra over the last 9Â½ long years that the government has been in office, we have seen the government comprehensively neglecting a whole range of telecommunications issues, which has rendered Australiaâs international competitiveness in telecommunications down at the bottom of the scale. That applies in particular to some of the competitive and regulatory arrangements which I will come to in due course as I make some remarks on the Telecommunications Legislation Amendment (Competition and Consumer Issues) Bill 2005.

The Australian people and this parliament should not forget that when John Howard made his election promises in 1996 he said to the Australian people that he would go to the 1996 election with a promise to privatise one-third of Telstraâwhat we know famously as T1. In the run-up to the 1996 election and in the so-called great debate in that election campaign, John Howard was asked on a number of occasions: âYou only want to privatise one-third? That leaves one-third private and two-thirds public. Doesnât that leave you a bit pregnant?â In response, John Howard said on more than one occasion: âNo, no. Thatâs the right public policy mix.â So, having told that to the Australian people in 1996 so that he could slide through and get himself elected by hiding the complete extent of his ideological obsession, he said: âNo, thatâs a fine public policy mix. There is no drama attached to that. That is not unusual. There are over 30 telcos in OECD countries that have a mix of private and public ownership. Telstra is not unique in that respect.â But suddenly these days, of course, this becomes the reason why. The Prime Minister says there is a yoke on Telstra, that the great burden on Telstra is the two-thirds, one-third mix of public and private ownership. If that is the caseâwhich I do not agree with and which I rejectâit is a yoke or a burden the Prime Minister has put on the company himself.

When we look at the history of the governmentâs privatisation efforts with the T1 privatisation and the subsequent T2 privatisationâwhen the parliament, courtesy of Senator Harradine, authorised a further sale from 33â  per cent to 49 per centâon both those occasions we have seen the governmentâs economic management credentials being very seriously challenged and questioned. On the first occasion, T1, the analysis of the Auditor-General after the event was that the government had put those shares out to market at a substantially lower price, at cost to the taxpayer. With T2, the nearly two millionâthe 1.6 to 1.7 millionâsmall shareholders know to their cost the incompetent economic management by the government.

We will all recallâI certainly recallâthe Prime Minister, when asked about what investors should do in respect of T2, saying in the context of that further privatisation that it was a great deal. The question was put to him: âWhat should worried investors think about Telstra?â He said, âItâs a great deal.â The then Minister for Finance, one of the formal shareholders of the Commonwealth, Mr Fahey, said on the floor of this chamber that it was a worthwhile investment and people should contemplate in the context of that investment the fact that the Commonwealth continued to have substantial assets and holdings in Telstra.

So we had the Prime Minister saying in 1996 that one-third, two-thirds, a mix of public and private, is an ownership mix which does not cause any public policy difficulties. We had the then Minister for Finance saying in the context of T2, and following on from the Prime Minister saying that it was a great deal, that one of the reasons it was a great deal was that the Commonwealth government had a shareholding, an ownership arrangement. Those small investor shareholders out there who purchased their T2 shares at $7.80 are perfectly entitled, as letters to editors and radio talkback feedback indicates, to feel that they have been ripped off by the government in respect of their shareholding arrangements.

I return to that solemn pledge that the Liberal and National parties made, not just in the 2004 election but in 2001 and in 1998, that they would not further or fully privatise Telstra unless services to rural and regional Australia were up to scratch. Let us look at the objective record: I can recall month after month the reports of the old Australian Communications Authority detailing service deficiencies in outer metropolitan Australia and in rural and regional Australia and the government, in pursuit of its ideological obsession, trying to establish inquiry after inquiry to try to get any inquiry to say that services were up to scratch.

Their first inquiry was chaired by Mr Besley. Even before Mr Besley took any evidence, he was on the public record quite happily saying that he was a supporter of the full privatisation of Telstra, that he was a full privatiser. Yet not even Mr Besley could be brought to the barrier; not even Mr Besley could recommend in a report that services in rural and regional Australia were up to scratch. Having failed with Mr Besley, in a subsequent parliament the government moved on to Mr Estens. They got a bit closer with Mr Estens. Mr Estens said that if you adopt these 39 recommendations and implement them then there is some chance that services in rural and regional Australia might be adequate.

The problem for the government is, firstly, that not all those recommendations have been implemented and, secondly, that the National Farmers Federation, both its national body and its constituent state branches, is out there saying that, despite a partial implementation of the Estens inquiry recommendations, services to regional and rural Australia are not up to scratch. As if you needed any further adviceâthe government could not get the Besley inquiry up to the mark and it could not get the Estens inquiry up to the mark. If we fast forward to the current context, we now knowâout of the horseâs mouth on 11 August this yearâthat Telstra itself was providing the government with detailed advice that shows conclusively a failure to invest in Telstra over recent years in the order of $3 billion to $4 billion, which included paying dividends out of reserves, and Telstra is incapable of providing adequate service to rural and regional Australia or to outer metropolitan Australia. We find in Telstraâs once secret advice on 11 Augustâwhich the government was happy to try and keep secret, but we know how the cat got out of the bag on that oneâthat Telstra has received 14 million phone fault reports and that over 14 per cent of Telstraâs lines are faulty. On Telstraâs own admission, how could you in any sensible or plausible way expect that that would lead to adequacy of services in rural and regional Australia?

In that context we find earlier today the amendment coming back from the Senateâthe drop in the ocean, last-minute, âBackdown Barnabyâ, National Party inducement. Where has the National Partyâthat once great National Partyâbeen on this issue? Black Jack McEwen would be rolling in his grave at the way in which the current National Party has tugged its forelock to the Liberal Party lawyers from Melbourne and Sydneyâa once great National Party, who once saw it as its role in life to stand up for the interests of rural and regional Australia. Where are they now? They are tugging their forelocks to the Liberal Party lawyers from Melbourne and Sydney. What would those once great National and Country Party ministers, AnthonyâAnthony senior, of courseâNixon, Hunt and Sinclair, be thinking as they look in now? What would those once great National Party ministers be thinking looking in and seeing the decline of a once great National Party now led by Mr Vaile, the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade, supported by his own deputy, Mr Truss, the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, and the last cab off the ministerial rank for the National Party, Mr McGauran, who has the responsibility for the passage of these bills through this parliament? What would those ministers be thinking looking in at the decline of a once great political party led now by Mr Vaile, previously led by Mr Anderson, the former Deputy Prime Minister? It is a regrettable fact on an analysis of Australian politics that the current leader and former leader make Charles Blunt look like an effective leader of the National Party. At least you could say of Charles Blunt that he put his stamp on the National Party. The only stamp that is being put on the National Party these days is the stamp of the Liberal Party from Melbourne and Sydney, driven by an ideological obsession with the full privatisation of Telstra.

As a consequence of that ideological position there is no concern about the interests of the Commonwealth taxpayer, as reflected by the T1 privatisation, no concern about the interests of small investor shareholders, as shown by the aftermath of T2, and no concern for the national interest, as shown by their ideological obsession. They are refusing to baulk in any way at the secret advice received from Telstra on 11 August and refusing to baulk in any way at the suggestions that Telstra themselves remain very concerned about their capacity to meet their obligations to rural and regional Australia.

Part of that ideological obsession has seen a serious neglect so far as the government is concerned of some major regulatory and competitive issues. We find the culmination of those regulatory and competitive issues now contained in the additional legislation: the Telecommunications Legislation Amendment (Competition and Consumer Issues) Bill 2005. It is quite clear that the model that the government has adopted in that bill is fundamentally flawed. The problem for government is that it has adopted a model of operational separation that is fundamentally flawed. The operational separation regime outlined in the bill is considered by the Senate Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts Legislation Committee inquiry into the bill as containing very little detail as to how that final operational separation model will operate. The bill merely provides a very broad framework for that operational separation model and then allows Telstra three months to prepare a draft operational separation plan for approval by the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. In other words, the government is effectively saying that it wants to set up a regulatory regime for Telstra, but it is happy to let Telstra write that regulatory regime, with the minister giving it the tick behind closed doors.

The legislation also provides that the pricing principles which will govern the provision of Telstraâs wholesale services will be determined at a future date by committee consisting of Telstra, the minister and the ACCC.

I suspect from the ACCCâs view that that is a two to one majority against it. Here is a situation in which the government is openly saying that they want to enshrine in legislation that a minister goes and sits in on commercial and regulatory negotiations between the regulatorâthe ACCCâand a company, Telstra. It is of course the case that these commercial negotiations materially affect any communications competitors that Telstra has. The simple, fundamental question that needs to be asked here is: why should the minister be involved in determining prices in the marketplace directly with Telstra, by far the major telco in the marketplace? Why should the minister be sitting on a committee determining prices? Where is there any transparency or independence here? These negotiations between Telstra and the regulator about the competitive regime and the regulatory regime should be free from interference from the minister and should take place directly between the ACCC and Telstra.

The practical effect of this is likely to be that companies that rely on ministerial decisions in many other areas will be afraid to speak out about their view of what is going on. Telecommunications companies will be afraid to criticise the legislation, because their future commercial operations rely on the goodwill of the person who is determining the prices they will be charged and will be able to pass onânamely, the minister. It is wrong in principle to put Telstra, its competitors, the ACCC and the ministers in that position.

We have no objection to the notion of operational separation, but the way in which the government is implementing it is fundamentally flawed. Indeed, the Chairman of the ACCC, Mr Samuel, noted during his evidence to the Senate inquiry that a number of issues required further consideration, including the precise details of the operational separation plan and Telstraâs obligations in relation to that plan, the scope of the services that will be subject to the operational separation plan, the enforcement regime associated with compliance and noncompliance with the operational separation plan, the powers to investigate whether or not compliance has occurred, and the development by the proposed working partyânamely, the working party between Telstra, the ACCC and the departmentâof the internal wholesale pricing and the pricing equivalence regime. So there are some fundamental flaws in those regulatory and competitive arrangements.

If you speak to Telstraâs competitors over the years, you will find that their essential complaint has been that very serious competitive and regulatory issues have been ignored and neglected by the government. There is a very simple explanation for that. The government has always been very slow out of the blocks, not wanting to move on competitive and regulatory issues which might have an adverse impact so far as Telstra is concerned in the marketplace but a beneficial impact so far as competition is concerned, because it wanted to ensure that the Telstra share price would be as high as possible, to enable the government to have an argument to slide through the further or full privatisation.

The problem for the government is that that game has now been comprehensively sprung by Mr Trujillo and the other Telstra executives who gave that formal and frank advice to the government on 11 August. What did the government do? The government tried to do everything it possibly could to make sure that that did not become public or that the community was not aware of that before it slid through the legislation to fully privatise Telstra.

All these issues will come home to roost. In the 2007 election, which you can currently expect to be in the last quarter of 2007, the Australian community will again have a stark contrast between the Liberal-National parties and the Labor Party. The Liberal and National parties, in breach of a faithful election promise, will have passed legislation to fully privatise Telstra, ignoring the needs of rural and regional Australia, ignoring the national interest and pursuing a Liberal Party ideological political interest. In stark contrast to that will be a Labor Party with a firm and proud record of wanting to say: âWe need to ensure that our international competitiveness in communications is right at the top of the list, not at the bottom of the list, and the absolute, essential condition is to ensure parity and adequacy of services in telecommunications to regional, rural and outer metropolitan Australia.â That stark contrast will be there for all to see, and it will be there at great cost to the Liberal Party and the National Party.

talk.start.para: âThe Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 2005 and the Telecommunications Legislation Amendment (Competition and Consumer Issues) Bill 2005 form part of a package of telecommunications legislation which enables the government to proceed with its longstanding policy to fully privatise Telstra. The key features of this legislation include the removal of the current requirement in the Telstra Corporation Act 1991 that requires the Commonwealth to maintain a minimum of 50.1 per cent of shares in Telstra. Incidentally, we currently own 51.8 per cent. They include flexibility for the government to determine the structure of any further sale of Telstra, including the ability to offer hybrid securities or to transfer shares into the Future Fund or the Communications Fund; and confirmation that shares transferred to the Future Fund or the Communications Fund are not to be considered shares owned by the Commonwealth. They include the removal of a number of ministerial direction powers and reporting obligations related to the governmentâs majority shareholding when the Commonwealth shareholding falls below 15 per cent. This does not, however, affect ministerial direction powers relating to specific telecommunications regulation or Telstra licence conditions such as operational separation. A further key feature is the affirmation, by specific inclusion in the act, of the governmentâs commitment to the universal service obligation and the customer service guarantee as basic telecommunications consumer safeguards.

speech.para: The core component of this legislation is the removal of the requirement that the Commonwealth maintains a minimum of 50.1 per cent of the shares of Telstra. Why is this important? The government is currently responsible for the regulation of the telecommunications industry, whilst having a direct financial interest in the operation of the main telecommunications carrier in the industry. Divestment of its remaining shareholding in Telstra will allow the government to concentrate solely on the regulation of Telstra for the benefit of consumers and industry. At the same time, it will allow Telstra to focus on the business of providing telecommunications services without the distraction of the government as a shareholder. The divestment by the government of its remaining shareholding should also dispel any thoughts amongst competitors that Telstra is gaining special benefit by virtue of government ownership.

The current requirement to maintain a 50.1 per cent shareholding in Telstra by the government has a negative effect on the business operations of Telstra. As long as the government is required to maintain a 50.1 per cent shareholding, Telstra cannot raise new equity capital or introduce a dividend investment plan, because that would reduce the Commonwealthâs ownership below this level. This inability to access markets and the consequent need to rely on debt markets adds to the cost of capital and limits the amount of funds that can be returned to shareholders. It is estimated that the ALPâs opposition to the full sale of Telstra has not only cost the taxpayer some $30 billion but reduced the value of the shares and dividend returns of the several million Australians who own shares in Telstra.

In a free market, Telstraâno longer owned by a regulator with a vested interest in its profitabilityâwould be just one among a number of private companies required to compete for customers and meet certain standards. As long as Telstra remains a state owned enterprise, there will always be the temptation for future governments to shift the regulatory balance away from protecting consumers and towards maximising revenue streams from this huge asset. This was covered by the previous speaker.

The OECD communications outlook 2005 stated that countries such as Australia and France that have laws requiring the state to maintain majority ownership of the incumbent operator have now rescinded these laws and have made it clear that they are willing to reduce state ownership to below 50 per cent. (Quorum formed) Australia and France are willing to reduce state ownership below 50 per cent and in certain cases have made commitments to privatise completely. This process needs to be encouraged, to avoid situations which have occurred in previous years, where government ownership of incumbents conflicts at times with best practice regulation and policy making. In only two OECD countries, Luxembourg and Turkey, is the incumbent telecommunications operator still wholly owned by the state.

In other countries where there is state ownership of the incumbent, some progress has been made in reducing the governmentâs share in operations. Government ownership is expected to decline over 2005-06 throughout all OECD nations. The sale of the remaining shareholdings will enable a number of initiatives that were announced in the Connect Australia package, which was presented in August this year. The Connect Australia package involves an investment of $1.1 billion in services; a perpetual $2 billion Communications Fund from the proceeds of the Telstra sale to generate revenue for rural telecommunications services into the future; improved competition regulation, including a requirement for the operational separation of Telstra to deal with ongoing concerns about Telstraâs high degree of integration; and enhanced consumer safeguards which build on the existing universal service obligation and the digital data service obligation.

Service levels are not linked to government ownership of Telstra. The less the government has owned of Telstra the more services have improved. Ten years ago the government owned all of Telstra, and prices were higher, services were slower and the range of products was much smaller. With consumer safeguards in place there is no longer any practicable public interest role in continued government ownership of Telstra. The telecommunications regulatory structure provides wide powers sufficient to allow the government to regulate Telstra without relying on or needing to own Telstra.

This bill affirms these consumer safeguards, namely the universal service obligation and customer service guarantee. The universal service obligation entitles all Australians to access to a standard phone service and payphone regardless of where they live or carry out their business. In general terms a standard phone service means a basic fixed phone line with access to local, national and international calls; 24-hour access to the emergency call service number; operator assisted services; and itemised billing, including itemised local calls on request. If the universal service obligation provider cannot connect or repair a line in the specified time frame, it must offer an interim service such as a mobile or satellite phone until the permanent service is provided or restored.

The customer service guarantee entitles all Australians to timely service for connection and repairs to their standard phone. Currently Telstra is the only universal service obligation provider in Australia. The customer service guarantee applies to Telstra and to all other telecommunications companies. The sale of the remaining shareholdings in Telstra will be in line with other reforms that have been introduced over the years that have been focused on giving all Australians equitable access to telecommunications services and ensuring that Australia as a nation takes full advantage of the benefits that new technology can bring in increased productivity and better delivery of services.

Australiaâs telecommunications sector has developed progressively from a largely centralised, publicly controlled monopoly structure, through a managed competitive model, to an open and competitive market regime with an emphasis on industry self-regulation. From 1901 to 1975, telecommunications was widely regarded as a government service. The Postmaster Generalâs Department was a department with its own minister and directly provided telecommunications and postal services to the public. In 1946, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission was established to provide international telecommunications services, again as a government service.

From 1975 to 1988, the Postmaster Generalâs telecommunications functions were moved to the newly corporatised Telecom Australia. Telecom was established as a statutory authority operating with greater independence from the minister for communications, providing domestic telecommunications services on a monopoly basis. Nevertheless, Telecom retained some governmental functions, notably a large range of explicit regulatory powers regarding technical matters such as technical standards for equipment connected to the network.

In 1981, an additional publicly owned carrier, AUSSAT, was established to operate a domestic satellite system. AUSSAT started commercial operations in 1985. From 1988 to 1991, liberalisation of the sector progressed. As part of the reforms implemented under the Telecommunications Act 1989, value-added services, customer cabling and customer equipment markets were opened to competition, and Telecomâs regulatory powers were vested in a new, independent regulator, AUSTEL. AUSTEL was given the role of facilitating competition in these markets and given several consumer protection roles. Explicit price controls were imposed on Telecom for the first time. The 1989 changes also subjected Telecom to a range of accountability and management reforms designed to provide it with a more commercial focus, no special benefits accruing from government ownership, greater operational freedom, management independence and accountability.

From 1991 to 1997, the market was opened to duopoly competition at the network level, and the services market opened up with the removal of prohibitions on the resale of basic services. A second full service competitor, Optus, and a third mobile network operator, Vodaphone, were licensed. The Telecommunications Act 1991 introduced a carrier-neutral approach towards the communications market. It gave the minister for communications wide-ranging powers to impose obligations on carriers, including a flexible and powerful licensing regime. AUSTELâs role was considerably widened to deal with resourcing issues such as numbering, intercarrier disputes, anticompetitive behaviour, tariff and pricing issues, law enforcement and a wide range of other matters.

The Telstra Corporations Act 1991 merged Telecom and the Overseas Telecommunications Commission into what has become known as Telstra. Telstra became a public company registered under the Corporations Law. Being an independent corporation, Telstraâs board and management were responsible for the day-to-day running of the company. This included Telstraâs strategic direction and decisions of an operational nature, such as employment and investment issues and how the organisation carried on its business.

1997 saw the introduction of reforms which further liberalised telecommunications services, with the opening up of the market for infrastructure as well as services. The Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Act resulted in one-third of Telstra being divested, with the first shares being traded on 17 November 1997. The bulk of the sale proceeds from the partial privatisation were used to retire government debt. Around $1.49 billion was used to fund the Natural Heritage Trust. Around $250 million was applied to the Regional Telecommunications Infrastructure Fund. The gross proceeds from the sale were $14.24 billion and direct costs of the sale were $260.61 million.

During this time, a comprehensive competition framework was put into place to facilitate efficient market entry, and a wide range of consumer and other protections were established. The Australian Communications Authority replaced AUSTEL as the industry regulator, with the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission regulating the new telecommunications specific provisions of the Trade Practices Act.

Before the divestment of 1997, Telstra aimed to connect new phone services in remote Australia within 810 daysâalmost in the same league as countries such as Hungary and the Czech Republic, which had waiting times for a new line of roughly 1,058 days and 2,170 days respectively. Today, however, Australians can get a new phone service within 20 days, wherever they live.

Since these reforms of 1997, the average price of telecommunications services, including both call prices and line rentals, has fallen by some 20 per cent. The reforms were also a huge boost to the economy. It is estimated that the economy is $10 billion larger than it would have been without the reforms. Small business is estimated to have benefited by $2.16 billion, and households by around $924 each.

Since 1997, the regulatory regime has been progressively refined in relation to consumer safeguards, to the point where Australia arguably has the most comprehensive telecommunications consumer protection regime in the world. The governmentâs policy since 1998 has been the full privatisation of Telstra. 1999 saw legislation passed authorising the sale of a further 16.6 per cent of Telstra. The majority of the revenues of this sale were allocated to further debt reduction. Funds were also made available to upgrade services in rural and regional Australia under the social bonus. Gross proceeds of the sale were $16.04 billion, with direct sales costs of $169.23 million.

Today, access to high-quality, affordable telecommunications services is more important than ever if Australia is to keep pace with other industrialised countries. The governmentâs primary role is to establish the Australian telecommunications policy framework, which is primarily directed at maximising the long-term interests of the end users of telecommunications services in Australia. The government will facilitate the development of an efficient and competitive market; underpin this market based strategy with a regulatory safety net which is amongst the tightest in the world; address particular areas of need through targeted funding; and provide leadership to the sector and to governments at the state and local levels. None of these strategies for improving communications services rely on the ownership of Telstra. The coalition government are committed to enabling Australians access to affordable, reliable communications services. The final sale of government shareholding in Telstra will enable us to get on with the job of doing this.

No doubt he will have to live with theâ
(Mr Quick)âI remind the honourable member for Melbourne that if we are going to name people they should be given their appropriate title.

Anybody who is listening can form their own judgment about whether the epithet I have applied to him is appropriate.

speech.para: Today I want to deal with a number of the underlying issues that are relevant to the question of whether or not Telstra should remain in public ownership and relevant to the future of telecommunications in Australiaâwhere it is likely to head under the Howard government and how it is likely to fare following the privatisation of Telstra in the wake of the governmentâs extreme obsession with privatisation, which has prevailed over all other issues in telecommunications in Australia. The first issue I would like to consider is competition, which in my view is at the core of telecommunications issues in Australia and has been sadly neglected by the Howard government. The Keating government introduced competition in telecommunications in 1992, which began with a duopoly with Optus, and the preparations were in place for open competition to be introduced. That was subsequently put in place by the Howard government in 1997 in accordance with the timetable originally specified by the Keating government and in accordance with policies originally adopted by the Hawke government.

Since then, we have seen a sequence of regulatory failures under the Howard government and an inability to come to terms with the fact that Telstra remains overwhelmingly dominant in telecommunications in Australia and that competition has failed to take root in a way that we would have liked. The end results of this have been a grossly inadequate rollout of new technologies like broadband; Telstra making an EBITDA, as the terminology has itâthat is, earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisationâthat has, at times, been over 50 per cent; and Telstra achieving a rate of earnings, a rate of return on its investments, that most Australian companies would kill for.

We have seen a squeeze on ordinary consumers, with massive increases in line rentals for the privilege of having a phone line into their home. In many cases, it has applied to phone lines which have been in place for decades and which cost very little to maintain and keep in place, yet line rental fees have gone up to $30 a month. That is not only a very big imposition on the ordinary consumer; it also squeezes competition. Because the line rental is effectively a uniform part of the total package that a provider supplies to a consumer, it narrows down the scope for differentiation of product and price that is available to would-be competitors of Telstra.

If we want to see how Telstraâs dominance and the inadequate regulatory structure with respect to competition in telecommunications diminish outcomes and results for consumers in Australia, all we need to do is to compare broadband with 3G telephony, or third-generation mobile phone telephonyâvideo and photography over mobile phones. Because there is no immediate and direct significance to the Telstra fixed-line network on the 3G side of the spectrum, Australia has been very much leading the world in 3G. We were one of the early adopters and are one of the countries that have made very major progress with that technology. This is in contrast to broadband, where Telstra is ubiquitous, where what it does with its network is fundamental to the rate of progress with broadband and where we have the unhappy situation of Australia now being 21st on the OECD list of developed countries in terms of broadband access. We have been falling steadily over the past few years, because a few years ago we were 13th on the list.

The governmentâs approach to regulating competition has been spectacularly unsuccessful. We have seen occasional attempts over the past few years to strengthen the competition regime. For example, under former Minister Senator Alston, we saw the introduction of accounting separation at the end of 2002, which was designed to increase the rigour with which the regulatory arrangements ensure that access to Telstraâs network by competitors occurs on a genuine level playing field basis, with proper pricing that reflects the true cost of that access. That accounting separation regime has been a manifest failure, and the government has implicitly acknowledged that by putting forward yet another regulatory system. The reason it has been a failure is that Telstra is still able to game the system; it is still able to use the regulatory regime as a means of exhausting its opponents with very lengthy and difficult disputes that inevitably involve large expenditures of money on lawyers.

At the last election, with me as the shadow communications minister, Labor advanced as its key regulatory reform a policy of the virtual separation of Telstra. The idea behind this is that Telstra should be effectively split internally between its wholesale or network activities and its retail activities in order to ensure that the regulator can, at a glance, see whether Telstra is giving itself the same terms, conditions and prices for use of its network to deliver telephony and other telecommunications services that it is providing to its competitors. This kind of approach has been in place for a number of years in the United Kingdom, and it has been in place for a number of years in Sweden. Although there are obviously differences of detail and there are further reforms in the pipeline in Britain, it clearly is a much more effective way of ensuring that the publicly owned network and publicly created network can be used on a level playing field basisâon an even, open basisâby competitors.

There are some commentators who suggest that Telstra is already being forced to provide to its competitors access to its network at below costâat below the true price and at below the true price it offers itself. There is no evidence of this. In fact, the simple question that should be asked of these commentators is: if that were the case, why havenât Optus, Primus, AAPT and all the other competitors effectively taken over dominance of telephone services in Australia? If Telstra were effectively being forced to provide them with access to its network at prices below the price it would effectively have to pay itself, one would assume that over time that would mean that those competitors would effectively put Telstra out of business or, at the very least, make massive inroads into its market share, which has not occurred.

Although the government has adopted Laborâs policy from the last election with respect to the operational separation of Telstra, it has failed to follow through. That is hardly a surprise, because it reflects precisely what has occurred previously. It has sidelined the ACCC. It has asked Telstra to write the rules. It has decided to split Telstra into three sections, not two, and effectively created a differential arrangement between how Telstra deals with itself on the one hand and how it deals with competitors on the other. Rather than having a network division and a wholesale division as a single entity, it has decided to separate them, so there will be a different process and a different pattern of dealing for competitors. Most significantly of all, the government has decided to have the minister of the day, the minister for communications, directly involved in regulatory decision making, in particular with the requirement for the minister to issue a rectification notice where Telstra is in breach of its obligations under operational separation.

This is an extraordinary development because the government has, over time, gradually pushed one claim to the fore in its arguments for privatising Telstra, and that is the alleged conflict of interest involved in the government being both an owner and a regulator of Telstra. I will get to that issue in some detail in a few minutes. The government says that it is a terrible situation for it to be both the owner of this entity and its broader regulator. On the governmentâs own admission, Telstra could remain in public ownership for at least another year or two or possibly longer, and there could be a substantial minority public shareholding in it for an even lengthier period. In those circumstances I find it extraordinary that the government is adopting a model that involves a direct role for the minister in regulating Telstra. Up till now that role has essentially been performed by the ACCC, so there has been an armâs length regulatory arrangement. So, in spite of all of the governmentâs rhetoric about there being a conflict of interest, it is putting the minister directly into the regulatory loop.

I turn now to the state of Telstraâs network, one of the key issues in this debate. It is revealed in the infamous Telstra document of 11 August that 14 per cent of Telstraâs lines around Australia are faulty. The government has responded by saying, âAha. But the Australian Communications and Media Authority data on the number of faults reported for the month of July was that only one per cent were faultyâ99 per cent of lines were reported to be fault free.â We have seen this trick before. When I was shadow minister I exposed the fact that the ACA, as it then was, was effectively aggregating the monthly statistics and averaging them. It was saying that on an annual basis the lines were 98 or 99 per cent fault free, because the average in a given month for the totality of telephone lines in Australia was that 99 or 98 per cent were fault free. But that is a totally misleading statistic when you average it out, because it is not the same phone line that is incurring a fault every month; it is different phone lines. So the 14 per cent is a much more realistic figure, one that gives you a true picture and demonstrates that a very substantial proportion of phone lines in Australia have faults.

Having been all around Australia, having talked to people who work in Telstra and to the many people who use telecommunications and having seen with my own eyes the dilapidated and deteriorating state of Telstraâs network, I know that it makes sense that there is a very high level of faults, because Telstra has been substantially diminishing its investment in its network. In the late 1990s its total capital expenditure was about $4.5 billion. In the last couple of years, that has dropped below $3 billion. And guess where that is coming from? It is coming from investment in the network. So it is no surprise that Telstra reported to the government that there was a $3 billion gap in terms of routine mainstream investment in its network as a result of those decisionsâall of them coming from the governmentâs obsession with privatising Telstra.

The thing that is different about the three amigos and Mr Trujillo is that they are looking beyond privatisation; they are looking at how they are going to run the company and make a decent return. The previous management, understandably, shared the governmentâs obsession with privatisation and subordinated everything they did to the privatisation goal, which meant underinvesting in the network, pumping up the dividend stream unsustainably in order to pump up the share price, and a variety of other things. It is clear that telecommunications services around Australia are not up to scratch, particularly in regional Australia but also in many parts of metropolitan Australia. It is abundantly clear that the government misled the Australian people in the last election campaign by claiming that telecommunications services were up to scratch. It is equally clear that very little is going to be done to fix the problem.

The government have relied over the years on a range of smoke-and-mirrors initiatives, window-dressing initiatives that are designed to make it look like the government are doing something. But those initiatives have not achieved very much. The government have primarily focused on pork-barrelling in appropriate marginal coalition seats in regional Australia. The Networking the Nation fund saw about half a billion dollarsâa very substantial amount of moneyâdribbled out around the country. The Auditor-General, when he examined the fund, reached the conclusion that it was impossible to determine whether the fund had benefited the nation, because there were no benchmarks, no targets, no performance standards. There was no way of telling whether the fund had produced any serious benefit for Australia.

We have more recently seen the HiBIS scheme, the broadband subsidy scheme, which has been dribbled out in the same way. During the election campaign, the government announced specific broadband micro-initiatives for particular small towns that just happen to be at the heart of vulnerable marginal electorates. So rather than building Australiaâs telecommunications infrastructure for the 21st century, rather than ensuring that we have an up-to-date network with decent speeds, accessible to all Australians, the government has been using large sums of taxpayersâ money to window-dress, to create an impression of things happening at the same time as it is pursuing its obsession with privatising Telstra, to the great disadvantage of Australian telecommunications consumers.

On the broadband front, as I said, we are now 21st in the world and slipping, and Australian speeds are very ordinary compared with those of many of our competitors and other nations. We are flattered, if anything, by the OECD statistics because their indicator level is 256 kilobits per second, which is a pretty ordinary broadband speed. Many people would argue that it does not even constitute true broadband. Our take-up rate is only a half to a third of the take-up rate of equivalent nations like the United States and Canada.

Broadband is fundamental to the future of this country. Getting access to decent broadband in the future is going to be as important as getting access to electricity was during the 20th century. It is going to be essential to virtually all kinds of economic activities. A couple of years ago I visited an industrial estate in the electorate of Cowan and discovered that there was a sausage factory there, of all things, that was having a significant problem because it could not get access to broadband. That was having a major impact on its competitive position, because it had to deal with suppliers and customers by fax rather than over the internet. Even for something as apparently mundane and old economy as making sausages, the question of availability of broadband was fundamentally important.

The issue that our nation should be dealing withâthe question that we should be addressingâis not who owns Telstra; it is what Telstra is going to do and what our nation is going to do to ensure that we are at the forefront of the developed world in rolling out high-speed, high-quality telecommunications infrastructure and services that will be the backbone of our economic future. That is the issue that the government has totally neglected. That is the issue that has been the basis for the governmentâs window dressing, its pretending to do something, its trying to look like it is doing something, and its pouring dribs and drabs of money all around the country in various marginal seats for its own political benefits without achieving anything substantial for the nation.

I want to touch briefly on the future of Telstra as a private company. It has been run de facto as a private company for many years, because the government has chosen not to make use of its ownership for broader community purposes, generally speaking. As a result, the government was quite happy for Telstra to seek to launch a takeover bid for the Channel 9 network. Similarly, the government ticked off on Telstraâs attempt to take over the Fairfax newspaper group.

It is pretty clear that once Telstra is privatised, particularly if the government is successful in getting the abolition of cross-media ownership rules through the parliament, it is so big, so profitable, and has such an enormous cash flow that its ability to gobble up half or more of the existing Australian media will create a situation where we could have a massive concentrationâa narrowing downâof power and control in our media. It is eminently possible that a privately owned Telstra will, in rapid order, acquire one of the free-to-air TV networks and possibly the Fairfax newspaper group or parts of it. At the same time it will be establishing internet TV networks. It is already well and truly running down that path; it is 50 per cent owner of the monopoly pay-TV network Foxtel. The implications of this for Australia, for democratic debate and for diversity of public opinion are enormous. That is one of the key reasons why I think Telstra should remain in public ownership. It should be forced to focus on its primary responsibilities and activitiesâtelecommunications ânot media.

I want to make an observation on the matter of conflict of interest that the government places so much emphasis on. The claim is that the government cannot own Telstra because it also regulates telecommunications. Other than the peculiarities of the regulatory regime that has been introduced as part of this set of legislation, which I referred to previously, it is worth pointing out that that regulatory arrangement does occur at armâs length through the ACCC, as it should.

It is also worth pointing out that there are other organisations that the government owns and regulates, which it regulates in a sector where there is competition. The most obvious example, which I completely clean bowled the Prime Minister with in question time last week, is Australia Post. The government is adamant that it has no intention of privatising Australia Post. Eighty-five per cent of Australia Post revenue comes from fully contestable and competitive activities, yet it is owned and regulated by the government, which regulates postal services generally. The situation is precisely the same as that of Telstra. The government both owns the institutionâin this case it has 100 per cent ownershipâand regulates the market. Australia Post competes on a whole host of activities with a lot of private companies. The government does not appear to think that that is a problem, but it is the key reason why Telstra needs to be privatised.

You can make the same observation with broadcasting. The ABC and the SBS compete, in effect, with commercial broadcasters, particularly the SBS, which is competing with commercial broadcasters for advertising revenue. But they are both competing with commercial broadcasters for eyeballs, and the government regulates broadcasting. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise today to speak on the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 2005 and the Telecommunications Legislation Amendment (Competition and Consumer Issues) Bill 2005. Passing the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 2005 will allow our government to sell down its shareholding below 51 per cent, but it will also maintain the flexibility to put Telstra to the market in the best position for the people of Australia. This is not a rushed sell down; this is about the government divesting itself of a corporation that governments should not be in the business of running. As the member for Melbourne quite rightly said, the issue is not that of who owns Telstra; the issue is where we go from here and what will be done with Telstra and communications.

speech.para: The Telecommunications Legislation Amendment (Competition and Consumer Issues) Bill 2005 will legislate to impose on Telstra, through its licence conditions, a requirement for operational separation. It will give the minister the power to determine matters covered by the operational separation plan and the services it covers, require the ACCC to take account of the costs and risks of new network investment when making a decision under the telecommunications access regime, amend the Trade Practices Act to speed up and streamline ACCC decision-making processes and allow the powers of ACMA to be enhanced to accept court enforceable undertakings to ensure compliance by industry participants and to enforce compliance with industry codes. And there will be other changes that will be driven by the minister.

There are also non-legislative parts of this communications package. They include price control determinations. The government has announced that from 1 January 2006 new price control arrangements will come into effect. These arrangements will be implemented by way of ministerial determination. The new arrangements will be brought into effect by ministerial determination prior to January 2006.

The one that really has an effect on my local area is that the government will introduce a local presence plan. This will be imposed on Telstra through licence conditions that will require Telstra to put in place the local presence plan. Telstra has to conduct public consultation on its proposed plan, and the plan must be provided for ministerial approval in December 2005. Once the plans are approved, they must be continually updated and approved every three years.

In this House, over the nine-odd years that we have been in government, there has been a lot of debate. It was this government that introduced the customer service guarantee. There have been many aspects of this, ensuring that we maintain certain levels of communications service and affordability in the area of telecommunications. Backing that up is the universal service guarantee. I have spoken many times on that and I do not wish to go back to it at this point in time.

Earlier this week in the House, we debated three bills that were largely appropriation bills. (Quorum formed) The young boys and girls from school who are up there in the gallery are probably wondering what has happened. I need them to know that the Labor Party tend to shut people down when they are making constructive points on bills under debate. It is their way of denying freedom of speech.

(Mr Quick)âOrder! The member for Corio!

âThank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Today we are discussing and debating the privatisation of Telstra. But earlier this week there were three bills which I would like to reflect on. Those bills in particular provided for $3 billion, just about 10 per cent of the residual value of Telstra shareholdings by the Australian government, to be invested in future proofing our communications. There was $2 billion for the Communications Fund, which will be administered by an independent board with representatives from rural and regional areas such as mineâ$2 billion that will be invested into the communications network. And, importantly, there is $1.1 billion, of which $878 million will be invested in Broadband Connect, providing all Australians with affordable broadband network services.

speech.para: There will be $113 million for Clever Networks, to improve the delivery of health, education and other essential services over the broadband networks. I have a large electorate of nearly 10,000 square kilometres, and I have a lot of satellite hospitals through Hunter New England Health. They will benefit by being able to go online to access health information. I am also impressed by the $30 million for Mobile Connect, to extend terrestrial mobile coverage where it can be commercially maintained and to provide continued handset subsidies for satellite communication. Quite often we hear members of the opposition talk about there being no mobile communications in some areas. There is, and has been for quite some considerable time now, the ability to have satellite mobile phone technology. A lot of my constituents are in remote and distant areas where topography prohibits the use of handheld CDMA or digital phones because of the valleys and mountains in the region.

I would like to reflect on the services prior to this government coming into power. The Labor Party did a deal to increase competition. I welcome that. However, as part of that deal, it agreed to shut down the analog phone network. It shows how city-centric the Labor Party was with its plans when it intended to shut down the analog mobile phone network: the digital or GSM phone network operates predominantly in city areas.

Rural and regional areas, like my electorate of Paterson, relied on the analog phone system. There were only a few areas where it worked because the Labor Party had refused to instruct Telstra to install analog transmitters throughout the country in rural and regional areas. We were left with a situation where the Labor Party had introduced a time line for the shutdown of the analog phone system but without a plan. They had no plan to have telephone services in regional and rural Australia, yet they complain.

It was interesting to note earlier in this week in the debate on the three bills that provide $3.1 billion for investing into our telephone networks that all of the members of the Labor Party, all the Labor members in the Hunter region, voted against $3.1 billion worth of investment. I thought they would be smart politicians. I thought they would vote for the $3.1 billion to be invested, particularly in regional and rural areas where they come from, but they opposed it. I intend to make sure that the public in our area understand that they opposed those bills and did not want the investment in their area.

As we grow and we use technology I am glad to report to this House that, over the last nine years and the sell-off of the first half of Telstra, my communities have benefited. In the number of speeches that I have made in this House I have repeatedly talked about the advancements achieved through the community technology centres and the HiBIS system, the Higher Bandwidth Incentive Scheme, and of the money that has been invested to repair TV blackspots so that people in my area can have access to what most people in the city consider to be normalâaccess to TV channels like 9, 7, 10, 2 and SBS. That has been a great investment. There is still work to be done. We have introduced demand aggregation brokers that have brought people together to build up the demand so that we can put a case forward for increased broadband supplement.

There have been investments in commercial radio blackspots and in the highway mobile phone coverage. I have going through my electorate a part of the New England Highway but I have a large slab of the Pacific Highway and we have improved mobile phone communications on that highway. There has been an extensive roll out in investment in providing mobile telephone communications to towns of under 500 people. In fact, in my electorate now there are over 32 mobile phone transmitters. When I came into office in 1996 there were some five analog transmitters in my electorate.

There are now 26 exchanges in my electorate enabled for broadband roll out. I remember that when I came to parliament in 1996 dial-up internet services were not even considered. The internet was a new thing. Now we have moved to broadbandâand it will never be enough; already we are seeing new technologies emerge. I am glad that we are putting away $3.1 billion to help invest. But it is also important to note that that $3.1 billion will not just be there for the benefit of Telstra; it will be for the benefit of all those other players that have come into the market that do support the increased competition and the privatisation of Telstra because it will give them an opportunity to start competing on an equal footing.

The other thing that the Labor Party omits to advise the House is that, since this government came in and implemented universal service guarantees, we now have untimed local calls in large places throughout Australia. In fact, all call costs have been reduced dramatically. The prices of overseas calls, interstate calls and STD calls through increased competition have reduced dramatically.

As I said, my colleague but opponent the member for Hunter in this chamber criticised me for not speaking on the legislation on Monday. But I am speaking here today and I am putting forward the views of the people in my electorate of Paterson. They demand services; they do not demand ownership. What we will see is an increased roll out, because it is the local member who pushes and strives for such things in his electorate.

The member for Hunter is the Shane Warne of politics. I do not say that because of his ability to put a spin on things. I say that because of the similarities, as we have witnessed in the chamber, with his ability to use the old SMS. I am sure there would be some interesting readings on that and that the similarities between him and Mr Warne would be extraordinary.

It is good to see people using technology for their own advantage. I would like to see an increased roll out. I am looking forward to the increased roll out of XDA, the CDMA high-speed mobile phone broadband network. I am looking forward to seeing the black spots being fixed up in my area. But I know, and my constituents know, that when it comes to mobile telephony there can never be 100 per cent coverage with a CDMA or GSM network. We have a satellite system for those who, through topography or for reasons of distance away from main towns, will not have the ability to use the standard phone systems. It is important and great to see that this government will continue to subsidise call costs and handsets to make them affordable for people. Of course, the more people who take up satellite mobile communications, the cheaper the operation will be because the atomisation of costs will be over a broader area.

I wholeheartedly support this legislation. I will be telling my constituents that I support this legislation. I support the three bills that went through earlier this week guaranteeing $3.1 billion. But I will also be supporting and driving my government to make sure that we, either through legislation or providing incentives, continue to get increased competition and development for the provision of telephone services, whether it be mobile, landline or broadband, into areas such as mine. I support this legislation and commend it to the House.

talk.start.para: âThank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker. (Quorum formed) At 12.30 pm today, the bells of this House will toll on one of the great Judas acts in Australian politics. Yesterday in the Senate, the Judas Iscariot of Australian politicsâBarnaby the betrayer, as he is now knownâsealed the fate of Telstra when he picked up the 30 pieces of silver and slunk out into the Canberra night.
âMr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. A standing order says members will be referred to by their title. I hardly think âBarnaby the betrayerâ is the title of the senator from Queensland.
âThe member for Corio might choose to use the senatorâs title.

âThank you, Mr Speaker. With Senator Joyceâs reputation went the reputation of his fellow National Party senators, National Party members in this parliament and, indeed, the reputation of the once great National Party. Let me read out to this House the rollcall of the National Party members who have given effect to the sale of Telstra in this place. Hitherto they will be known in rural Australia as the dirty dozen: the member for Gwydir, the member for Page, the member for Parkes, the member for Mallee, the member for Cowper, the member for Riverina, the member for Dawson, the member for Gippsland, the member for Hinkler, the member for Maranoa, the member for Wide Bay and the member for Lyne. These people comprehensively betrayed rural and regional Australia with this decision.

speech.para: Let me remind the National Farmers Federation, which caved in to pressure from the government, of the extent of the betrayal that we are witnessing on the floor of this House today. The New South Wales Farmers Federation conducted a survey of farmers in June 2005 and this is what that survey said: 80 per cent of the farmers surveyed opposed the sale. They were asked, âIs your landline reliable?â Noâ29 per cent. âIs your mobile phone reliable?â Noâ63 per cent. âAre you satisfied with your internet speed?â Noâ60 per cent. Here today we have a betrayal of their interests.

We know that Senator Joyce in that other place is known now as âMr 65 per centâ, because he said, âWell, Iâm only 65 per cent happy with the decision.â You cannot be a little bit pregnant in this place. You cannot be 65 per cent sort of happy with it. Let me tell you, Senator Joyce and members of the National Party: you might be 65 per cent happy with the decision that you have madeâbut, out in rural Australia, farmers are 100 per cent disillusioned and unhappy with the decision that you have made.

This is one of the most comprehensive betrayals that we have witnessed on the floor of this parliament. Telstra itself has said in this document that the faults in Telstra are enormous. The services that are being provided to farmers and their families are below par and not up to scratch. What sort of dream time are you living in if you believe that, when this document says you need $5.7 billion to bring Telstra up to scratch and you allocate $3 billion, these problems that have been identified by Telstra management will be overcome? The simple fact of the matter is this: on the sale of Telstra, the spivs, the merchant bankers and the brokers will pick up some $850 million to $1 billion, and the government will invest only $2 billion, with a return each year of $100 million, to address some of the major faults that have been identified by Telstra. Telstra itself has indicated that there has been a massive underinvestment in this telco.
