talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services
talker.name: Mr TRUSS

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the first part of the question is that certainly a large quantity of ammonium nitrate is shipped into Australia. We have significant demands for this product with our burgeoning mining industry, and of course ammonium nitrate is also important in agriculture. So significant quantities of ammonium nitrate come to Australia. About 99 per cent of our trade is involved with foreign ships, so it is quite likely that a significant proportion of it comes in on foreign ships.
âFlag of convenience ships.
âBut it is not true to say that these ships come in without any checking. The reality is that we have a substantial, comprehensive risk assessment process in place.
âAsk the shipâs master.
âThe member for Brisbane has asked his question.

âEach ship is subject to security checking irrespective of its flag. In addition to that, the members of the crew are checked against any alert lists to make sure that they do not pose a risk to Australia. If they choose to enter Australia, they must go through the same kinds of immigration checks as anyone else coming into this country.

answer.para: The Leader of the Opposition was in Gladstone a few weeks ago on that accident-prone trip and tried to make something of the fact that ammonium nitrate was being moved between Australian ports on ships that had a single-voyage permit. The reality is that the alternative to moving ammonium nitrate around Australia by ship is to move it by truck. Instead of this ammonium nitrate going from Sydney to Gladstone by ship, it could have gone by truck. It would have taken 500 semitrailers to make that journey. And which do you think is saferâ500 semitrailers going up the road or one ship?

The reality is that we have a safety regime in place. It is much safer to transport ammonium nitrate by ship than by road. I think the Australian public would want us to continue that kind of transport regime.

âMy question is addressed to the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations. Would the minister update the House on the governmentâs measures to reform the building and construction industry? How will the industry and home buyers benefit from these reforms?

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service
talker.name: Mr ANDREWS

talk.start.para: âI thank the member for Hasluck for his question. I can inform him that today I was delighted to announce the appointment of the Hon. John Lloyd as the first Australian Building and Construction Commissioner. Mr Lloyd brings a long background of involvement in industrial relations at the state level as well as the Commonwealth level, most recently as a senior deputy president of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, to this role.

answer.para: What the establishment of the ABCC involves is the culmination of a four-year process commencing with the royal commission under Mr Justice Cole, which established a clear and undeniable case for a comprehensive clean-up of the building and construction industry. The Econtech report of a few years ago showed that the benefit of cleaning up the unlawful practices in the commercial building and construction industry could be worth up to $2.3 billion to the Australian economy, yet the ALP has opposed every single measure that the government has put forward in an endeavour to do this.

We have had some more examples today in the media. Yesterday the Western Australian Assistant Secretary of the CFMEU, Joe Macdonald, was convicted of assaulting two managers of a Perth building site after he attempted to gain unauthorised entryâanother example of this sort of behaviour.

Then we have seen another report where the full bench of the Federal Court ruled that the Victorian government, having resisted providing documents to the Building Industry Task Force for some 2Â½ yearsâat a cost of some tens if not hundreds of thousands of dollars to Victorian taxpayersâmust hand over documents in relation to an investigation into allegations that it manipulated a government tender process to award contracts to a company that was favoured by the CFMEU. This is serious. This is an allegation of a deliberate manipulation of a government contract so that it did not go to a company that employed non-unionists in relation to this tender.

The point of this is that, if a state government can succumb to union pressure, what hope have the little subcontractors out on the building sites around Australia? What this shows once again is that this side of the chamber, this side of politics in Australia, is about law abiding and productive building and construction sites in Australia and that the Labor Party, in fighting this tooth and nail, year after year, stands for the protection of the rackets and the rorts that go on in the building and construction sector. âMy question is addressed to the Minister for Education, Science and Training. Is the minister aware of concerns about English standards for Australian school leavers? What is the government doing to improve standards in our schools? Are there any alternative policies?

talk.start.para: âI thank the member for La Trobe for his question and for proudly being a member of a government committed to high national standards in schooling. I awoke this morning to a headline in the Australian newspaper entitled âStudents unable to write a sentenceâ. In fact, the ADFA Associate Dean of Education, Stephen Yeomans, is reported as saying:

quote.para: What I particularly notice is improper sentence construction, inappropriate or no punctuation, lack of conjunctives, misuse of apostrophes, poor spelling and so on.

answer.para: The average Australian would probably think that Australiaâs minister for education would be shocked to read such a headline and to read such a study. The only thing that is shocking about it is that I am not shocked; in fact, I am not even surprised. In this particular studyâwe are talking about students who achieved a tertiary entrance rank of 80 or moreâonly one in six of those students could achieve 70 per cent accuracy in basic grammar. Just to put that into some context, there are students who have been accepted into Australian universities this yearâ

âThe member for Lingiari is warned!

âto train as teachers, with tertiary entrance scores in the low 50s. In the Saturday Age, the front-page story was âVCE English âdumbed downâ: one book a year could be enough under âEnglish liteâââstudents would have to read only one single book in year 12.

answer.para: I would also point out to the Houseâand I am happy to table theseâthat I have three examples of minimum passing results by students in the year 12 Higher School Certificate in New South Wales. The second is that the member for Cowper, very ably supported by the member for Port Adelaide, is conducting an inquiry into the training of teachers in Australian universitiesâand there will be major reform. The third is that the government is driving an Australian certificate of education. We are determined through the Australian Council of Education to drive a nationally-consistent high-quality year 12 qualification.

I also inform the House that I will be commissioning some independent work to assess the academic rigour of English, chemistry, physics and mathematics at the year 12 level throughout Australia and I will be making it available to communities so that they can compare the standards in one state with another. talk.start.para: âBoth the Prime Minister and I are right. I say to the member for Sydney that, as I said the other day, the government believe there are considerable benefits in people being able to work where they are capable of working. We believe that far too many people have been locked out of the economic life of this country. For example, something like 700,000 children in Australia are growing up in jobless households. That is unacceptable, and that is why the government are putting in place some changes in the Welfare to Work measures.

answer.para: In the past the welfare system has been based on the proposition that either people could work full time or they could not work at all. Today there are many people in Australia who work part time and we believe that, if a person is capable of part-time employment, then there should be some obligation to do that. If they do that and work for 15 hours as required at the normal award classification wages for adults, that effectively means that a sole parent on the minimum wage for 15 hours a week will have $484.24 a week to take home. This compares to a sole parent pension recipient who does not work who receives $58 a week less. This is effectively about saying that we are going to give those people an opportunity to be in the economic life of this country and that we are going to do something about stopping the intergenerational poverty which is caused by allowing the current situation to go on. If the honourable member and her colleagues on the other side of the table were interested in helping out people in that situation, they would get behind these measures.

âYesterday the Chief Opposition Whip asked me a question about dress standards for the chamber galleries. speech.para: The rule against protest action in the galleries is longstanding and serves to maintain the dignity of the House and its proceedings. The rule is a statement of principle, for, as the honourable member would appreciateâand I think all members would appreciateâit would be impossible to have a list of every item of clothing and example of behaviour which would be inappropriate in the galleries. As all honourable members would know, the presumption is that persons attending in the galleries of the chamber do so to observe the proceedings of the House. It is not appropriate for any persons in the galleries to engage in behaviour which would be likely to draw attention to themselves or to disturb other observers in the galleries.

In the particular case raised by the Chief Opposition Whip, I understand that it was the intention of a group of firefighters visiting the galleries to wear their specialist protective clothing with large reflective panels on the chest and leg areas. I appreciate that all members of the group complied with the request to remove the outer specialist clothing before they entered the gallery. talk.start.para: âTrust in our parliamentary institutions is something that we all should value. There have been a number of occurrences in recent years which have meant people are starting to distrust their parliamentary institutions, and I think it is paramount that we all recognise that and try to do something about it. Whether it be in relation to issues like âchildren overboardâ, the Iraq war, the drought and the misrepresentations that occurred there, the free trade agreement, Telstra or climate change, the information that is transferred within this chamber and the other chamber is, from time to time, found later on not to be correct. That leads to a situation where the general populace do not trust the institution and do not trust the political process. Irrespective of who is in government, who is in opposition and who did what in the past, I think that is starting to erode the facilities of government itself. So I ask that we as members of parliament take this issue seriously and try and do something about it.

speech.para: Just in recent weeks, and even today, the trust in the parliament was abused. The Deputy Prime Minister, for instance, said today: âThere has been, in terms of the Telstra sale, a $3.1 billion investment in telecommunications infrastructure.â That is not correct. What has happened is that there has been a $1.1 billion investment in broadband and mobile services and a fund of $2 billion set aside, from which the interest will be used to invest in telecommunications infrastructure. That is not $3.1 billion. That is misleading the public. When they find out the truth, the publicâs view will be that that they have been misled by the parliament.

There have been a number of issues in relation to Telstra, such as the term âup to scratchâ. A lot of people who vote assumed that in this case the National Party would abide by the terms on which it went to the last electionâthat it would not sell Telstra until it was âup to scratchâ, until all the recommendations of the Estens report were in place. That has not happened, and the National Party has voted for the full sale, the full privatisation, of Telstra. People are wondering why and how they can trust their parliamentarians when that sort of activity is occurring.

Another phrase, âdown the trackâ, came into the parliament in the last week, used by Senator Minchin. Things will be right âdown the trackâ. They are not up to scratch nowâwe have been shown by the new CEO and others that there has been a massive underinvestment et ceteraâbut apparently, out of this package of $3.1 billion, which is really only $1.1 billion and the interest from $2 billion, things will be right âdown the trackâ. When you look at that, though, you find that the interest from that $2 billion fund is $100 millionâand those are the words of Mark Vaile, the Deputy Prime Minister, not mine. One hundred million dollars is less than the $125 million that the government has been providing annually over the last eight yearsâa $25 million reduction in expenditure on telecommunications infrastructure. And here we had again today a lack of openness when the Deputy Prime Minister, the Acting Prime Minister, said $3.1 billion is being invested.

We have had the absurdity with the National Farmers Federation in the last few days. The farming community right across Australia, in all the surveys that have been done, have indicated that the service is not up to scratch, that they are opposed to the sale, that the Estens recommendations have not been fully implemented, that Sol Trujillo has said that there has been massive underinvestment and that particularly the underground infrastructure is in a messâdefinitely not up to scratch. We saw the absurdity the other day of the President of the National Farmers Federation, Peter Corish, coming into this place and suddenly reversing the decision, and the outrage that has been expressed by the farming community about that.

I questioned the President of the National Farmers Federation as to why that had happened. In a press release, the National Farmers Federation said that they had received a guarantee from the government that there would be pricing parity with telephone services and broadband. When questioned in the parliament yesterday, the Acting Prime Minister could not find where in the legislation that guarantee was delivered. In the Senate yesterday afternoon, Senator Conroy questioned the minister responsible, the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, and she categorically said that there was no guarantee in terms of broadband services. That is in the Hansard. These are the sorts of things about which the community is being misled. There is no guarantee in the legislation; it was mentioned in a speech by the minister.

I remember, when the goods and services tax was introduced, the National Party once again standing up and suggesting that, based on the price, there would be a degree of inequity in the application of the goods and services tax between city people and country people.

talk.start.para: âAnd there is.

âThere is, as the member for Hunter said. The government put in place the Fuel Sales Grants Scheme to compensate for the inequity. Where is it now? It has gone, but the inequity has not gone. The application of the goods and services tax has not gone, but the Fuel Sales Grants Scheme has gone. The same brand of the same parliament that instituted it, for good reasons, has decided, âThatâs long enough; it can go,â and that is exactly what will happen with Telstra: âThatâs long enough; it can go.â It will drift away.

speech.para: I questioned the President of the National Farmers Federation as to why there was a reversal. Some of the state organisations were very angry about that decision. I made certain comments to the press that the President of the National Farmers Federationâit was no secretâwas contemplating a political career and considering seats in the north of New South Wales and southern Queensland. He has not denied that. However, a strange person has come out of left field; the member for Gwydir has entered this debate. The member for Gwydir, in an article by Michael Thomson, was reported as saying:

quote.para: There is no deal for Peter Corish. There can be no deal. No-one is in a position to offer such a deal. The most powerful man in the National Party could not have arranged such a thingâ

speech.para: for him.

quote.para: Even if he were to run, heâs got to win preselection. It will be a very strong field, indeed. Five or six people have indicated they want to run; itâll will be a battle royal.

speech.para: I did not mention the National Party to Michael Thomson when I talked about Peter Corish. I did not mention the seat of Gwydir. All I said was that it was no secret that this man was contemplating a political career in southern Queensland or northern New South Wales. That career may well be as an Independent in New England.

The former Deputy Prime Minister and Leader of the National Party seems to know quite a bit more about this man that he has defended. When it comes to openness and frankness, they are the sorts of things that the community has a right to know. To add insult to injury, the President of the National Farmers Federation, Peter Corish, appeared in a radio program yesterday afternoon on 2AY in Albury, and I happened to be on the same program talking about Telstra. This was after Senator Joyce had made his decision, not by way of voting but by publicly announcing it. About an hour after that, Mr Corish said that the National Farmers Federation did not support the full sale of Telstra. I thought, âThatâs a bit absurd; that is not what he was saying the other day.â He then went on to say that the NFF did support the bills before the House. I have had involvement with the National Farmers Federation over many years. I was one of those who organised busloads of people to come down to Canberra to rally against former Prime Minister Hawke.

talk.start.para: âHow could you?

âIt was easy, and a lot of people came to rally against the indecencies of government in those days and to rally for honesty in government. To see the National Farmers Federation dragged to this all-time low and then purport to represent the farming community of Australia is quite disturbing. I have had phone call after phone call from people who are involved in the associated organisations. I was on the general council of the New South Wales Farmers Association, and I was on the Grains Council of Australia. They have become puppets of government as well in respect of their attitude to ethanol. Some of these representative bodies have to make up their minds if they are to have any credibility in parliament, irrespective of who is in government. They have to start to represent the issues that their constituents believe in, and that is a broad reflection on the political process.

speech.para: We saw the farce in relation to free trade. The President of the National Farmers Association was involved in that well. There were concrete guarantees, when they left here, that sugar would be in, that there would be very strict rules in relation to open access to trade and that the beef industry would be entitled. A few words from Mark Vaile in the United States and that all fell apart.

There is a whole range of issues on which we need more openness. We saw the development of national competition policy, and how that was underwritten, over the years. The two major parts of national competition policy on water reform were about a market being developed, which has partially been done, and property rights being recognised. It is 10 years on and they still have not been recognised. We have had all this palaver about how great it is with the bilaterals, the intergovernmental agreements et cetera. The people have been misled. Those people who have been sitting out there waiting for their property rights to be recognised when an environmental change occurs have been misled once again.

There was Regional Partnershipsâno wonder people are cynical about the political process. I hope the committee that is currently looking at that program makes recommendations to the Auditor-General, because I think there is a number of instances there where it is far greater than the traditional pork-barrelling that we would all accept to a certain degreeâwe might not agree with it on the day but it is part of the political process. But it seems to me that there may well be some corrupt activity in relation to where some of these funds have ended up and whether they have even been found. That might need a further inquiry.

I have talked about the Fuel Sales Grants Scheme, ethanol, Iraq and other issues. In terms of the Telstra debate and political representation, I will be working to get people into this parliament who actually represent the people who they purport to represent. I will be part of it and I will be proud to be part of it. I encourage other members of parliament to stand up for the people they represent, irrespective of what side of parliament they are on or whether or not they are in a party. It is about time, particularly in relation to regional and country issues, that we started to stand up for those people. We have seen this classic example, an example greater than any other that I can remember, where country people have said to this parliament and all their parliamentarians by way of survey and carrier pigeon that they do not want Telstra sold. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI was expecting to hear something from the honourable member for New England, but what he said had nothing to do with the matter of public importance; it was more about getting the dirt off the honourable member for New Englandâs liver. Quite frankly, that is all that we heard.

speech.para: If we want to talk about honesty and integrity in government and having people look up to politicians, I dare say that we have to start here. Most of it is generated from this particular chamber and from statements made here that are not entirely true. It does not just include this side of the House or that side of the House; it includes Independent members as well. This motion today is not so much about honesty or openness in government; it is more about relevance deprivation syndrome. Quite frankly, that is what it is all about.

The honourable member for New England has been in parliament for a number of years: he was in the New South Wales parliament for a number of yearsâhe was there when I was thereâand he has been here for a number of years. Except for one term in New South Wales when he had the balance of power with the coalition government, he has achieved absolutely nothing in politics. He is bitter about that, and that is where most of these problems that he has at the present time come from. If people do not entirely accept the view of the member for New England, then of course there must be some ulterior motive, he thinks.

We just heard a spray on the National Farmers Federation. I will say something about this Telstra debate because I think it is relevant to the whole process. There is no doubt in my mind that, as far as the people of Australia are concerned, the sooner we get some competition in this field the better. There have been many articles in the papers over the last few days showing how far behind we are in Australia compared to countries that have competition. Yet the honourable member for New England, the honourable member for Kennedy, the honourable member for Calare and those over on the opposition side would prefer to see us live in the Dark Ages. They do not want to see some of this competition. They then say: âOh well, the government are not being honest. They are not being honest with the people.â As far as honesty is concerned, we are saying it exactly as it is.

The honourable member for New England goes on about the services of Telstra, that it is not âup to scratchâ, as he puts it. If any electorate in New South Wales has benefited from the billion dollars that has been spent by our government over the last few years, it has been the electorate of New England. We still have the funds available to continue that. The member for New England is never honest enough to say that to the Australian peopleâthat is the issue here today.

When the member for New England had the balance of power in New South Wales, I remember one big statement he made over an issue in his electorate where he was looking for something from the government. He said that Greiner came along with a brown paper bag in his hand. That is what he said in New South Wales. It is a little bit duplicitous on the one hand to accuse people when on the other hand he has said similar things himself.

Let us have a look at the openness of our government. I have heard those opposite and the Independents talk about the GST debate. I have also heard the cries of ânever, everâ from over there about the Prime Minister saying at a previous time that he did not want to have a goods and services tax. But one thing I will say is that we went to an election with that as a policy. If anyone has ever fought a hard election, I can tell you that that was a hard election because we were being open with the people about what was going to happen. The GST did not go to our government; it was for the benefit of Australia so that the state governments could get a growth tax to provide the services that they need in their states. It was nothing to do with us. We almost committed harakiri in the name of the country. If that is not honest, I do not know what honest is.

It is the same when it comes to the words that are thrown around this chamber about âchildren overboardâ. Have a look at the Senate inquiry. While at that particular time the Senate inquiry showed that the words may not have been used, children were thrown overboard only two or three days before. It was proven to be a policy of these people and what they were doing, yet in this parliament the Labor Party, in particular, try and distort the whole debate by just picking a few words out here and there instead of being absolutely honest about the whole debate.

As I said, this is not the real reason behind this matter of public importanceâthe real reason has nothing to do with the words on the paper; it is to try and get the dirt off the liver of the member for New England.

talk.start.para: âTell us about the Fuel Sales Grant Scheme.

âWe will have a look at this fuel sales tax because it is something that the member for New England has been on about for a long time. It was not this governmentâs policy; it was to get the GST through the Senate by a deal done with the Democrats. If the member for New England were patient, he might see something in the future, but he is never patient to see what might happen. That deal had to be done because the Democrats had this complicated policy. I was not very happy about it at the time either, but if we wanted to get the legislation through there were a few things that we had to agree to. There were a few compromises that we had to make. We did not have the luxury of being an Independent, sitting back there being irrelevant and throwing your opinion around the place. When you are in government, you have to make some decisions and you sometimes have to make some compromises. But you make those decisions and those compromises in the interests of the country.

speech.para: This whole debate about Telstra shows a lack of vision by the Independents, in particular, and the Labor Party. There is no vision to see where we are going in the future with telecommunications. In fact, I suppose they could almost be classed as troglodytes, because the fact is that, if you want to see where we are going in the future, you will find that it is moving at a rapid rate, because we have competition. Only yesterday I noticed an article in the newspaper backing up what I said in my speech on Telstra the other day. It said that we can now give broadband across an electricity line. It is being rolled out in Tasmania. There is a second networkâcompetitionâand yet we are hearing this rubbish from the Independents that somehow or other the world is going to collapse. I can assure you that we are going to get better services, not because we have had any vision from those opposite but because people were prepared to sit down, have a look at the options and work through this.

I also heard the member for New England mention climate change. I can only suspect that he was talking about the Kyoto protocol. I would be absolutely amazed and absolutely surprised if the member for New England were prepared to sell Australian jobs overseas.

talk.start.para: âItâs called fine particle emissions.
âOrder! The member for New England has had his turn.

âWe now have the idiot fringe over here talking about how ethanol will change that. Let me put it to you this way: if these fuels were competitive with oil at the present time, they would be in the marketplace. You hear all the ranting and the raving, but go and have a close look at the cost of these fuels. If they were competitive, they would be in the marketplace. I have heard the member for Kennedy before on ethanol and sugar. Let me say this to you, Mr Speaker: I will not be growing sugar for ethanol because you cannot make enough money out of it. That is just an absolutely nonsensical argument.

speech.para: With regard to the Kyoto protocol, obviously the member for New England is prepared to say, âWeâll cut back on all our emissions, destroy our opportunities to develop and destroy our jobs in this country so that we can let undeveloped countries take over all those jobs and all those opportunities.â I do not think that is fair. The governmentâs policy to reduce emissions overall and to give some encouragement for worldâs best technology in underdeveloped countries is the right one. Have we been dishonest about that? We have been quite open about it; we have told everyone exactly where we stand on that. So I think that that particular position is absolute nonsense.

We hear a lot about these issues but I have yet to hear one word that I could believeâand I did not hear it in this debateâthat showed where this government had not been completely honest with the Australian people. The issues here are the fudging of the edges. I suppose that is politics, but to make the claim that someone has been deliberately dishonest is a dishonest statement.

talk.start.para: âWhere are the property rights for water?

âThe member for New England wants to have a second debate here, apparently, because he does not like being told a different story and to hear another opinion. We had the situation in which he made all sorts of allegations about the grants to Regional Partnerships, but when it was asked that they be backed up in the Senate they were not backed up at all.
Mr Windsor interjectingâ
âThe member for New England was heard in silence.

âIf you have a close look at these grants, you will see that they are right across the board and not just in government seats. If you want to talk about rural Australia, you must ask: who represents rural Australia? It is the government members who represent rural Australia, so, naturally, if there are going to be grants in seats in rural Australia, more government members will be involved than opposition members; they represent Sydney and Melbourne. Obviously that is going to happen. But then you make the claim that something is dishonest about this. Is it any wonder that people have concerns about it when the member for New England is out there throwing the mud around? Obviously people will start to believe some of this. I think it was Goebbels who once said, âTell them often enough and theyâll believe it,â and that is certainly the attitude that has been adopted. I would reject completely the allegations that have been made against the government in this debate, because, quite frankly, I have never served under a government that has been so open to the Australian people. We have gone to elections making it very clear where we stood.

speech.para: The member for New England talked about Iraq. If you want to go back to where the Iraq situation all started, the United Nations believed, Mr Butler believed and the British and Americans believed that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction. We are all very wise in hindsight when we start to throw things around, but, at the time, the world believed that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction. He was offered the chance of having inspectors in there and he refused. But now we have these wonderful people who, in hindsight, say, âYou were wrong.â Hindsight is great, isnât it? But where were they leading? Where were they with their ideas? All they can do is sit back and snipe. That is their only ambition, and that is their only use in lifeâto sit back and snipe.

The member for New England has been doing it now for a number of years. His absolute obsession with some of these things has to be seen to be believed. Yes, he missed out on preselection for The Nationals. He stood as an Independent and won the seatâcongratulationsâbut, since then, he has been bitter. That is where the whole thing comes fromâthe whole attack and all the issues. If something is going to be put up by the government, especially by The Nationals, he will oppose it; he will do anything to undermine it. We have heard it today. He wants to stand members in seatsâthat is not new. He has been out there before, standing Independent members in seats, but they have not won. I think that one or two seats went to Independents in certain areas, but then they came back again. That issue has been out there for a long time.

I saw in the paper this morning that the member for New England was gloating and saying, âThis is the end of The Nationals.â Let me tell the member for New England: as people realise that the policies that have been put in place are going to benefit those in country areas and as people realise what not just The Nationals but Liberal backbenchers from the country areas fought for in Telstraâto see that services in those non-profitable areas were protectedâthey will understand. We will continue to roll out those services. They will also see the competition that is going to come into the marketplace. They will see that the prediction of doom and gloom by the member for New England and others was wrong. I have to say to you, Mr Speaker, that they will be grateful, because at the present time families in Australia are saving $750 a year because of the changes that have come into place in telecommunications, and they will save more in the future. Those in the isolated areas that are served by the member for Kennedy, for instance, now get subsidised satellite, and they have never had a better service. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI agree with the previous speaker, the member for Page, in saying that services from Telstra are goodâwell, I am not saying that they are good; I should say that they are acceptable. It has never been my position to condemn the services from Telstra. But if they are acceptable then why are you selling Telstra? If something is not broken, why do you want to fix it? Like me, the honourable member for Page has been a long-serving minister in a government. My policy was always: if it ainât broke, donât fix it, because we have enough broken things out there that do need fixing.

speech.para: I admire the member for Page in many ways, as I have said in this House on many occasions, but I cannot resile from my duty to point out to the House the statement by the government that they are going to provide $3,000 million to meet the requirements of rural Australia. I can skite; it is open to me to get out there and skite, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, because, with all due respect, in sharp contrast to what you just said previouslyâthat we have achieved nothingâif we were not here, if I had been beaten at the last election or the election before last or if the honourable member for New England were not here, we would not have lobbied the senators, and Telstra would have been sold the last time the government wanted to sell it. It would have been sold and there would not have been the $3,000 million that you people are claiming. I will come back to the $3,000 million, because we are talking about truthfulness, openness and honesty here.

According to Telstra Country Wide, last year they put $231 million into new services. According to government papers, there was $280 million put into Networking the Nation and there was a further $163 million spent this year by Telstra Country Wide. If you add those up, you get a figure of $700 million. If Telstra had been sold, there would have been no $700 million thereâand it would have been sold if we had not lobbied the Independent and small party senators. Three of them had made statements which at best were equivocal and, at worst, certainly indicated that they were going to vote for the sale of Telstra. That was until we did the heavy lobbying. I do not want to or have time to go into the detail, but it would have been gone. If you people are standing here today skiting about securing the $3,000 million, you should remember that there would have been no $3,000 million. It would have been sold three years ago. So if there is anyone to be thanked for this, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, by your own arguments it is the three gentlemen, the three amigos, sitting in this part of the House.

Let me move on. Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, you said that we were ineffective. The honourable member for New England and I secured money before the last election campaign which would make maidens blush. If they had been National Party seats, they would have got considerably less. They would have got the same as all the other National Party seats. But, because Mr Anderson, the then Deputy Prime Minister, wanted to indulge his own personal hatreds and vitriol, largesse was poured into our electorates like we had never seen before. But if we had just held up our hands and voted with the governmentââGofer, send a rubber stamp and a photograph to this placeââthen there would have been none of the largesse pouring in before the last election. I most certainly thank the government for the $227 million they poured into Kennedy in discretionary funds on the eve of the last election.

I am not in a position to disclose what happened in the banana industry, but suffice to say that the imported bananas are not in Australia at the present moment. We still live in fear and terror that they are going to come in, but that was put off because of my actions, and I do not resile from saying that or apologise to anyone for saying it.

The beef quotas came out and they were enormously detrimental to the grinding beef market of Australia. They helped the plate beef market, but they were dreadful for us. Again, I cannot outline what actions I took, but suffice to say that the quota arrangements were changed.

Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, you are a very skilled person who knows a very great deal about the sugar industry, but you are not up to speed on this. With regard to the Brazilian ethanol program, the document I hold was produced by the Brazilian government and Unicaâwhich you would be familiar withâand is to be presented at a Queensland seminar on ethanol. Page 9 says that, regarding the cane sector in Brazil, âEthanol makes gasoline cheaper. There is no pure gasoline in the Brazilian market today.â There is E25 at US90c; and E100, which is pure ethanol, at US50c a litre. Working that back into Australian currency, the good people we have in the library tell me that it works out to 66c a litre. I am sorry, but the figure in Australia is 76c a litre. When you add 12c a litre, which the government is applying in tax on ethanolâit is the only government in the world to apply a tax on ethanolâit comes out to 78c a litre. Then if you apply the excise regime on petrol it comes out to 114c a litre. I am sorry, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, but I have to tell you that it is 78c a litre. That is what we should be able to buy it at. There is a transport and retail margin, but that goes on both fuels: petrol and ethanol. The comparable figures, before the retail and transport margin goes in, are 78c and 114c.

They are not my figures; they are the figures from Brazil that were presented in Cairns. There were members of the government present in Cairns, Townsville and also at the big international seminar that was held in Brisbane. I was quoting the ethanol production figures recently at 600 litres. In fact, in one of the papers that was presented, they were still on 600 litres. That was corrected by the Brazilians, as I was. The Brazilians said: âWe are now getting 700 to 800 litres out of ethanol.â But even without that, I am simply quoting the figures that the Brazilian government has produced.

If the three amigos are not here, then every time we deregulate something everyone in this place will be for it. Everyone in this place is a free marketeer. The government did not invent this; in fact, they were also-rans. There was hardly anything left to privatise by the time they came in; it was all done by the Labor government and the policies have not changed. But the only three people with different policies in this place are the three amigos. We do not believe in the policies of free markets. Labor have already established that they do; they were in government for 12, 13 or 15 yearsâwhatever it wasâand they privatised and deregulated everything that they could lay their hands on.

This government took over what was leftâderegulation of the dairy industry, for example. I do not accuse you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Your position was made very clear to everybody, and there were other people who agreed with you. But that was what the government did. I am ashamed to say that at that time I was part of the government. I made a decision to no longer be part of the problem. Maybe I am not part of the solution, but I am most certainly no longer part of the problem. For those that are in government, I am sorry to tell you that you are part of the problem.

I had a lot to do with fighting corruption in Queensland and the most serious ramifications that occurred in that state. I am very familiar with how these things work. The payouts that were made in the fishing industry bear very close scrutiny. I give warning that I am scrutinising those payouts. I am scrutinising where the money flowed and how it flowed.

The people where the citrus canker outbreak occurred were foreign people. They had special arrangements with the government that have never been denied in the newspapers or in this place. The citrus canker came in and there was a $5,000 donation not to party funds, where it had to be made public, but to a research foundation. That is where all this money is laundered. All parties do that; I am not singling out the National Party. When you have been in politics for 32 years like I have, your antenna goes up when something is done with indecent haste, such as the sale of Telstra. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThank you for the opportunity to speak on this matter of public importance. Mr Deputy Speaker, you know that I am a new member in this place. I have not quite one year of experience, and today is my first opportunity to speak on what we call in this building an MPI. The member for New England brought on the matter of public importance, namely:

quote.para: The necessity for the Government to treat the Australian people with openness and frankness.

speech.para: There is not one person here who could disagree with that statement. I say these words as the member for New England is leaving the room. That statement has been notoriously twisted and turned around. It shows that what underlies the member for New Englandâs actions today is nothing short of hatred. I really mean that. It has been evident. You could see it on his face; you could hear it in his words; you could hear it in the timbre of his voice as he spoke. There were no interruptions from members listening to himâthe chair, members on this side of the House or even those from the opposition side. But as the member for Page was taking the opportunity to rebut some of the statements made by the member for New England there was constant interjection, interruption and sniggering and the member for New England made further spurious claims.

I bear the member for New England no ill will; I hardly know him. As a new member I have met him a few times; he seems okay, but when he strides into this chamber something quite different confronts everybody in this room. It is worth pointing out to people who may be in the gallery or listening on the broadcast that to raise a matter of public importance it is necessary, when given the opportunity, for the Speaker to identify at least eight members of parliament who stand with the person who is raising the MPI to support the fact that we should have the debate. So today, given the opportunity, eight members stood; in fact, all of the opposition were here right after question time and they all stood in their places. They supported the member for New England in raising this MPI. If it is a matter of public importance, you stand and agree that we should debate this for an hour or an hour and a half. They are all gone.

talk.start.para: âThatâs not right; Iâm here.

âThe member for Rankin has returned, but they all went. The member for New England has gone. He does not want to hear any more; he has had enough; he has had his say. He has raised the MPI, but he has gone. He does not want to hear any critique of what he has had to say.
âThis is full of substance, isnât it!
âIf you havenât got 10 minutes, just sit down.
âI would like to be heard.
Mr Griffin interjectingâ
(Hon. IR Causley)âThe member for Bass has the call.

âThe member for New England raised a scattergun of issues claiming that the government had been less that honest, less than open and less than frank. He scattergunned with âchildren overboardâ; he threw in Telstra, Iraq and even climate change for good measure, and we still did not get to the bottom of what he meant. He said that these issues and others were starting to erode public confidence in this important institutionânot just the government but the parliament.

speech.para: I would have to say that I share some understanding of how people feel, particularly when they watch or listen to question time. I am very aware of this. I hear it in my electorate when I am meeting people. They often mention thisâthat question time is like a bear pit. People are attacking each other, sometimes personally. Today we heard it from the would-be health minister, the member for Lalor, when she was attacking the Acting Prime Minister for taking steps to show some compassion when one of his colleagues was in hospital.

I accept that. I understand that question time can be a pretty angry time. It shows us at our worst; I would admit that. But at least it is democracy in action. At least the chair has the opportunity to shut down people who are acting inappropriately, to kick them out if they do not accept a warning and to require people to withdraw when they make outrageous statementsâsuch as the time when the chair had to send out the member for New England for what have been proven to be outrageous, unfair, unqualified, unsubstantiated claims of bribery against the then Deputy Prime Minister, the member for Gwydir. What a shame that was and what a disgrace.

There is a real arrogance in the member for New England today lecturing people like me on this sideâlecturing this chamberâabout the need to be open, honest and frank. It is shockingly arrogant. It is also very hypocritical. When he was given the opportunity to make the same statements outside the parliament, he would not do it. He was not prepared to make his claims against John Anderson, the member for Gwydir, outside this chamberâwithout the protection of the soft green leather chairs and parliamentary privilege. He would not do it.

Instead of taking personal responsibility for himself, being accountable for his own actions and explaining to his electorate why he is not even here half the timeâand I include question time and voting in divisions in thatâhe lashes out. As I have said, he is a man filled with hatred and anger. That is a great disappointment to me and I know it is a great disappointment to people all over Australia who have been witness to it.

What a shame that instead of taking responsibility for himself he has only one course of actionâto enlist the support of the Labor Party in attacking the government. They leave him for dead. He is on his own. They have just used him today as a puppet. Even the member for Rankin has now gone. I hope he comes back. I would like to hear what he has to say. I will listen to him.

It is very easy to accuse other people of corruption. That is terribly easy. It is very, very easy to attribute an improper motive to another person. None of us is perfect. I know I am not. Like so many other people on both sides of the chamber, I appreciate the value of honesty. None of us meets the test all the time. True integrity is living what you believe, living it outâactually demonstrating it. Honesty is saying the truth.

I would say that, to a degree, everybody has integrity and honesty. All of us have that. For example, we all tell the truth most of the time. A truly honest person is someone who tells the truth even when it hurtsâwhen it is hard to tell the truth, when they know they have done something wrong and they should give account. That is an honest person. A person with integrity is a person who lives their beliefs when it hurts them, when it costs them. I am not seeing it today. I have not seen it in some of the Independentsâ actions in my 11 months as the member for Bass.

Rather than criticising other people and making virtually criminal accusations against them, I suggest that the member for New England should take account of his own actions. He should recognise that the claims he has made in the past are really claims that can be put up against his own test of not being open, not being frank. He was not prepared to make claims against other people outside this chamber. I suggest that some of the other claims he has made today he would not be prepared to make outside the chamber.

When the member for New England says that these actions of the government, which he has virtually made up, are starting to erode trust in government, he is partly right, but he is part of the problem. He is the one who is talking down the positive attributes of, frankly, probably Australiaâs most honest Prime Minister and his government. The member for Rankin looks as though he has just emptied his stomach over there behind his desk. But the reality is that he is filled with hatred against the Liberal Party in the same way the member for New England is filled with hatred against any member of the National Party. We have heard about the disappointments of the member for New England today. We have heard about that fateful day when he missed out on preselection and then wanted to run as an Independent.

Today the member for Kennedy, instead of saying that it is a bribe when somebody negotiates a position with the government and that involves a package of reforms and improvements to infrastructureârather than saying that, as an Independent he is now taking the credit for Networking the Nation. You cannot have it both ways.

This government is an honest government. This government, like me, is not perfect. But do not go lecturing us on being open, frank and accountable to the Australian people when we have demonstrated that we will go to an election with a hard policy and then implement itânot like the Labor Party when it goes to an election with l-a-w law tax cuts and then after the election shuts them down.

Debate resumed from 13 September, on motion by Mr Abbott:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âThe continuation of the debate on the Health Insurance Amendment (Medicare Safety-nets) Bill 2005 gives me the opportunity to comment on the governmentâs honesty. I did welcome the just completed debate on the matter of public importance about the necessity for the government to treat the Australian people with openness and frankness. The government has failed to do that in the nine long years in which it has ruled this country. The contribution to the matter of public importance from the previous speaker, the member for Bass, was astonishing, to say the least, when he declared that the Prime Minister must be the most honest Prime Minister this country has ever had. The member for Bass is a new member and he may not be fully aware of the document entitled Truth overboard: 27 Lies told by John Howard and counting. I will not go through all of those becauseâ
(Hon. IR Causley)âOrder! That has nothing to do with the bill before the House.

âI do want to confine myself to the Medicare safety net legislation. In order to do that we will need to set some benchmarks in truth and honesty in government. The Medicare safety net legislation is a formalisation of the breaking of an election promise by this governmentâthe breaking of a promise that it knew before the election that it could not keep but it did not have the honesty to take the Australian people into its confidence and tell them before the election that it would not be able to sustain the Medicare safety net because it was too financially expensive and costs were blowing out.

speech.para: I mentioned that we need to make these judgments against benchmarks set by leaders. That benchmark was set in respect of this government by the Prime Minister of Australia when he was opposition leader. He said on 25 August 1995:

quote.para: Truth is absolute, truth is supreme, truth is never disposable in national political life.

speech.para: The Prime Minister, the Treasurer and most particularly the health minister knew the truth before the last election. The truth was that the Medicare safety net was unsustainable. The department of finance had advised the finance minister of this fact and obviously that fact was shared with other ministers. Nevertheless, the government proceeded to spend $20 million of taxpayersâ money assuring the Australian people that the Medicare safety net would remain intact in full. The Minister for Health and Ageing told the Australian people just before the last election, on 16 September:

quote.para: I absolutely guarantee that the safety net, as the government has put it into operation, will continueâI absolutely guarantee it.

speech.para: He said in another interview 10 days before that:

motion.para: That is an absolutely rock solid, iron-clad commitment.

speech.para: We have just had a debate about truth and honesty in government. When the minister was making those statements he was aware that the cost of the Medicare safety net was blowing out and yet he continued to say that this was a promise that would be kept after the election. The government knew that it could not keep that promise; nevertheless, it continued to reassure the Australian people that it would be kept.

During question time the same minister unloaded another bucket of vitriol in the Australian parliament, using harsh language but most importantly conveying to the Australian people his hatred and his bitterness. This is not a great day for the Australian Labor Party with the release of the Latham diariesâwe know that. Mr Latham has left this parliament a very bitter and disappointed man. But we have in this parliament still a very bitter and disappointed man, and that man is the minister for health.

The minister for health is a shadow of his former selfâa shell of a man. I remember when I first became a member of parliament in 1998 and the now minister for health had been promoted to a junior portfolio. He used to lumber from the end of the frontbench to the microphone and, to show that he was a really tough guy, he would lay into the Labor Party or anyone else with his vitriol. This man has continued to do that right up to this day, in question time today. He is an embarrassment to the Australian parliament. He is a very bitter and disappointed man.

The minister for health should himself consider his position in the Australian parliament and consider whether he has any further worthwhile contribution to make to public policy formulation in this country. We are debating a piece of legislation that formalises the breaking of a promise by the Howard government, the breaking of a promise by the minister for health and the breaking of an assurance that he would absolutely guarantee this as a rock solid commitment.

But he is completely unabashed. There seems to be no embarrassment on the part of this minister to then get up in question time today as though he were some sort of great orator and great contributor to the parliamentary debates in our great country. He is not. He is a very bitter and disappointed man. His ambitions have been thwarted by none other than himself, because he has proven time and time again that he is a stranger to the truthâas formalised in this Medicare safety net legislation. As I mentioned previously, the word âabsolutelyâ comes out of the mouth of the health minister with monotonous regularity. When the word âabsolutelyâ comes out in response to a question, particularly from the health minister, you need to be suspicious that in fact he is saying exactly the opposite. Where do I get the evidence for that? I get the evidence for that in a Four Corners interview of 1998, when he was asked about financial backing for Terry Sharples. The reporterâs question was:

quote.para: So there was never any question of any party or other funds from any other source being offered to Terry Sharples?

speech.para: The minister answered:

quote.para: Absolutely not, absolutely not ...

talk.start.para: âOrder! It is hard to see how the member for Rankin could tie that back to the bill.

âMr Deputy Speaker, I am going to the health ministerâs credibility and capacity to tell the truth. The fact is that his incapacity to tell the truth is formalised here, today, in a piece of legislation that this parliament will be voting on. This piece of legislation declares that the ministerâs commitmentsâgiven as an ironclad promise with the use of the word âabsolutelyââhave today been broken. The government announced before the election that it would sustain this Medicare safety net, even though it knew before the election that it would not be able to do so. It put in $20 million of taxpayersâ funds to assure the Australian people that the Medicare safety net would be retained in full.
âMr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I ask that you direct the member to keep his comments on the bill.
(Hon. IR Causley)âI have already done that, member for Makin.

âIf the member for Makin had been listening, she would know that I was talking about $20 million of taxpayersâ funds being used to perpetrate what the Australian government and the health minister knew to be untrue: that the Medicare safety net would be retained in full. If the member were to check the Notice Paper, she would know that the debate here in the parliament this afternoon is on the Medicare safety net legislation. I trust that, following the closing of my remarks, she will make some sort of a contribution to this debate. The fact is that the government did not tell the truth. Against the benchmark set by the Prime Minister of Australia that:

quote.para: ... truth is absolute, truth is supreme, truth is never disposable in national political life ...

speech.para: This parliament ought to condemn the health minister for his wilful incapacity to tell the truth. That is what has happened here todayâand, in making some sort of assessment of this health minister, it is not the only time. Members of parliament may well recall a recent interview in relation to health policy that occurred on Lateline on 30 September last year. The transcript of that interview reads as follows:

quote.para: TONY JONES: Tony Abbott on another matter, have you met Archbishop Pell during the election campaign?
TONY ABBOTT: Not that I can recall.
TONY JONES: Not that you can recall, because we believe that youâve had at least one meeting with him quite recently? You donât recall that?
TONY ABBOTT: Well, when? Where?
TONY JONES: At the presbytery in Sydney.
TONY ABBOTT: Ah, actually now that you do mention it, I did meet with Cardinal Pell. So what? Why shouldnât I meet with Cardinal Pell?

speech.para: It was only when the health minister realised that Tony Jones of Lateline had details not only of the time of the meeting but also the venue of the meeting that the health minister realised that he would have to tell the truth. But if the health minister could have gotten away with not telling the truth, as he had attempted to, he would have. If the details had not been known to the ABC, the health minister yet again would not have told the truth. Here he is in parliament today in question time, unloading his bucket of bile in the Australian parliament because he has nothing to contribute to health policy. This is a man who presides over a health budget in excess of $30,000 million, yet he spends most of his waking hours thinking of language that he can pour out of his mouth in getting stuck into the Labor Party, while displaying to the Australian people that he is not fit to be a member of this parliament.

There is one bitter and disappointed man who has left this parliament; another bitter and disappointed man ought to leave it as quickly as possible. We will do everything that we possibly can to ensure that the minister for health leaves this parliament; it is time. As was evidenced in this debate on a matter of public importance to raise the standardâ

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I fail to see how any of the honourable memberâs remarks relate in any way to the bill that is under discussion.
(Hon. IR Causley)âThe member for Rankin is in order.

âThank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I will just use my last 30 seconds to explain to the member for Makin that the truth has a valueâand the truth and a promise in this legislation is being broken. When this bill passes the House, this legislation will formalise the breaking of a promise by the health ministerâand he should be condemned for it. (Time expired)

âI rise to oppose the Health Insurance Amendment (Medicare Safety-nets) Bill 2005. It is interesting that we are speaking on this piece of legislation on a day when we have discussed a matter of public importance relating to the necessity for government to treat the Australian people with openness and frankness. This billâs purpose is to reduce the annual thresholds above which benefits under the extended Medicare safety net are payable. From 1 January 2006, the thresholds will increase from $306.90 to $500 for concession card holders and other low-income families, and from $716.10 to $1,000 for all other families and individuals. In debating this legislation, I wish to make three points. One is the fact that this is the legislation of a broken election promise by the Howard government. The second matter I want to discuss is the inequitable nature of the Medicare safety net. The third is that this piece of legislation and the Medicare safety net are other aspects of the governmentâs health care program that lead to this mish-mash we have seen in the development of health policies by this government.

speech.para: In the short time that I have tonight, I want to go to the point of equity, because it is very interesting to look at where the benefit from this measure is going. From the latest figures available for the federal electorates in Victoria, each of the electorates of Kooyong, Goldstein and Higgins gains over $500,000 because of this policy: $560,000 to Kooyong, $529,000 to Goldstein and $523,000 to Higgins. If we look at Indi, it is $203,000. If we look at the seat of Scullin, it is $185,000. Mr Speaker, if we look at Wannon, it is $108,000. On equity grounds, how could it be said that an electorate like Wannon, in health policy, should gain around half a million dollars less in a quarter than electorates like Kooyong, Goldstein and Higgins? That is one of the problems with this overall piece of policy. The fact that this represents a broken election promise is an issue that also needs to be developed.
