talk.start.para: âI rise to comment on recent events in my electorate that deserve to be placed on the record in this place. Last weekend Wangaratta Aerodrome played host to a very significant event commemorating our returned service men and women. The Benalla campus of the Goulburn Ovens Institute of TAFE organised a successful Pacific flyers reunion to complement recent commemorations of the 60th anniversary of Victory in the Pacific Day. The day included a flyover of historic aircraft, displays of fighter aircraft, a display of historic military vehicles and a tour of the museum precinct and the aircraft restoration facility.

speech.para: I want to thank Adrian Vaughan and his organising team from the Benalla TAFE, who spent many months organising this event. It was part of a documentary by the TAFEâs multimedia students called On a Wing and a Prayer on the restoration of war planes. Over 1,000 people attended in blustery and wet conditions, including many veterans who came from far-off places. A particular highlight was the flight of a lovingly restored P40 Kittyhawk fighter-bomber which was last in operation in Papua New Guinea 60 years ago. It was back in the air last weekend at Wangaratta Aerodrome and was reunited with its former pilot, Robert Warren, who came from his home town of Tulsa in Oklahoma to be in Wangaratta for this historic event. Mr Warren was delighted at the restoration work carried out on the plane by Wangarattaâs own Precision Aerospace Productions.

But residents heard the loudest roar when they played host to an F18 Hornet flyover. At this point, I want to place on the record my thanks and appreciation to Senator Robert Hill, the Minister for Defence. At the last minute, when it looked like the flyover would not be able to take place owing to an absence of pavement concessions and indemnity insurance, the organisers approached my office and I swiftly took up the matter with the ministerâs office. Once these outstanding issues were addressed, the minister gave his approval on Friday afternoon for this historic flyover. I thank him and his office for doing everything possible to ensure that this very welcome and much anticipated community event went ahead. Former Wangaratta resident Shawn Mathews flew the Hornet from the base in Williamtown.

Another event of note in the north-east last weekend was the annual staging of the Three Choirs Festival. This is a yearly event where the three pre-eminent choirs in the regionâthe Wangaratta Choristers, the Beechworth Singers and the Murray Conservatorium Choirâcollaborate to deliver a series of concerts to audiences in our region. This yearâs feature work was the rarely heard Beethoven Mass in C. Beethoven is not particularly renowned for his sacred music compositions, but the Mass in C is a delight for listeners. Unfortunately, I was unable to attend the concerts last weekend, but I am told that the concerts in Yarrawonga, Wodonga and Wangaratta were a great success.

Another aspect of the concert was the performance of a work by one of my constituents, local Wodonga resident Bohdan Krowicky. His piece âThou and Iâ is a hauntingly evocative composition, with the text taken from a poem by the 13th century mystic Rumi. All credit goes to my constituent Mr Krowicky for having his own composition performed publicly. We can often forget the achievements of our musicians, artists and composers, particularly in rural and regional areas, but it is important to give these home-grown works a performance whenever we can.

I am informed that the crowds were a bit down in Yarrawonga on the Friday night but that the attendances at Wodonga and Wangaratta were excellent and the crowds were definitely treated to quality performances by our local musicians. Thanks go to Ben Wilson, director of the Wangaratta Choristers, Margaret Phillips, director of the Beechworth Singers, and Michael Halsey, director of the Murray Conservatorium Choir, who prepared the respective choirs excellently for this event. Events such as this show that the arts and in particular musical performance are respected and encouraged in rural and regional Australia. We should work towards continuing to develop regional arts practice and the role of the arts in sustaining and unifying our regional communities.

talk.start.para: âThis year, 2005, has been an important year for both the state of Israel and the Palestinian Authority. Mahmoud Abbas was elected President of the Palestinian Authority, and Prime Minister Sharon and President Abbas declared a cease-fire between Israel and the Palestinian Authority. In February the Knesset voted 59 to 40 to approve the disengagement implementation law, an act of parliament that would see more than 8,000 Israeli settlers in Gaza evacuated and the resultant vacant land given back to the Palestinian people. It must be said that Israelâs decision to withdraw from Gaza has been controversial. Not many people would dispute that. Many within Israel itself were not happy with Prime Minister Sharonâs decision but Mr Sharon, to his credit, persevered until this week, when the parliament formally recognised Israelâs withdrawal from Gaza.

speech.para: The conclusion of an Israeli withdrawal from Gaza is a significant step towards an overall peace settlement in the Middle East and should be welcomed by all Australians. As Chief Opposition Whip, I take this opportunity on behalf of the Labor Party to commend Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, the Israeli parliament and the Israeli people for taking this courageous step, which has clearly been a very traumatic and painful process for Israel. Whatever we may think of Israeli occupation of the Palestinian territories or of the settlement policies of the previous Israeli governments, the decision to remove more than 8,000 settlers from Gaza and return the territory to Palestinian rule is a major advance towards a peaceful settlement, particularly since it was done unilaterally and without any guarantees of security.

Labor now calls on both sides to follow up the momentum created by this withdrawal by taking further concrete steps to keep the peace process moving. On the Palestinian side, this must include a crackdown on those groups responsible for terrorist attacks on Israel and an end to the incitement and encouragement of violence and hatred. On the Israeli side, there needs to be continuing disengagement from the West Bank and steps taken to allow the Palestinian Authority to assume full responsibility for Gaza, including its air space and coastline, in a manner consistent with Israelâs legitimate security interests.

So why is this relevant to the Australian parliament? Because we on our side of the chamber take a keen interest in the Middle East. Labor wears on its chest with pride its role in the creation of an Israeli state. It was, after all, the Chifley Labor government which, over 50 years ago, was amongst the first in the world to give political support to the idea of a Jewish state. Under Labor, Australia was the first country to vote in favour of the 1947 partition resolution. And, as President of the United Nations General Assembly, former Labor foreign minister Dr Evatt played a key role in the founding of Israel in 1948.

For the past 50 years Labor has never taken a backward step in advocating practical solutions to the long-running Israel-Palestine conflict. In recent years Labor has repeatedly urged both Israel and Palestine to engage on the road map to peace. We believe, despite some setbacks along the way, that the road map offers the strongest possibility of a sustainable and robust peace between Israelis and Palestinians. Our policy is based on the right of the state of Israel to exist within secure boundaries. We do not back away from that. We vest our hope in a two-state solution involving the creation of a separate Palestinian state behind secure boundaries. A lasting settlement between the Palestinian and Israeli peoples is the only way forward.

No-one should pretend that the road map to peace is an easy path. It is not. But progress is being made. The withdrawal from Gaza is another step forward. To ignore that fact is ignorant. Australia should do whatever it can in the coming months to encourage both sides to maintain the momentum created by Israelâs decision to withdraw from Gaza. It is true that the honourable member for Fowler, who is always passionate about the causes she embraces, used some words in a speech which caused offence, but she withdrew them today after question time and I admire the honourable member for Fowler for her courage in doing so.

talk.start.para: âI rise today to express on behalf of my constituents and many residents of the Gold Coast our disgust at the betrayal by the Beattie Labor government of residents who live in my electorate and who live within the confines of Gold Coast City. At 11 am this morning the Beattie state Labor government ended the charade they had been carrying on with for a matter of months about what they would be doing with the cruise ship terminal on the Gold Coast. At 11 am this morning, Anna Bligh, the Deputy Premier and state Labor Minister for State Development, announced to the assembled media throng that the Beattie Labor government would be pushing ahead with the proposal to build a cruise ship terminal.

speech.para: Those on the Gold Coast who have been following this debate closely for some time would know that I have thought for some monthsâand, indeed, I had heard whispers for some monthsâthat the Beattie state Labor government had in fact passed through their cabinet last December the decision to push forward with a cruise ship terminal, despite the fact that it is very clear that many residents of Main Beach, Surfers Paradise and more broadly were opposed to the idea of a cruise ship terminal on the Spit.

Questions need to be asked. Why is the state Labor government undertaking this path? Why is the state Labor government turning up its nose at the residents of Main Beach? Why is the state Labor government turning its back on the residents of Surfers Paradise and imposing this cruise ship terminal in an area where nobody wants it to be built? The reason is that it is a knee-jerk political reaction from a very scared state Labor government to try to save backsides and to ensure the political survival of the state member for Southport, Peter Lawlor, and the state member for Broadwater, Peta-Kaye Croft.

In this particular instance, what is very clear is that a deal has been done by the state Labor government in the context of a cruise ship terminal. In particular, the state Labor government has pushed forward with three key proposals as part of the development of a cruise ship terminal. So for many months now we have seen the state Labor government talking about the fact that it says a cruise ship terminal is good for the Gold Coast. Indeed, I support that notion, as does my colleague the state Liberal member for Surfers Paradise, John-Paul Langbroek. Dr Langbroek and I have been saying that we support a cruise ship terminal, but we reject entirely the notion that a cruise ship terminal should be built on the end of the Spit. We reject entirely that a cruise ship terminal should be built in crown parkland in one of the last remaining vegetation areas on the Gold Coast. We reject entirely that a cruise ship terminal should be built for the political convenience of two state Labor MPs and for the political convenience of the Premier, Peter Beattie.

But I will tell you the reason why the state Labor government is insisting that a cruise ship terminal be built on the Spit. The reason is that it is part of a deal that has been done with the developers to redevelop the western side of the Spit. That has been the key behind this decision from the very outset. The reality is that the state Labor government has made an arrangement that the consortium that will build the cruise ship terminal, a loss-making venture, will do so on the basis that they have the opportunity to redevelop the western side of the Broadwater. Some 7Â½ hectares will be redeveloped into hotels, units and residential and commercial buildings because the state Labor government wants the millions of dollars of leasing rental that will flow to it by redeveloping that 7Â½ hectares.

More importantly, the state Labor government also intends to facilitate this dodgy deal to have the sea scouts, the naval cadets and the water police move from their current location on the western side of the Spit and be incorporated into the development that is going to take place in this green area. The state Liberal member for Surfers Paradise, John-Paul Langbroek, and I object to this because we have seen the federal government invest millions of dollars through Green Corps projects and Work for the Dole projects to revegetate the Spit. We object to it because the Beattie state Labor government has neglected public consultation in order to push this deal through. More importantly, we reject this deal because the Beattie Labor government has done this deal without being honest with the people of the Gold Coast. Today is a very bleak day for the residents of Main Beach and Surfers Paradise. It is a day when the Beattie Labor government has compounded its dishonesty, not only over the state health sector but also on this issue. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak on the matter of West Papua. The Australian Labor Party has a long and proud record on human rights, and it is an area of real interest to me as a member of this parliament. That strong stance is set out in considerable detail in the ALP platform, which explicitly states:

quote.para: Labor considers the promotion of universal human rights to be a core foreign policy objective that cannot be traded off against other diplomatic and economic goals.

speech.para: Respect for human rightsâthe dignity and welfare of our fellow humansâis naturally our first and most immediate response to reports of human rights abuses. However, Labor also believes that respect for human rights is an important consideration in international relations. Respect for human rights contributes to domestic peace and stability and economic prosperity. This in turn contributes to the maintenance of international security.

In this regard, I have been greatly concerned, as others have, by reports from church groups and human rights organisations about incidents of police and military brutality in the Indonesian province of West Papua. Most disturbing are the reports of the Indonesian armyâs involvement in the murder of Papuan independence leader Theys Eluay in 2001. In particular, I draw the attention of the House to a report that was submitted to the UN Economic and Social Council on 9 March this year by Franciscans International on behalf of a number of respected and credible church groups, including the Catholic Institute for International Relations, the Protestant Church in Germany, Dominicans for Justice and Peace, and the World Council of Churches. That report noted that human rights abuses, including torture, arbitrary arrest and detention, and displacement, were continuing in Papua.

There is no doubt that during the bad old days of the Suharto government the Papuan people were subjected to gross violations of their human rights. In addition to military brutality and political oppression, the province was neglected by Jakarta, with the Papuans lagging behind the rest of the country by virtually every standard of human developmentâinfant mortality, literacy and life expectancy. The fall of the Suharto government and the subsequent election of President Wahid in 2000 gave rise to real optimism that a new era in Papua would unfold. It is important to acknowledge that there have been some positive developments, including the introduction of a special autonomy law granting Papuans political freedoms and autonomy. But the fact remains that we continue to receive disturbing reports of human rights abuses in Papua. Labor are very concerned about these reports. It is our view that a failure to address ongoing human rights concerns will only serve to undermine Indonesian authority in the province.

Labor are also very disappointed at the failure to fully implement the law, which was passed by the Indonesian parliament in 2002. We have made our concerns clear to the Indonesian government and will continue to do so. The Leader of the Opposition and the shadow foreign minister, Kevin Rudd, took the opportunity provided by the recent visit to Australia by Indonesian President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono to raise their concerns about the human rights situation in West Papua and the failure to implement the special autonomy law. Shadow minister Rudd made it clear when he said:

quote.para: ... when it comes to human rights abuses or allegations of human rights abuses in Papua ... we have an expectation that the government in Jakarta will attend to those matters ... at a thorough level.

speech.para: Still, it is clear from reports recently made public, including Genocide in West Papua?âand the question mark following this title raises legitimate questions about whether it is the right term to use here; we do not think that it isâthat the situation is of concern. That particular report, from the Centre for Conflict and Peace Studies, shows that the situation in West Papua continues to deteriorate and is very serious. Health conditions in some areas are very poor. The fact that special autonomy has not reached grassroots levels means there remain continuing infringements of peopleâs rights. This is serious. So it is essential that this parliament provide encouragement to the Indonesian government to speedily advance those arrangements identified as necessary for the implementation of the special autonomy law.

We have welcomed President Yudhoyonoâs success in negotiating a peace agreement in Aceh. His decision to grasp the opportunity provided in the wake of the tsunami to rebuild not just the bricks and mortar of the province but also civil society is acknowledged. It is now time for similar energies and commitment to be brought to bear for the people of West Papua.

talk.start.para: âI wish to place on record my concern over the comments made by the member for Fowler in this place on 13 September and 8 September this year and 2 December last year. It follows on from comments made earlier in this adjournment debate by the member for Chifley and from a question asked by the member for Casey to the Attorney-General in question time today. As the member for Stirling, I represent in this place a large Jewish community, a community that makes a large contribution to my electorate and to Western Australia as a whole. Indeed, I think the contribution that the community makes is out of proportion to the size of that community, which is not numerically large.

speech.para: I was reminded just this week that they can feel uniquely vulnerable, and as a community they have legitimate security needs. Alsoâand I think quite rightlyâthey are sensitive to any reference to the Holocaust. To come into this chamber and use terms like âconcentration campâ, âghettoâ and âethnic cleansingâ against Israel is enormously insensitive. No matter what your views on the conflict in the Middle Eastâand I am not disputing the right of the member for Fowler to hold a different view to mine on the conflict thereâit is completely inappropriate for her to come into this chamber and to compare the mass extermination of six million people in concentration camps to events that are occurring in the Middle East at the present time. That is why using the language of the Holocaust against Israel causes such hurt to members of the Jewish community in Australia, some of whom actually survived the events she is now using to push a case about Middle Eastern politics. The member for Fowler needs to recognise these concerns in any future comments on this issue and she must apologise for going down this path in the first place.

I well remember her earlier comments in December last year in this place eulogising Yassar Arafatâsomething I believe was very ill-advised given his well-known record as someone who used violence to achieve his political ends. For the parliament of a country that is one of the worldâs oldest democracies to be used to eulogise as a hero someone who ruled as dictator and used violence to achieve his goals, sometimes against his own people, is a very sad occurrence in the history of this place.

I know that the member for Fowler has a particular view about Middle Eastern politics. As I said before, although I do not share this view I respect her right to hold it. But this tolerance does not extend to using this parliament to eulogise people of violence or to deeply offend Australian Jewry by using the language of the Holocaust in a wholly inappropriate way.

While I am addressing this issue, I want to highlight some other comments made by the member for Fowler on 8 September in relation to Islamic fundamentalism. In my electorate of Stirling there is a large Muslim community. I have spent quite a bit of time at the two mosques in my electorate, and I have taken the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and the Attorney-General to meet with community leaders at different times. They have always been very clear with me that they reject Islamic extremism and the terrorism that emanates from that ideology. Sadly, though, the member for Fowler rejects this link and has used the parliament to outline her view that these terrorists are killing Westerners because of Western actions in the Muslim world. Last week she said:

quote.para: ... terrorists do not hate us for what we are; they hate us for what we are doing in their home countries. When we can appreciate that, we will be a lot closer to solving problems in Iraq and reducing the risk of terrorist attacks against Australians. But this cowardly government wants to hide behind another lieâthe lie that Islamic fundamentalism is the root of terrorism.

speech.para: This goes well beyond the ALPâs position on this issue, and I believe that this thinking skates very close to justifying the terroristsâ repulsive actions. It also reflects terrorist propaganda. Islamic fundamentalists are killing Westerners because of who we are, not for any other reason. They despise us for our freedoms, and they despise us for our democracy. The Labor Party as a whole need to face up to this issue. Will they tolerate people within their ranks who believe that somehow Western nations have brought this savage terrorism upon themselves, or will the opposition Leader show some ticker and repudiateâ(Time expired)

speech.para: In the last parliamentary fortnight and particularly in the last parliamentary week we have seen a week of guillotines. We saw the Telstra debate guillotined in this House on Monday. We saw it guillotined again in this House today. We saw it guillotined in an unprecedented fashion in the Senate. These were guillotines on a debate about the sale of the single biggest asset the Australian government owns and is ever likely to ownâa week of guillotines. It seems to me remarkable that, in a week of guillotines, when debate has been gagged in this parliament, somehow the members opposite and particularly the Treasurer have taken to referring to me as Madame Defarge. I think there is a grand irony about that. Those are the lovers of the guillotine over there. They are the ones that have been cackling and laughing as the guillotine has come down on Telstra.

But for sheer, breathtaking, amazing carry-on, we cannot go past the Minister for Health and Ageing this week in his capacity as Leader of the House, who has of course administered the guillotine twice in this place to prevent members speaking but yesterday wasâremarkablyâraising a point of order with you, Mr Speaker, where he said:

quote.para: ... it would be almost an obscenity in a parliament dedicated to free speech if people were able to use personal explanations to gag debate in this place.

speech.para: The minister for health is the lover of debate on some occasions and the hater of debate on others. His views about free speech have to be seen as grandly inconsistent, because he was happy to guillotine opposition members this week, and guillotine them he did.

The minister for health has certainly won the lack of consistency award, and he has also won the lack of taste and empathy award for the fortnight. In fact, his performance has gone from bad to worse. He started the week with parliamentary scandal about callous and insensitive remarks he made in relation to the matter involving Mr Brogden, and of course he has managed to end the week reinforcing his insensitivity. Nye Bevanâone of my Welsh forebearsâfamously said, as his career progressed: âReal power always seemed to lie just beyond my reach.â I think for the minister for health it is respect that always seems to lie just beyond his reach, and he has certainly fallen very short of that benchmark today.

What have we seen this fortnight? We have seen the once great National Party starting to emit a death rattle. We have seen the National Party at its worstâwith the notable exception of the member for Riverinaâas it sold out its constituency. With respect to the National Party, I think Alan Ramsey got it right a month ago when he interviewed a person he described as âone of the Prime Ministerâs junior colleaguesâ and as âa very jacked-off Liberalâ. That Liberal had the following things to say about the National Party. Mr Speaker, I am sorry about the language, but I am quoting:

quote.para: The Nats are scum. They take everything and give nothing. They get elected on our coat-tails, theyâve got the worst ministers in the Government, they get the perks, the extra staff, the trips, the Prime Ministerâs ear, yet they never contribute. Itâs always about take, about self-interest. Theyâre never part of the team.
â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦
Did you see Cobbâs performance in question time today? He was hopeless. Just so bad. Is it any wonder Liberals are so resentful?

speech.para: And it goes on and on, ending up describing National Party members in the following terms:

quote.para: John Anderson was hopeless. Vaile isnât much better. Cobb is an embarrassment. So is Truss, the new deputy leader. An absolute embarrassment. McGauran is a laughing stock. So why is there resentment from the Liberals? I mean, does one need to ask the question?

speech.para: You do not need to ask the question, because we have seen the National Party on display this week, famously without a backbone, except for the member for Riverina, and we certainly know that Senator Barnaby Joyce is still looking for his. In the parliamentary fortnight we have also seen, Sliding Doors style, a glimpse of what would happen with the alternative government. We have seen the Prime Minister away one week, we have seen the Treasurer away another week, and we would have to say that it has not been a pretty sight.

speech.para: David Hopkins did bombardment in the Pacific, from the Battle of the Coral Sea to the Philippines. He lost a lot of mates during the Philippines campaign and said that you do not know the feeling until you lose a mate. He read about a prisoner of war on the Burma railway, about his mate, and that was the poem I just read.

The reason why I read that is that there was a kerfuffle recently about whether the word âmateâ should be used by attendants. Of course it should be. It is part of our lexicon; it is part of our Australian history. It is something we should be proud of. The diggers are the greatest personification of mates. Many mates were lost during the war; people lost their lives protecting their mates. So I thought it was appropriate to read what David Hopkins had to say. It might be a message to those of the politically correct class to leave the word âmateâ alone. It is best used in as many circumstances as it can be. I commend to the House the poem that David Hopkins read out.

talk.start.para: âThat was a very good contribution by the member for Banks, Mr Deputy Speaker. It was not long ago that my electorate of Hinkler languished near the bottom of the national bulk-billing rate, but that trend has been reversed in the past year or soânot only have Hinklerâs bulk-billing rates steadily improved but we are now one of the best performing electorates in the nation. The latest bulk-billing figures, covering the 12 months from June 2003-04 to June 2004-05, show a dramatic increase from 52.6 to 66.8âin other words, two-thirds of all people in my electorate can now be bulk-billed. It was the biggest percentage increase of any Queensland electorate and more than double the state average of 6.1. We have beaten many urban seats in lifting our bulk-billing services, and even though we are still slightly behind the state average, we are forging ahead in giving people access to bulk-billing services. This has been a steady trend over time. The electorateâs bulk-billing rates went from 47.7 to 60.5 between the December quarters of 2003 and 2004. It grew again in the next six months to reach a bulk-billing rate of 66.8 in the June quarter of this year.

speech.para: I have worked hard to make sure that Hinkler gets a fair share of doctors. This has been helped enormously by the coalitionâs bulk-billing incentive payments and my concentration on areas of work force need. The new structure for GPs, which gives doctors an extra $5.10 or $7.65 for servicing concession card holders and children under 16, has been a real incentive. The consequence of this policy has been that people have more choice and opportunity to bulk-bill. In turn it has contributed to Australiaâs bulk-billing rate reaching almost 75 per cent. In fact, in the last quarterly figures two new records were set: firstly, the bulk-billing rate is now 69 per cent in country areas, which our political opponents said would never happen, and, secondly, 81.8 per cent of children are now bulk-billed. That is interesting, isnât it? Five out of every six kids are now bulk-billed.

talk.start.para: âNot in Shortland!

âThen you need to work on it, because the local member has a lot to do with it. These outstanding results fly in the face of the gloom and doom that was predicted by Labor about bulk-billing. In fact, all Labor and Independent held seats in QueenslandâCapricornia, Brisbane, Rankin, Oxley, Griffith, Lilley and Kennedyâhave experienced increases in their bulk-billing rates. I think it is a very important issue and something we should keep under review, giving Australians a choice of bulk-billing and other services.

âAustralia has a new barbecue stopper. All around Australia people are talking about the rising price of fuel and the impact this is having on their way of life. Everybody has a view as to what should be done about it. People say things like, âCut taxes,â âImprove public transportâ and âPut more investment in alternative fuel sources.â These are just a few of the suggestions doing the rounds at the moment, but the Prime Ministerâs ostrich plan is the most astonishing response to the issue to date. His idea to bury his head in the sand and do absolutely nothing about the price of fuel defies belief. I am sure the so-called battlers who are out there in the suburbs are not making whoopee this morning at the news that the PM plans to do nothing. Astonishing as it sounds, this demonstrates just how out of touch the government have become. It demonstrates that they are more interested in pursuing their radical and extreme ideological agendas than in doing anything meaningful and constructive to improve the lives of those who at the last election placed their trust and confidence in the Prime Minister to lead this nation. Instead, all he has done is lead them down the garden path.

speech.para: For the Prime Minister to suggest that he can do nothing to help the lives of ordinary Australians is an insult to the electorateâs intelligence. There is a lot the Prime Minister can do, and the vital first step is to conjure up the courage to confront the problemâto acknowledge it, not to wash your hands of the issue. Labor and Kim Beazley put the Prime Minister on notice over petrol prices in June and put forward a plan to tackle the issue, including such things as applying the competition blowtorch to the industry by strengthening the Trade Practices Act to prevent abuse of market power; having the ACCC investigate petrol prices and report every six months on price movements, particularly in regional Australia; modernising the 25-year-old regulatory regime for the petrol sector to promote competition and protect independent service station operators and franchisees; reducing our reliance on imported oil; growing an Australian fuel industry; and providing a real future for the biofuels industry by providing a government fleet market for ethanol blends to set an example and help grow the industry.

These are just a few of the positive steps that the government could be taking. The Prime Minister could reduce the pressure on families, could take positive steps forward to do something. It would certainly be better than saying and doing nothing and blaming everybody else. When will the Prime Minister wake up? Australian motorists see the significant price fluctuations week to week and cannot figure out why or how it works. We see wild variations in prices from suburb to suburb that have no reason or commonsense. Everybody understands this. Even the ACCC chairman has acknowledged that something funny is going on. John Howard and the government have had nine long years to come up with a plan to address petrol prices and they have done nothing.

There is also the issue of the condition of our roads and national highways and the impact that has on our vehicles and the use of fuel, and the issue of public transport. There are a whole range of ways that we can address the ongoing crisis of petrol prices in Australiaâsomething that is not going to go away and that sooner or later the government has to take head on. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI am pleased to rise today to celebrate the function that I had in commemoration of Victory in the Pacific Day on 15 August. I was fortunate to have the opportunity to host a function at the newly built Gold Coast Convention and Exhibition Centre. More than 300 people in my electorate attended the two-hour ceremony, during which I had the opportunity to present commemorative medallions to more than 60 World War II veterans, both men and women, to mark the 60th anniversary of Victory in the Pacific Day. That day, 15 August 1945, was a defining moment in history; it was the day that Japan surrendered to allied forces, ending World War II, which had raged for almost six years. Some 60 years later, on 15 August 2005, it was indeed my great honour and pleasure to join Australian service men and women in celebrating this very significant anniversary.

speech.para: Army, Navy and Air Force cadets ably assisted on the day, and they came from TS Southport, the 222 Squadron and the TSS School Army Cadet Unit, who opened the function with an excellent drill routine and paid their respects to the veterans assembled on the day. This was followed by the Australian national anthem, performed by the Gold Coast brass band. I must pay special tribute to those who fought in World War II and to the acknowledgment of and connection to todayâs military that came from the presence of Lieutenant Colonel Iain Cruickshank, who travelled to the Gold Coast from Brisbane to be the keynote speaker on the day. Lieutenant Colonel Cruickshank, as guest speaker, made an outstanding contribution, assessing then and now the differences between the Army as it had been traditionally and the Army as it is today. Lieutenant Colonel Cruickshank has recently returned from the Middle East, where he was the commanding officer of the 1st Australian Army Training Team in Iraq. He has also seen operational service in South-East Asia, Lebanon and East Timor. He was awarded the Conspicuous Service Cross for the role he played in the SO1 operations during the evacuations of the Solomon Islands in 2000. It was a delight to see the faces of veterans and their families light up during the speech by Lieutenant Colonel Cruickshank as he compared the then and now. It was indeed an excellent moment.

It is amazing to consider how far weapons have come over the years and the level of training that is now available to those in the defence forces. It makes what I do worth while just to go that extra mile to say thank you to the ex-service men and women and to have provided this function as a small way to remember the great sacrifices that were made. We can certainly never repay our veterans. I would like to particularly thank all those veterans and their families who came along. I thank the Department of Veteransâ Affairs and I also acknowledge John-Paul Langbroek, the state Liberal member for Surfers Paradise, who was master of ceremonies. The men and women from the generation of World War II paid the ultimate sacrifice in many respects, and to those assembled on the day I think it is important that we say thank you.

talk.start.para: âCrime and community safety is a big concern at the local level, and elderly people in particular tell me that they are tired of feeling afraid. We all have the right to feel safe in our homes and to walk through our streets and suburbs without fear. Quality policing is one obvious solution, but more can be done to prevent crime and make communities safer. Some of the most effective strategies can be implemented by local governments. Good urban planning and quick response times to graffiti can make a community feel much safer.

speech.para: In the city of Gosnells, in Western Australia, the Safe City Initiative has led to the creation of a series of community safety strategies. The cornerstone of these strategies is the Safe City Urban Design Strategy. Research showed that some perceptions about what were safe areas and what were dangerous areas within a city were not borne out in statistics. People often feel that quiet streets are nice and safe, but areas that are active are safer because of what is called ânatural surveillanceââthat is, the fact that neighbours look out for one another and that, if you go for a walk at night, you know that you will pass other people on the street and you will feel more safe. From these statistics, it has become clear that the challenge is to create an environment in which people feel okay about wandering outside. Level pavements, decent street lighting and open spaces and parks in which people can congregate become more important, not just because these things help to create a better sense of community but also because they help to reduce criminal activity.

As well as fostering significant improvements in urban planning approaches, the initiative has implemented a Safer Seniors program to help elderly residents develop personal safety strategies and to increase their awareness about safety. Likewise, a safety strategy for people with disabilities is being developed. There is a âDob in a Hoonâ campaign to help police apprehend speeding and unsafe drivers, which has also been implemented in South Australia. As well, there is a full-time team of graffiti busters who remove graffiti within 24 hours of being advised it is there. There is research that suggests that such prompt removal is a disincentive to so-called graffiti artists. The main reason for their tagging is so that their peers can see what they have done, so a quick response takes the thrill out of it.

As a result, there have been decreases in recorded crime: residential burglary down by seven per cent, property damage down by 12 per cent and drug offences down by 15 per cent. So the city of Gosnells is a great success story. I can think of several councils in the electorate of Hindmarsh which would be delighted to implement a similar project. Unfortunately, that is where the federal government comes in. Funding to local government in total has dropped substantially as a proportion of Commonwealth taxation revenue. As the city of Gosnells has demonstrated, a huge difference can be made to crime rates by local councils through urban planning, but local government cannot make changes on their own. Support from the federal government is essential if such a program is to be implemented by councils around the country. We need to assist our communities to feel safer, to create better communities where people do not feel afraid to leave their homes. This can only be done with the assistance of local government, state government and federal government. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise today to speak in support of people who suffer from diabetes, a serious disease in Australia. Diabetes is a chronic disease, characterised by high blood glucose levels resulting from the body not producing insulin or not using it properly. There are two main types of diabetes. The particular one I want to talk about today, type 1, requires consistent daily treatment. Onset usually occurs in childhood or young adulthood, although it can occur at any stage. The symptoms usually appear abruptly and include excessive thirst and urination, unexplained weight loss, weakness, fatigue and irritability. Diabetes is Australiaâs fastest growing chronic disease and is the seventh highest cause of death in Australia. It has some extreme complicationsâfor example, 3,000 amputations for people with diabetes, most of which were preventable. Some 520,000 Australians have been diagnosed with diabetes but it is estimated that for every person diagnosed there is another person who has it but is unaware. This would mean there are well over one million Australians with diabetes, with some 80,000 South Australians known to have diabetes.

speech.para: Treatment is needed to prevent some of the bad health outcomes for people who have diabetes. Treatment is a lifelong course of insulin injectionsâevery dayâregular blood glucose level tests, healthy eating and regular physical activity. The injections and tests require a large commitment by sufferers to ensure they access the appropriate kits and the supplies they need. Where those supplies are not commonly available, it takes a large commitment to get them. If we are committed to the health care of people in Australia, we need to make sure that kits are available in appropriately located areas. In the electorate of Wakefield, north of Adelaide, a large number of people suffer from diabetesâfrom Gawler through to the edge of the Barossa Valley, in the Clare Valley, the mid-north in Virginia and Two Wells. Many people use the township of Gawler as a regional services hub. There is sufficient demand there to justify the establishment of an additional diabetes product supply outlet to service people in the outer metropolitan area and the country areas to the north of Adelaide.

I have written to the management of Diabetes SA expressing my support for a subagency in Gawler. I am pleased this week to have tabled in the parliament of Australia a petition in support of a Gawler outlet signed by 2,861 people in the electorate of Wakefield. I call upon Diabetes SA to make a priority locating an outlet in the town of Gawler to serve these people.

talk.start.para: âThe Howard governmentâs legislation which seeks to ban the collection of universal student services and amenities fees has galvanised the opposition, which comes from a vast majority of the higher education community and the general public. Students themselves have expressed their strong opposition to this legislation. In their thousands they have demanded that they be permitted to continue to financially support the provision of vital services: counselling, health and welfare, representation and advocacy, sport and recreation, employment, legal assistance, child-care places, clubs and societies, and so the list goes on. Everyone from vice-chancellors, regional communities, business leaders, sporting and arts communities and, of course, members of the coalitionâs backbench want Mr Howard to drop his extreme attack on student services.

speech.para: Students at the St Patrick campus of the Australian Catholic University decided to test the opinions of their fellow students on this extreme anti student services legislation. A petition was circulated to students and the completed petition was sent to me to table in the House. Unfortunately, the petition does not conform to the required format, so I wanted to take the opportunity to draw attention to it today and to congratulate the students for their efforts. This is a relatively small campus but 900 students signed a petition which contained the request that the government and/or the Senate categorically reject all anti student organisation legislation. The students pointed out:

quote.para: ... this legislation is not necessary and will significantly detract from the quality of university life. At our own universityâ

speech.para: the Australian Catholic Universityâ

quote.para: we take great pride in providing a caring and supported educational environment.

speech.para: The petitioners further stressed that these features would âdisappear if you allow this legislation to be ratifiedâ. But the Minister for Education, Science and Training, Brendan Nelson, and the Howard government have been totally deaf to the determined and united pleas from the higher education sector, and those outside, that this legislation would be extraordinarily damaging to the interests of our universities and our students. The response by the education minister to these pleas has been to remain adamant that he will not budge an inch from the very hardline attitude that he has adopted on this issue. He continues to be uncompromisingly ideological. In the Labor Party we have heard the voices of students and members of the university community. talk.start.para: âOn this historic day when the bill for the sale of Telstra has passed from the Senate back to our House, I am very fortunate to have the opportunity to extend the comments I made on that bill. I referred in my speech to a report from Ericsson on the technologies available, and I would like to expand on that, if I can, in the time allotted to me today. The technology option I was speaking about was dial-up on copper. Dial-up on copper allows 56 kilobits per second, at best, if within two to four kilometres of the exchange. But often this is much less in rural areas, so you get something like 2.4 kilobits per second on long lines or lines with pair gains. This type of technology is sensitive to interference from electronic fences et cetera. It is basically used for low-speed internet only.

speech.para: Satellite technology shares approximately 40 megabits per second across all national users. Satellite technology has capacity problems. It is incredibly expensive. You have to put the pieces in place and get a bandwidthâand you pay for that. The fewer customers you have, the more expensive it is. Also, the more users you have, the more downgrading you get in capacity. It provides up to 800 kilobits per second to the subscriber and up to 128 kilobits per second from the subscriber. It is basically for fast internet use only. Satellite technology has some high latency in telephony because, let us face it, it has to go fair up into the sky and back again. Those latency issues are not going to be removed, and it is expensive even though subsidised for remote and some rural services.

The WiMax 802 or wireless technology shares approximately 50 to 75 megabits across a cell of seven to eight kilometres, which is one to two megabits per second per subscriber. It can be used for fast internet only and not for large-scale telephony. No large-scale video is possible. It is equivalent in cost and price to ADSL. The mobile wireless or 2G networks on the GSM network provide seven megabits per second and use a PC card. They will be coming out next year. They provide high-speed internet connection, and some video applications are available. It is very expensive due to the mobile-centric nature of that technology.

The same applies to the 3G networks. This is scheduled for release in 2015 or after. It has the potential to deliver up 100 megabits per second, which is where I think we want to be, but that will be available after 2015. Sharing is necessary. The prime application is for mobility and it is very expensive for fixed line operations. Regarding ADSL on copper, at three kilometres from the exchange you can get approximately six megabits to the subscriber and 1.3 from the subscriber. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI am gravely concerned about the future of those Australians currently receiving welfare payments under this governmentâs extreme agenda. Surprisingly, in this case I am not referring to the bungled attempt to implement the Welfare to Work program that is more aptly described as the welfare to lower welfare program. I am concerned about the impact that the governmentâs industrial relations agenda may have on pensioners. Some members may wonder why I would be concerned for the future income security of the most vulnerable in our society when considered through the prism of the industrial relations changes. They may wonder what impact slashing wages and working conditions will have on people receiving age, single parent, disability support, war widows and service pensions.

speech.para: Those among us who are not so out of touch with our constituents will know exactly how the governmentâs industrial relations obsession may well affect pensioners. Many pensions and other social security payments are benchmarked to 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings. This means that movements in the wages of working Australians flow on to pensions. This, of course, means that the wage impact of the industrial relations changes will also flow on to pensioners. Government members opposite may scoff at this suggestion and claim that it could not possibly be the case, but they would be wrong on this occasion. Over recent years Australian pension recipients have experienced increases in their pensions at rates higher than the growth of inflation because of real wage growth. Sadly, it is not to the full extent of the much claimed but largely unproven 14 per cent increase that the Prime Minister crows aboutâbut, then again, very few of us have experienced such growth.

Future increases in payments to 40,000 pensioners in the south-west of Sydney are at risk because of the governmentâs extreme industrial relations agenda. More than 22,000 of those live in my electorate. I know this government cares little about the plight of Australian workers and Australian families, but I would have thought it would be willing to leave the poor and the elderly alone. The governmentâs extreme, unnecessary and unfair industrial relations agenda has managed to produce another set of victims. It is not enough that the government has unionists, building and construction workers and university staff in its sights; now, in a nasty side effect of its so-called reforms, those least able to afford it will also face real cuts to their incomes. While elderly and retired Australians are concerned for the working conditions of their children and grandchildren, they should now start worrying about their own financial futures. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise today with a hint of sadness and regret. After I left my home the other morning to drive to Wonthaggi to meet the Leongatha pea growers, I proceeded along the South Gippsland Highway to an area where my family have recreated for nearly all of our generations, on the beaches and surrounds of South Gippsland. This is the most pristine area of the state, where it has always been my great pleasure to drive out of the turn at Anderson on the way to Phillip Island and be gobsmacked and breathless at the vista that stretches towards Cape Paterson and Wonthaggi and down into South Gippsland.

speech.para: But the other morning my heart was broken and dulled when I went over the rise in the car and there before me was that magnificent vista and smack in the middle of it were seven ugly, criminal wind turbines. They have destroyed that vista of coastline for at least the next 25 years. These seven unproductive wind turbines were put right on the coast by the vandalism of the Bracks government. They have stolen this pristine area of Gippsland, raping the landscape and denying generations of the future the beauty and benefit that I have had. The Bracks government have vandalised the South Gippsland coast, and I will do everything in my power to stop any further wind turbines going into that area of South Gippsland.

talk.start.para: (Hon. IR Causley)âOrder! In accordance with standing order 193 the time for membersâ statements has concluded.
âI move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: The purpose of the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2005 is to make a number of minor amendments to four pieces of Defence portfolio legislation: the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982, the Military Superannuation and Benefits Act 1991, the Defence Act 1903 and the Naval Defence Act 1910.

The Defence Force Discipline Act 1982, the DFDA, is amended to redefine which laws form âterritory offencesâ under that act as a result of changes in the criminal law of the Australian Capital Territory. These amendments are considered essential to ensure that this act continues to reflect the range of offences originally intended for its operation. The scope of these offences has been severely limited in recent times by changes to the laws that are referred to in the act.

The DFDA imports civil criminal offences into that act as service offences in order to extend the ambit of the act to circumstances that might otherwise not be prosecuted and to give greater efficacy to disciplinary law. The mechanism currently used to achieve this is the incorporation of the laws of the Commonwealth, the ACT Crimes Act 1900 and the ACT Police Offences Act 1930 as they apply in the Jervis Bay Territory.

Since the introduction of the territory offence provisions, changes have occurred to the incorporated legislation such that some updating of the DFDA is essential. Most concerning is that the ACT in 2001 and 2002 enacted Criminal Code legislation based on the Commonwealth Model Criminal Code, and since 2002 it has repealed numerous offences from its Crimes Act in favour of the Criminal Code. The net effect of this is that offences such as computer theft, arson and blackmail can no longer be prosecuted by the Australian Defence Force under the DFDA. Furthermore, it is anticipated that offences such as murder, manslaughter and assault will also move to the Criminal Code by the end of 2005. Also of concern is the fact that the Police Offences Act was repealed in 1996, and references to it are therefore ineffective. The proposed bill will remove redundant legislation references and refer instead to the criminal law in force in the Jervis Bay Territory from time to time.

The Military Superannuation and Benefits Act 1991, known as the benefits act, is to be amended to repeal part 8 so as to remove the retention benefit currently available for certain Australian Defence Force members of the benefits scheme.Â

Part 8 of the benefits act currently provides a bonus of one yearâs salary to eligible members of the Military Superannuation and Benefits Scheme who, on reaching 15 years of continuous effective service, agree to complete a further five years service. The Review of Australian Defence Force Remuneration 2001, the Nunn review, considered that issues of attraction to, and retention in, the services would be better suited for determination by the Navy, Army and Air Force service chiefs based on priority needs and linked to capability. An automatic retention bonus rigidly tied up to a number of years of service, at a fixed rate, is no longer regarded as appropriate.

Despite the repeal of part 8 of the benefits act, it is proposed that access to the retention benefit would continue for current members for as long as they remain eligible but would not be available to new members joining the ADF after the date of the commencement of the proposed amendments.

These amendments are required to ensure that ADF pay arrangements provide an effective, efficient and flexible remuneration framework that is consistent with reforms in the wider public and private sectors.

Thirdly, the Defence Act 1903 is amended to change references from âinvestigating officersâ to âinquiry officersâ to make it clear that these officers are conducting purely administrative rather than criminal investigations. This amendment is an administrative amendment that is required to improve administration of military justice.

The term âinvestigating officerâ appears in both the Defence Act and the DFDA, but has different meanings in each act. The role of an investigating officer as referred to in the Defence Act is to conduct an administrative inquiry into matters affecting the ADF. However, some ADF members believe that officers are conducting criminal investigations because of the use of the words âinvestigating officersâ. To remove this confusion, it is considered appropriate to change references in the Defence Act from âinvestigating officersâ to âinquiry officersâ to make it clear that these officers are conducting purely administrative investigations.

The fourth act to be amended by this bill, the Naval Defence Act 1910, is amended to align the legislation governing eligible ages of Navy cadets with the legislation governing their Army and Air Force counterparts. The alignment of the various laws dealing with ADF cadets to provide more consistency between the respective services is long overdue. The amendment to the Naval Defence Act will provide a uniform maximum entry age of 20 years for acceptance into the ADF cadets and will provide for a person to cease being a cadet at the age of 21 years or such lower age as is prescribed under the regulations.

Finally, this bill also contains provisions amending various Defence administrative legislation resulting from the commencement of the Legislative Instruments Act 2003 and the Legislative Instruments (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Act 2003. These are technical housekeeping amendments to remove redundant references to the Statutory Rules Publication Act 1903 and repealed provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act 1900. These amendments do not in any way affect the operation of the Defence legislation referred to in the bill. I present the explanatory memorandum to the bill.

talk.start.para: âThe opposition supports the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2005. The bill makes a number of amendments to Defence legislation, principally dealing with personnel matters, as outlined by the Minister for Veteransâ Affairs. I will not detail the key amendments, but I will note them for the purpose of argument. First, an amendment is proposed to the Defence Force Discipline Act to update its provisions for the inclusion of amendments to the ACT Criminal Code. Second, an amendment is proposed to bring the age limits of Naval cadets, as set out in the Naval Defence Act, into line with those for the Army and the Air Force. Third, it makes some minor technical changes to the terminology of investigating officers and to references to remove some redundant provisions in respect of legislative instruments legislation. Fourth, it removes the current superannuation retention bonus for those who opt to sign up for another five years after 15 years of service. In large part, these are relatively non-controversial matters, but they have implications for current policy, and that is the issue that I will focus on primarily. The policies most relevant are those concerning military justice, recruitment and retention. Today I want to make some detailed references to those issues.

speech.para: The first amendment, for all intents and purposes, is simply intended to keep the Defence Force Discipline Act up to date. Because the act imports provisions from the ACT Criminal Code for disciplinary purposes, it obviously must be updated in the light of those changes to that Criminal Code. At present, it is clear that it has fallen behind and has been inadequate in many respects. To the extent that this amendment brings the Defence Force Discipline Act into line and makes it consistent, we support the amendment. However, we believe there is an important point to make. To some extent, the amendment assumes that the status quo, with respect to the Defence Force Discipline Act, will remain unchangedâthat is, that breaches of defence discipline and criminal law will continue to be both investigated and prosecuted by ADF authorities.

However, the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee, in its report on military justiceâwhich was delivered approximately three months agoâstrongly recommended that this arrangement be changed. The committee recommended that, other than at times during deployment, all responsibility for breaches of civilian and criminal law within Australia be investigated and prosecuted by civilian police, not by defence police. However, we recognise that the incorporation of the Criminal Code of the ACT into the Defence Force Discipline Act for disciplinary purposes overseas is necessary. In those cases, these provisions of the Criminal Code become the main authority for prosecuting offences. If the government accepts the recommendation of the Senate committee, however, there may be implications for the way in which the Defence Force Discipline Act provides for non-defence criminal offences. But, until the government responds to the committeeâs recommendations, we will not know whether those changes will be necessary. In those cases, the incorporation of the provisions of the ACT Criminal Code will, nonetheless, be important. To that extent, we regard this amendment as a housekeeping matter and necessary for the status quo. But it may, as we repeat, require fresh examination after the government announces its response to the Senate committee report.

While on this subject, we believe it is worth reiterating some of the committeeâs recommendations. The committee recommended that the management of defence disciplinary matters be separated from the investigation and prosecution of criminal matters. Essentially, it is an issue of expertise and efficiency. One of the greatest criticisms made in the committeeâs reportâwhich was a bipartisan reportâwas the poor standard of investigation of criminal offences by defence authorities. This was seen as a matter resulting from low levels of skill and expertise in terms of the qualifications and experience of those people entrusted with the responsibility.

The committee considered that, given the low frequency of such offences, it was difficult to develop and retain the requisite investigatory skills within the Australian Defence Force. In a world of rapidly-increasing specialisation and outsourcing, where appropriate, to centres of excellence, the committee was of the view that a better job could be done by civil police. That, by the way, is not proposed to absolve ADF members from defence discipline in any way. It simply seeks to bring greater expertise and efficiency to the process. It seeks to have defence disciplinary management confined to breaches of defence discipline which are most relevant on a daily basis to the activities of the Defence Force.

That was the unanimous view of the committee. It is a clear separation of function and in effect is no different to the operation of any other part of civil law affecting ADF personnel as private citizens in terms of any laws they may breach when not on active duty. If eventually the commission of a crime is proven, then of course Defence has a clear prerogative to consider that offence and behaviour in the light of its own standards, as may be reflected in internal defence disciplinary measures, but that is a separate issue to the enforcement of criminal law. We certainly hope that the government gives this recommendation very careful consideration. Should it agree with the committee, then of course we will need to re-examine the relevance of this particular amendment that we are dealing with today.

Turning to the second amendment, consistency of age provisions for cadets across Army, Navy and Air Force is sensible. That is practical housekeeping. I do want to mention a related matter, however, that was also referred to by the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee in its report on military justice. It concerns the duty of care owed to cadets, many of whom are minors and are away from their homes in circumstances where cadet instructors and staff, we would expect, have special responsibilities. The particular case highlighted by the committee was the tragic suicide of Air Cadet Eleanore Tibble. But for the failure of proper process, she might still be alive today. The saddest things about this case are the well-worn causes of inadequate guidelines and instruction manuals, lack of familiarity, poor training and inadequate codes of conduct. Too often the response made to those shortcomings is that the procedures have been reviewed and rewritten. Too often the bureaucratic response is to close the file in the hope and, in some cases, expectation that the issue will simply fade away.

We see that response can have tragic consequences. At the heart of these matters there is only one issue: the fulfilment of a duty of care, particularly to those who are younger and less experienced in both life skills and military skills. It is about the duty of care to everyone, not just cadets. If they are minors, the duty of care is even more onerous and hence the committeeâs great concern, as noted in its report. Remedying these concerns cannot simply be achieved by introducing manuals and processes. Real changes come from driving a change in attitude and culture within the Defence Force. I note that there are determined efforts within the Defence Force itself, but again they have to be reflected in appropriate legislative or structural change which fairly and squarely brings the responsibility to the desk of the relevant government ministers entrusted with that responsibility.

In 2004 alarming levels of soldier dissatisfaction were detailed in the Defence attitude survey. These concerns cannot be ignored. This specially prepared study demonstrated that almost one in three military personnel, as surveyed, wanted to quit; more than half of the soldiers asked said that the Army suffers from inadequate resources; and well over two-thirds of ADF personnel felt military values and standards had declined. I therefore urge the government to respond in full to the committeeâs recommendations for the institution of better processes for added resources and to drive a cultural change. Until the special duty of care for minors, in particular, is fully heeded and the culture of care is properly instilled, more tragedies like that involving Eleanore Tibble are inevitable.

Finally, I wish to address other key amendments concerning the retention bonus. This bonus was introduced in 1991. It provided for one yearâs salary to those members of the ADF who switched to the MSBS and who, after 15 years service, opted for a further five years. It was only available to medically fit officers above the rank of major and for other ranks above the rank of sergeant. It was initiated at the time that the DFRDB superannuation scheme was terminated. It was provided only to those who transferred to the new scheme. The point was to encourage longer serving experienced personnel to stay on and resist the temptation to leave for financial reasons. The DFRDB scheme, with its pension and part commutation to a lump sum, was an attractive option in those circumstances. The DFRDB had an immediate pension entitlement after 20 years of service, with an option of commutation of part of that to a lump sum. The bonus then was conditional on transferring to the MSBS. As such, it must be honoured for the small number who remain in service and have not yet exercised their option. To remove it would be unfair, and we agree with the approach taken by the government. That is why this amendment, in effect, grandfathers the bonus for all personnel currently serving, which we recognise is appropriate. It is therefore not to become redundant for some time to come.

The review of Australian Defence Force remuneration in 2001 by the Nunn inquiry considered this bonus in some detail. Nunn noted that there were several problems with the bonus. Firstly, during downsizing exercises retention bonuses encouraging people to stay for five years contradicted offers of redundancy. Some who re-signed got the bonus and were then offered a redundancy package; others were not made an offer because they have been paid the retention bonus. Additionally, retention policy began to focus on keeping particular skills rather than on general application. The bonus contradicted that policy as well. For those who undertook a return of service obligation this was not served concurrently but rather at the end of the five-year retention period. Naturally, all this produced friction, inconsistency and great dissatisfaction. More importantly, it interfered with targeted retention and the flexible management of skillâthe latter varying widely across services. The one-size-fits-all approach in the MSBS retention bonus proved to be quite counterproductive to those measures which I have outlined, though we recognise it did perhaps have a legitimate purpose at its heart.

This brings me to the policy on the issue of retention more generally. The particular provisions, though historical, have proven problematic for the reasons I have outlined but this is not to say that in the future retention bonuses might not be relevant as a tool in retaining skills. Having serving full-time personnel, on leaving the service, enlisting with the reserves is also something that legitimately requires consideration. Perhaps bonuses could be more related to the labour market circumstances of the time and not treated as an ongoing condition of service. Clearly, greater flexibility is required and we therefore support the amendment. But at the same time we encourage continued attention to employment and retention incentives where there are serious shortfalls which affect the effectiveness of the ADF.

This is not a new problemârecruitment and retention really are the sleeping giants of the defence forcesâ âfuture issues to confrontâ, and indeed to our ability to keep our technological and skills advantage as a regional power. This has been acknowledged not only by the opposition but by members of Defence and several independent sources. On 11 March this year the immediate past Chief of the Defence Force, General Peter Cosgrove, acknowledged the extent of the skills crisis in the ADF when he told a parliamentary committee: âI think we share Australiaâs issue with people getting into trades; we have to get them in the door.â General Cosgrove tabled a document at the hearing that listed several key areas where Defence was particularly deficient. These included engineers, surveyors and tradesmen among others.

The skills crisis in Australia is not only an important economic issue under this governmentâs watch; it has becomeâis increasingly becomingâa serious national security issue. Independent experts have also highlighted the extent of the problem. In their cost of defence post budget report for 2005, the Australian Strategic Policy Institute said, âDespite spending $500 million over five years on initiatives to improve the recruitment and retention of military personnel, the process of building up the size of the ADF has stalled.â Defence cannot recruit as many people as they needâless than 85 per cent of their recruitment targets have been reached in the last six years. In a nutshell, the government has to make careers in the ADF more attractive.

I note that the minister, who spoke previously in the Main Committee, has been undertaking some work on this. All we can say is that we have to have an open mind on those measures which will achieve that outcome. Certainly on this side of the chamber we are prepared to support practical measures that support the recruitment and retention of Australians. We believe our Australian Defence Force should be made up of Australians and not foreign soldiers. However, we are sceptical of bandaid fixes and measures which fail to address intrinsic problems. We particularly want the terrible image of the failed military justice system to be fixed. We think that is fundamental to recruitment, not only from the point of view of the desire of competent young people to enter the defence forces but also, quite clearly, to the preparedness of their families to encourage them into what otherwise can be a very satisfying, fulfilling and obviously worthwhile career. Until the government addresses these problems young people will think twice, as will their parents, about a career in the military.

The minister has promised to respond to the committeeâs report by 16 September. We very much look forward to a positive response accepting all the committeeâs recommendations. We believe this is fundamentally a test of leadership at government level. It is also a real test of how serious the government is about having the ADF turn over a new leaf and get serious about its people and the role it can play not only in protecting the nation but as an instrument for developing the young people of Australia. We fully support the bill.

talk.start.para: âThe purpose of the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2005 is to make some minor amendments to four pieces of Defence portfolio legislation. Before speaking about these minor amendments, I would like to take the opportunity to recognise the contribution made to our country by our Defence Force personnelâboth those who have served and those who are still serving. I have the honour of representing many ex-service men and women in my electorate of Fairfax, and I am proud of the way that many of these men and women continue the tradition of service by working for their community not just through the local RSL clubs but also through a multitude of community organisations.

speech.para: Yes, our defence personnel are there to protect Australia, but they do so much more than that. They have undertaken very dangerous peace-keeping duties in recent years in places like East Timor, the Sudan, Afghanistan, Bougainville and the Solomon Islands. They provide search and rescue missions such as the one a few weeks ago when the RAAF rescued stricken sailors in the Great Australian Bight. They provide emergency relief, within hours, in times of calamity such as the medical evacuations after the Bali bombings and the incredible assistance rendered in Banda Aceh after the tsunami. We currently have around 1,500 Australian Defence Force personnel deployed on operations around the world.

As the Minister for Defence said in his foreword to the booklet Winning in Peace, Winning in War, the rise of terrorism and regional stresses in the last few years has meant that our military forces have had to deal with difficult and complex missions in circumstances and locations previously not considered likely. They are able to mount complex operations, in the face of grave risk, with just a few hours notice. In fighting, in humanitarian assistance and in support of our regional neighbours, the ADF have shown themselves to be a force for good, showing the world the enduring character and spirit of the Australian people.

This bill, as I said at the beginning, makes minor amendments to four pieces of Defence portfolio legislation. The first of these is the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982, or DFDA, which is amended to redefine which laws form âterritory offencesâ under the act. These amendments are necessary because of changes to the criminal law of the ACT and the need to ensure that this act continues to reflect the range of offences originally intended for its operation. The Defence Force Discipline Act imports civil criminal offences into that act both to cover circumstances where they might not otherwise be prosecuted and to give greater efficacy to disciplinary law. We are talking here about offences such as computer theft, arson and blackmail. Because of the recent criminal law changes in the Australian Capital Territory, certain legislative references in the DFDA have become inaccurate. The amendments in this bill will remove those redundant legislation references and refer instead to the criminal law in force in the Jervis Bay territory from time to time. In summary, the amendments do not change offences under the act but only amend references to other legislation in the wording of the act.

The second act to be amended is the Defence Act 1903. The term âinvestigating officersâ appears in both the Defence Act and the Defence Force Discipline Act, but it has different meanings in each act. The amendment in this bill is to change references in the Defence Act from âinvestigating officersâ to âinquiry officersâ, to make it clear that these officers are conducting purely administrative investigations, not criminal investigations. Once again, the amendment does not change the focus or meaning of the act in any way. It simply redefines a term to avoid confusion.

The third schedule of the bill amends the Naval Defence Act 1910 to align the eligible ages of Navy cadets with those already existing for their Army and Air Force counterparts. This means there will be a uniform maximum entry age of 20 years for all cadetsâArmy, Navy and Air Forceâas well as a uniform maximum age when a young person must cease being a cadet. That maximum age will be â21 years or such lower age as is prescribedâ. Cadets is a Defence sponsored, community based organisation currently involving some 25,000 young people and 2,500 volunteer adults throughout Australia. Air Vice Marshal David Dunlop describes it as a youth development program delivered in a military context. In my electorate of Fairfax we are fortunate to have Army cadets at Yandina, Air Force cadets at Nambour and Navy cadets at Cooroy.

The fourth schedule of this bill amends the Military Superannuation and Benefits Act 1991, removing the automatic retention benefit currently available for certain Defence Force personnel. Currently the act provides a bonus of one yearâs salary to eligible members of the Military Superannuation and Benefits Scheme who, after 15 years of service, sign on for a further five years.
