The review of Australian Defence Force remuneration in 2001âthe Nunn reviewâfound that the issue of retention would be much better dealt with by the service chiefs, allowing them the flexibility to base incentives on priority needs and linking them to capability, rather than an automatic retention bonus for all, tied to a particular number of years of service. I stress that this change will not affect existing membersâonly future members. Access to retention benefits will continue for current members for as long as they remain eligible but will not be available to new members joining the ADF after the commencement date of this amendment.

The last schedule of this bill simply contains a number of minor technical amendments relating to legislative references in Defence legislation. These changes were made necessary by technical amendments to acts, such as the Legislative Instruments Act 2003, and do not in any way affect the operation of the subject Defence legislation. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: âAs the member for Barton has already indicated, the opposition support the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2005. However, I think it is important to point out that, while we support the bill, like many sections of the community, including sections of the defence community, we are becoming rather frustrated by the inordinately long period of time being taken by the government before it responds to what is considered to be a very good report of the recent Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee inquiry into the effectiveness of Australiaâs military justice system.

speech.para: In saying that, I also point out that this is not the only report that has come down in the time of the current governmentâindeed there have been a number. I think the Senate report, although probably one of the most far-reaching reports, is one of about seven. For instance, we have had the 2002-03 Western Australian Coronerâs investigation of the HMAS Westralia fire; the 2001 Burchett QC inquiry into military justice in the Australian Defence Force; the 2001 Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade report entitled Rough Justice? An investigation into allegations of brutality in the Armyâs Parachute Battalion; the 1999 Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade military justice procedures in the ADF inquiry; the 1998 Commonwealth Ombudsmanâs own motion investigation into how the ADF responds to allegations of serious incidents and offences; and the 1997 Abadee study into the judicial system under the Defence Force Discipline Act, which Justice Abadee began in 1995. All of these inquiries were outlined in that Senate report.

In my view, this is an important report, one that the government should not be delaying its response to. I understand that these are difficult, complex and complicated issues. Nonetheless, they are important issuesâindeed crucial issuesânot just to the wellbeing of members of the ADF. It is also important that they be addressed so that the mums and dads of Australia who are giving consideration, with their sons and daughters, to a career in the ADF are given some comfort, encouragement and certainty that these crucial issues which the ADF and the government must address are indeed being addressed. I have no doubt that mums and dads do consider these issues before they encourage their children into the ADF. I think that, until these issues are dealt with, we will continue to see problems with recruitment and retention.

We know that these are not the only reasons that there are problems confronting the ADF and its recruitment and retention issues, but they are important ones. Some of the issues that this Senate inquiry referred toâand I intend to go through some of themâwere the inordinate delay in investigations of alleged offences, in some cases investigations having gone on for several years; poor quality investigation of alleged offences such as the inappropriate questioning of civilian family members; failure to check easily obtainable exploratory evidence; failure to liaise closely with civilian agencies; a lack of independence in the investigation of alleged offences; failure to obtain and/or act on Australian Federal Police and DPP advice; a lack of independence in the decision to prosecute; poor quality prosecution of alleged offences; inordinate delay in the decision to prosecute; inordinate delay in the trial process; lack of independence in the trial process; lack of impartiality in the trial process; and inordinate delay in the review of trial processes.

talk.start.para: âI raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. We are dealing with amendments to the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982, and not once has the member referred to the bill. I do understand that he is incorporating the military justice scheme details, but we are here today to debate the bill and I ask that you bring the member back to the matter of the bill.
(Mr Hatton)âI thank the parliamentary secretary and call the member for Cowan.

âIf the member had any knowledge of military justice, if she had any knowledge of the Defence Force Discipline Act, she would know that these matters go to the core of the Defence Force Discipline Act and to the core of this bill. I can understand why the government might be a bit sensitive about these issues. They have had almost nine years to address them, and what do we see? We see a bill which just tinkers at the edges of what is, as I have already described, a difficult, complex and complicated issue which the government must deal with. What I am saying is that the bill does not go far enough. It does not deal with the core issues which were referred toâ

âMr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. With all respect to the member for Cowan, this is a housekeeping bill which deals with some technical aspects on uniformity of age in relation to naval recruits. It deals with civil and criminal definitions of legal offences and it deals with a particular retention issue on reaching 15 years of service. It has nothing to do with military justice.

âMr Deputy Speaker, on the point of order: I point out to you that within the last sentence of the speech by the member for Cowan he referred to the bill three times. Therefore, I contend that he is speaking to the bill and adding depth to the contribution that has been made by other members.

âAfter the first point of order I think the member for Cowan came directly to the point of the bill. The parliamentary secretaryâs view is that his speech is too wide in terms of a housekeeping bill. The member for Cowan canvassed issues, given that it does deal with some criminal justice matters. The precedent in the House, and certainly in the Main Committee, is that where there has been a great deal of debateâas there probably has been on this bill, given the shadow minister has had discussions on a range of defence mattersâwe would generally have a broader debate. If the member for Cowan cast too wide a net in regard to that, you could seek to bring him to order. At the moment I adjudge that he is in order. I am sure he will take into account your admonition. I think he has made a case as to why he is driving for a wider discussion in this debate.

âI thank the chair for its reasoned, balanced and wise ruling. I have just about concluded my speech. The points I wanted to raise in relation to Defence Force discipline are dealt with quite clearly in this bill. Before I move off the subject, I refer to paragraph 21, under the heading âDisciplinary actionââthe matter being dealt with in this billâin the executive summary of the report on the inquiry into the effectiveness of Australiaâs military justice system. Paragraph 21 reads:

quote.para: These submissions and others, described extraordinary delays in the investigation of alleged offences, the failure of investigators to pursue exculpatory evidence, the failure of investigators to disclose relevant material to the accused, the failure of investigators and commanders to advise the accused of allegations at the appropriation time, the failure of investigators and prosecutors (legal officers) to obtain and/or act on specialist advice, the failure of prosecutors (legal officers) to adequately weigh and assess witnesses evidence. The committee is satisfied that these problems did in fact plague some investigationsâthis point admitted to by Defence in key instancesâand the problems are so severe as to constitute systemic failures.

speech.para: The point I am making in relation to this bill is that it does not go far enough. If we have systemic failures in the Defence Force Discipline Act and in its practical application, then we need a response from the government so that this bill can be built on and we can get to the nub, the core, of the issues that need to be dealt with.

The bill also makes some amendment to the proposed age limits of Navy cadets, as set out in the Naval Defence Act, to bring them into line with those for Army and Air Force cadets. I believe that the ADF has a duty of care and, once again, the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee referred to the issue of cadets. I do not intend to go into all of the detail of the particular case that it dealt with, but recommendation 38 of the committeeâs report, which was a bipartisan report, says:

quote.para: To ensure that the further development and implementation of measures designed to improve the care and control and rights of minors in the cadets are consistent with the highest standards, the committee suggests that the ADF commission an expert in the human rights of children to monitor and advise the ADF on its training and education programs dealing with cadets.

speech.para: It may well be that the amendment in the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2005 is the start of the ADF and the government addressing the recommendations in this report and some of the important issues that need to be addressed. But duty of care goes beyond just cadets. Duty of care is owed to every member of the ADF. Until we get the matter of discipline right within the ADF, I think we will continue to have retention and recruitment problems.

Mr Deputy Speaker Hatton, I know that in your capacity as the Deputy Chair of the Defence Subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade you take a great deal of interest in matters dealing with Defence and that you, like me and other members on this side, are a very strong supporter of our young men and women in the ADF. We want to see these matters addressed. We want to see our members of the ADF given proper support and a proper framework within which they can carry out their very crucial and important day-to-day tasking operations both in Australia and overseas. Until we deal with the real issues confronting military justice, we are not doing them justice or giving them the sort of support that a proper, caring and committed government would be giving to our members of the Australian Defence Force. As I said earlier, the opposition support this bill, but we look forward to the very overdue response from the government which addresses the real matters that this bill should be going to.

talk.start.para: âWhilst the member for Cowan has been speaking, I have had an opportunity to look at the second reading speech and I note that the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2005 deals specifically with changes to the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 and, therefore, I am reinforced in my view that the member for Cowanâs previous argument was germane to the legislation.

talker.name: Gambaro, Teresa, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence
talker.name: Ms GAMBARO

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker Hatton, I thank you for your ruling. Having sat in the chair, I know that it is a difficult position to fulfil, and I respect your ruling. I was merely pointing out that, at some stages during his contribution, the member for Cowan was straying from the true intent of the bill. Thank you for your ruling, and I accept it.
(Mr Hatton)âI thank the member for Petrie.

âThe Defence Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2005 introduced by the Minister for Veteransâ Affairs deals largely with housekeeping measures that update various pieces of legislation within the Defence portfolio. I thank the numerous members who have spoken on the legislation, including the shadow minister for defence, the member for Cowan and the member for Fairfax. I thank the opposition for their support of this bill and for their comments.

speech.para: The Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 will be amended to redefine territory offences under the act as a result of the changes in the criminal law of the ACT. These amendments are necessary to ensure that this act continues to reflect a range of offences originally intended for its operation. The scope of these offences has been severely limited in recent times by changes to laws that are cross-referenced in the act. It is essential that the ADF retain the ability to prosecute a full range of criminal offences, and without this amendment to the definition of territory offences this would not be possible.

The ability to prosecute criminal offences acts as both a sword, by ensuring compliance within the minimum standards of behaviour of soldiers when appropriate, and a shield, by ensuring that criminal behaviour is tried in a fair and transparent system when our soldiers are in operations in countries where criminal justice systems may not meet the standards acceptable to the Australian public. The amendments to the definition of âterritory offenceâ are not as a result of or in any way inconsistent with the military justice inquiry reportânor is it an attempt to expand the current circumstances in which the jurisdiction should be exercised.

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker, I seek to intervene.
âDoes the parliamentary secretary accept the intervention?
âYes.

âMy question relates to the contribution of the member for Cowan. Would the parliamentary secretary give some indication to the House of when there is likely to be a response to the issues that the member for Cowan raised and, when the response is received, the likelihood of further enhancing this legislation?

âI was going to cover that when summing up my speech, but I am happy to give the member for Shortland an answer now. The member for Barton raised the issue, as did the member for Cowan, of the recently tabled report of the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee inquiry into the effectiveness of the Australian military justice system. As advised yesterday by the Minister for Defence, the governmentâs response to this inquiry has been considered by cabinet and the minister is looking forward to shortly providing a very considered response. I hope that satisfies the member for Shortland. I was going to cover it in my summation, but I thank her for her question.

speech.para: Going back to the bill, the repeal of part 8 of the Military Superannuation and Benefits Act 1991 to remove the retention benefit currently available to certain ADF members of the benefit scheme is required to ensure that ADF pay arrangements provide an effective, efficient and flexible remuneration framework consistent with reforms in the wider public and private sectors. Over time the value of retention benefit as an aid to retention has declined, and previous speakersâthe shadow minister and the member for Cowanâhave spoken about retention today. This is a very important measure that will make sure that the main exit points from the ADF after four years and eight to 10 years of service are looked at. There are loss rates at each point, and they vary according to the employment group in question. To be really effective, retention initiatives must now target those specific exit and employment group points. They are not always related to military service and condition; they are also related to demographic and skills issues and career path changes.

We must recognise that, in contrast, the retention bonus targets personnel with 15 years service and those who are likely to continue serving. That is what this measure has done. The current retention bonus is insufficiently targeted and does very little to assist in reducing those separations at critical points of service. Only members who join the ADF, and therefore the Military Superannuation Benefits Scheme, after the date of legislative change will be affected by these changes. Currently the eligible members will continue to have access to the bonuses as they reach the required level of service.

There have been a number of speakers today and they have raised a number of issues, particularly on retention. I am happy to say that the Minister for Veteransâ Affairs is currently engaged in an inquiry looking at retention and recruitment issues. It will be a wide-ranging inquiry. In my position as parliamentary secretary, I am looking at an inquiry into the reserves and what we need to do financially and non-financially to make sure we do not have any further decline in our recruitment in both the regular Defence Force and the reserves.

I want to use this opportunity to highlight a number of initiatives taken to make sure we retain our service men and women. We have improved the level of child care. Recently a contract was signed with ABC Learning Centres to ensure that defence men and women have access to child-care centres. The level of living standards and comfort of DHA housing provided to defence men and women has improved enormously. We have also looked at providing employment for spouses in areas such as Puckapunyal and Townsville, through providing business centres or processing centres where spouses are able to access employmentâand that is a very important issue to help us make sure we retain men and women in the Defence Force. I am looking forward to what both of the reviewsâthe review by the Minister for Veteransâ Affairs into recruitment and retention and the review into the reservesâwill uncover.

But it would be remiss of me to not talk about other issues that affect the defence forces. Not only are there issues relating to financial and non-financial aspects of their service; we also have issues in the private sector that we need to be aware of. We are currently suffering a worldwide skills shortage. Military men and women are highly trained and highly motivated, they possess great loyalty and they are an absolute bonus in anyoneâs workplace. We will always have the civilian sector very keen to encourage and recruit defence personnel to come into the civilian sector.

There are also demographic changes affecting reserves. Continuous training is provided to members of the Reserve. Typically members have taken four or five weeks annual leave and engaged in all of the training. The tourism industry now tells us that people are taking shorter and more frequent breaks rather than taking their annual leave in one hit, and that impacts on training levels and the continuous training that would normally have been undertaken in the past. So there is a whole pile of demographic things that we really need to consider as well. I know that some of these inquiries will look into the changing nature of work and working families and how that impacts on our defence men and women.

I want to touch on one other measure in particular in this bill. This involves minor amendments to Defence portfolio legislation to clarify terminology and eligible ages for ADF cadets. There has been a lack of uniformity, particularly with naval cadets. The bill now clarifies that; it makes the entry point 20 years of age and the exit point 21 years of age. This is in greater uniformity with Army and Air Force cadets. The shadow minister for defence and the member for Cowan both raised issues about cadets. We have improved cadets in a number of areas, including providing greater screening of officers. One of the recommendations they spoke about was providing professional youth councillors for young people in the cadets. We have already engaged a University of Queensland professor. The professor is working particularly with the cadet directorate on youth suicide type issues and other emotional issues that all young people face whether or not they are in the cadets.

I commend this bill. These measures are very important. They will ensure that we have effectiveness with respect to issues concerning cadets. Reference has been made to the Statutory Rules Publication Act 1903 and the repeal provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act which have resulted from the commencement of the new legislative instruments regime. I thank all of the speakers who have spoken to this legislation, and I thank the opposition for their support.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that this bill be reported to the House without amendment.

subdebate.2.para: Debate resumed from 14 September, on motion by Mr Slipper:

motion.para: That the House take note of the document.

talk.start.para: âI commence my remarks by, first of all, thanking the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for allowing me and my colleague Roger Price to join the committee. Both Mr Price and I were originally involved in an inquiry conducted by the former House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs on child custody arrangements. The report, entitled Every picture tells a story, was extremely well received by all groups within our community. There was a great strength of unanimity of the parties as regards the report. I believe it was the wish of the parliament to carry that unanimity into the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

speech.para: It was important to do that because, whilst the outside players and government institutions may all have their views in this vexed and complicated process, it is the role of members of the House to truly present what they believe to be the views of the Australian community and follow through to ensure that government, the executive and the whole mechanism of government observe the wishes of the Australian people. Mr Price and I were able to help in that regard. We were fortunate in that Mrs Hull, the member for Riverinaâthe chair of the former House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairsâwas also a member of the legal and constitutional affairs committee and the three of us were able to provide continuity in terms of the views of that former committee, which prepared what I think was quite a historic document.

The committee was charged with looking at the proposed legislation to change the Family Law Act. As people will be aware, there are several elements to the issue of family relationships. It is very hard and it is vexed. It is vicious at times and it is heartbreaking at other times to see what people do to each other or what they have to put up with. Sometimes that is not of their own making; sometimes it is through an action of the court or the Child Support Agencyâand there are all the other elements that enter into the complexity of the relationship between two people who are separating.

The committee had to consider the Family Law Act. The role of the Child Support Agency is dealt with differently and will be responded to by the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator the Hon. Kay Patterson. Our job was to look at the legal aspects of the Family Law Act. The Attorney-General, Mr Ruddock, provided us with a copy of the draft proposals in response to the previous report. The government has taken some time to respond. I think most people have been quite critical of that, but at the same time they have understood that this is no easy matter. Changes to the Family Law Act are difficult to devise and implement, and it is critical that we as a parliament do not create stress or hardship or unnecessary discrimination to one side or the other in the process. One thing that clearly came through from this report was that the needs of the children be placed paramount in everything that is done, so the best interests of the child are always to the fore in this report and these proposed changes.

Australia has one of the most interventionist family law acts in the world. There is not another area of administration of which I am aware that offers a court a greater opportunity than Australiaâs Family Court has to interfere with and intervene in the affairs of a separating couple. The British system, which is quite similar to ours, does not encourage the court to intervene in these personal affairs to the degree that the Australian system does. So it was the view of the original committee and of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs that the court should be discouraged from unnecessary intervention and that the couple themselvesâno matter how painful, how difficult and how traumatic it may be for a couple freshly separated, given all of the problems that separation may have created; it does not matter how difficult it has beenâought to be focused on the future of their relationship with their children. After their separationâeven after five, 10 or 20 years timeâthey remain parents, and their responsibilities as parents and the links that parents have with their children need to be maintained. For the sake of the childrenâwhich was a fitting title for the previous reportâit is vital that they are considered prime, and, while the court should stand back somewhat, it should still encourage the disengaging couple to think about their kids. It does not matter what they think of each other. They need to think about their children and what is best for their children. That is the theme, the very ethos, of what we are proposing with these legislative changes. I hope the government picks up the provisions that we have put forward in the list of recommendations.
One of the key recommendations is:

quote.para: ... section 65DAA be amended to provide that the court shall, in making parenting orders in situations where there is equally shared parental responsibility, consider whether equal time with both parents is in the best interests of the child and reasonably practicable.

speech.para: The concept is and the requirements are that parenting orders be established over a period of 13 weeks by the separating couples so that decisions about the childrenâs future as to schooling, religious upbringing and all of the things that are of long-term significance to the children are settled and written down. The resultant parenting order is capable of change. It is not a matter of going back to the court and seeking the courtâs approval to change the parenting order. If both parents agree that the parenting order needs to be changed, they can go back and try to change it, because children grow, their needs change, people move and new parenting arrangements are made in families. Families move on, they are never static, so parenting plans and parenting orders can change.

The parenting plan can often underlie the parenting order. The parenting order is something that the court will implement. The parenting order can be participated in only where there is not violence. Violence removes the person who is violent from the parenting order making process and so from the parenting plan. Where there is equally shared parent responsibility, it is a consideration of the committee that the children should spend, if practical and if possible, equal time with the parents. This is going to be more expensive than a family living together. Most separating couples seem to think that, once separated, they are going to be able to manage just as well as when they were together. That is not true. It is more expensive to be separated. That is not often a calculation that both partners understand.

The committee feels that, where practical, where the parents live geographically close to each other and getting the children to school is not a problem, it is very important that the children spend equal time with both parents. In a practical sense, speaking from a male point of view, I think many men will have difficulty in meeting that requirement, because they need to provide maintenance support for their children and former wife. But they must be given the opportunity to share equal time with their children if that is feasible. As a starting point, it is a reasonable thing. Across the nation, non-custodial parents, whether male or female, were saying, âWe havenât got custody, but we want involvement with our children.â It is not a gender thing at all. Everywhere in Australia, non-custodial parents, whether male or female, spoke exactly the same words and had exactly the same emotional reaction. So we must try and ensure that a parent has the opportunity of sewing themselves into the future of their child and establishing a full relationship with them. That is one of the goals we aim at, and I believe it is possible. With care as a starting point, and not a mandated process, there is every opportunity for us to be successful in changing the Family Law Act so that that is a consideration.

There are complexities in the Family Law Act that we seek to consolidate. The goals and objectives, and a whole range of requirements that need to be considered as people separate, need to be drawn togetherâand we have suggested that. We have proposed technical changes. The obvious sticking point is that Nicola Roxon produced a dissenting report. Representing the Australian Labor Party as shadow Attorney-General, she was caught between challenging the Attorney and being a member of the committee. I do not think we should encourage that in future. It is not conducive to the wellbeing of the committee. So her dissenting report is more a political statement than the statement of a committee member. I see that Duncan Kerr, Roger Price and John Murphy have raised some points. They say in their concluding paragraph:

quote.para: In particular, without elevating our concerns to the level of a dissent, we join with Ms Roxon in noting that the committeeâs recommendations, if adopted, will provide increased protection, where disputes arise, for the legitimate interests of those parents who want to share care for their children.

speech.para: These were their weasel words of dissent, but there was a general consensus for these changes. We had a lengthy period with the Chief Justice of the Family Court and members of that bench. We also had the opportunity of meeting others in the field, many of whom just want the best for Australian families. We have marked out a way ahead that includes a one-stop shop for people to get advice, encouragement and support. They will be able to get advice on what would happen if they decided to contest a decision. They will make the effort to come together for the sole purpose of planning the childrenâs future and, once that is done, go their separate ways. We want them first of all to think of their children and not of their pet hates and their dislike of each other, which can be so violent at times. We want to safeguard the children.

One interesting aspect of statistics that has come through is that blood-related parents are seldom aggressive or violent towards their own children; other people in relationships can be. The way in which we assess violence needs care and it needs to be a proven factor, somehow or other. It is very hard across jurisdictions when we go from the Commonwealth Family Court to a state policing system to establish with certainty what has gone on. The process of making a claim of unproven violenceâby hearsay, a subjective comment asserting assault or violenceâneeds to be dealt with in a better way than it is at the moment. Both womenâs and menâs groups who have been spoken to say that there is too much uncertainty. Claims can be made, in fake circumstances, that they are real. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Mr Baldwin) adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation Committee

subdebate.2.para: Debate resumed from 17 August, on motion by Mr Barresi:

motion.para: That the House take note of the report.

talk.start.para: âThe report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation, titled Making it work: inquiry into independent contracting and labour hire arrangements, was tabled in the House on 17 August 2005. The report is a culmination of a great deal of effort by the Employment, Workplace Relations and WorkforceÂ Participation Committee. The intention of our inquiry into independent contracting and labour hire is outlined in the terms of reference, but I summarise by saying that we were looking at establishing a clear delineation between employees and independent contractors. Unfortunately, there is an increasingly blurred line between what is, in todayâs society, an employee and what is an independent contractor. There are also considerations around the triangular relationship between labour hire employees, host employers and labour hire agencies. For example, where an employee is working with a person who is not directly employing them, who is responsible for the employeeâs occupational health and safety? It may, in the end, affect the employee when employed by another off-site. We were looking at the way in which that more complex relationship should be manifested and at recommending to the government ways to clarify the relationship between those three parties. Given the growth of independent contractors in the last 15 yearsâparticularly in the last 10 yearsâand the growth of labour hire companies used by employers, it is a very important area of public policy. There are some extraordinary deficiencies in Commonwealth law and even in state law.

speech.para: As deputy chair of this committee I embarked on the task with great enthusiasm. The committee works very well. There is good sense and good will amongst the members. The committee is chaired ably by Phil Barresi, the member for Deakin. He chairs the committee well and we have done some productive work in the past on participation in the work force. I look forward to the meetings and there is every attempt by all members to come up with genuine recommendations that we can put to the executive government. Alas, on this occasion there were some significant areas of difference between government and opposition members, but I think there were some very significant matters raised in the dissenting report.

Along with three other members of the committee, I played a role in writing the dissenting report in which we distinguished ourselves from the overall recommendations of the committee. I do not want to emphasise areas of disagreement because I think there was an attempt to reconcile differences wherever possible, but at some point I must mention these matters because they are very important to the Australian Labor Party and federal Labor parliamentarians. They are very important matters that affect the way in which employment operates in this country.

I do not want to be accused of carping but there were some recommendations that were consented to. In fact, the majority of the recommendations were consented to. Some of them were very good and, if embraced by the executive government, they will be useful. Hopefully, those recommendations will clear up some of the mess. There were attempts to gather proper information about how many independent contractors we now have in this country as a proportion of the entire work force. We also attempted to reach agreement on a definition. I did not agree with the majority view that we should use common law and other indicators to define âindependent contractorsâ. My view, and that of three other members of the committee, was that we should start from the basis that we must define âan employeeââand then what is not an employee may well be an independent contractor. We should not start from the basis of defining an independent contractor and work backwards to determine who, as a consequence, would be an employee. With respect, I think that that was a fundamental error in the reasoning of the majority members of the committee. The error may well have arisen because of the philosophical differences that we have in relation to these matters and it may also be a result of other matters that have been at play.

I think it is incumbent upon me to mention the behaviour of the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations in this particular matter because he treated the committee with some contempt. I do not say that lightly. I think it is a very grave thing to say about a minister who is charged with the responsibility of overseeing a very important area of national public policyâthat he acted in a contemptuous manner towards a parliamentary committee. I will indicate now why I believe he did so. The Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations referred this matter to us with terms of reference that we were asked to inquire into. We commenced our inquiry by calling for submissions and then embarked upon a whole range of public hearings to allow those who submitted, and others, to give evidence to us so that we could determine the recommendations we could make to the government.

Not long after that referral was made to us, the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations set up his own inquiry, with exactly the same terms of reference, asking almost the same parties to respond to a paper he wrote that was entitled Independent contracting and labour hire arrangements. We had concurrently a parliamentary committee commencing an open inquiry, calling for submissions from all interested partiesâfrom the public, organisations and individualsâon the one hand, and, on the other hand, at the same time, the minister operating a closed inquiry responding to what I have to say was a loaded paper with loaded assertions and questions, giving indications, if you like, as to the ministerâs view about particular matters.

That paper, which received some publicityâindeed, all committee members were very well aware of itâand the behaviour of the minister, in my view, tarnished the process for us. It had an adverse effect upon our processes and, in particular, upon government members of the committee. It is very unusual, and also very unfortunate, for a minister to refer a particular matter to a parliamentary committee in good faith and then at the same time start indicating his views before the committee has had an opportunity to make any recommendation on those matters. That behaviour was contemptuous, in my view. I made my views clear on that at the time, and I do so now because, without the intervention of the minister and the contemptuous behaviour, we may have found more areas of agreement. I say with all genuineness that I believe this committee operates openly and that people collaborate genuinely on these matters. I have to say for the record that that was a very disturbing interventionâintrusion, if you likeâby the minister.

But there were a number of recommendations that we agreed to. They do not have a lot of teeth, but there are recommendations about collating information so that we can clarify exactly what is going on and some recommendations about improving occupational health and safety matters and ensuring that the labour hire agency and the host employer understand their obligations to employees. There are areas where we agreed. They are not very compelling, and they are not particularly strong recommendations, but, nonetheless, the sincerity with which they were put by all members in the areas in which we consented was important. I am hoping that the government will at least pick up the unanimous recommendations that were put to the minister.

As I said earlier, we differed fundamentally because we believe that you have to start by defining an employee. In listening to the evidence, with all the submissions we had and the witnesses who came before us, we found that there is clearly significant misuse of the term âindependent contractorâ. There is an attempt by some employersâand, by the way, it disadvantages employees and other employersâto disguise employment, to dress the employees up as independent contractors, if you like, so that they can defray, so that they can shift what would normally be employer obligations onto those employees. A classic example is this. On Friday, an employee or a group of employees is working for an employer; on Monday they are told they must have an ABN, they must look after their own superannuation and they must insure themselves for workers compensation, because now they are independent contractors.

I think most committee members know what a genuine independent contractor is. It is a person who understands that they are in the marketplace and they are trading their labour freely with all sorts of other parties. The relationship between an independent contractor and a principal who needs that labour is clearly a genuine thing. You see that with a lot of highly skilled tradespeople, for example, who set up a business. They understand the risks. There is a downside to being an independent contractor because you do not necessarily have the surety of work. You have to find your own work in the economy and you are responsible for superannuation, insuring yourself and indeed other matters that would normally be the responsibility of the employer.

The Labor Party has no problem with those people who have the wherewithal and the wit to set themselves up as a contractor. We have no problem with those arrangements. What we do not accept is allowing employers to set up an arrangement where they force their employees to be an employee on Friday and a so-called independent contractor on Monday. We have suggested a series of recommendations to the minister to properly delineate genuine independent contractors from the bogus independent contractor. We have recommended specific methods for the government to delineate clearly who is a genuine contractor and who is not. The government members failed to accept the recommendations and I dare say the minister will treat us with the contempt he has already treated the committee. We also made recommendations in relation to labour hire arrangements. We think there should be a clear responsibility between the host employer and the labour hire agency.

I want to finish by saying specifically that we are very concerned about the proposed independent contractors act. It tries to prevent the Transport Workers Union, which has represented contractors for 80 years, from having the right to represent contractors. It is quite extraordinary when the Australian Football Association and other bodies like that can represent contractors but the employee organisations registered would be prevented from representing their members. That clearly is a deliberate attempt to damage collective bargaining in the workplace. We have recommended specifically that that provision be deleted from the bill before the parliament. There is a whole series of things that have been put forward and I think the government should take them very seriously. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThere is no doubt there has been a quiet revolution taking place in the Australian labour market over the last 15 years and, more particularly, that change has been very evident over the past 10 years. It is estimated that there are more than one million Australiansâand, in fact, that figure could be closer to two million Australiansâworking as independent contractors. In other words, these people are working entirely outside the traditional employment paradigm. Advances and developments of in-home office technology, email, mobile phones, voicemail and a raft of other modern technology mean that Australians can set up microbusinesses that can be run from home or indeed from the back of a car. The office of the past has changed. It no longer needs to be a static stand-alone piece of infrastructure. It is flexible and moveable.

speech.para: The delivery of services to industry has changed. A more modern, flexible work force is evidence of a changing labour force. These are generational changes that were unthinkable 10 years agoâchanges that see people wanting to manage their own affairs and their own work environments. There is no such thing these days as a permanent job for a lifetime. The number of independent contractors will just continue to grow as technology advances. The work force is on the move.

But, of course, with the growth of independent contractors the challenges of providing protection for the contractors have also grown. The chair of the Standing Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation, the member for Deakin, recently tabled a report in the House entitled Making it work: inquiry into independent contracting and labour hire arrangements and I commend the report to the House. The terms of reference for the inquiry were adopted on 9 December 2004 by the committee. The Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, the Hon. Kevin Andrews, requested the committee inquire into and report on issues including the status and range of independent contracting and labour hire arrangements, the strategies to ensure independent contract arrangements were legitimate and the role of labour hire arrangements in a modern Australian economy.

It was a challenge, particularly in view of the short period of time for the inquiry to undertake the necessary public hearings and for the report consideration. It was also a challenge in view of the increasing debate that was happeningâand is still ongoingâregarding changes to federal workplace relations legislation and the impact any changes may have on independent contractors. However, the committee met the deadlines and members worked together to achieve what I believe to be a credible report with some important recommendations.

The 16 recommendations included in the report covered areas such as: the occupational health and safety of labour hire workers and independent contractors; the improvement of access to skill development and training for labour hire workers; the establishment of a voluntary code of practice for the labour hire industry; the need to create greater consistency across federal, state and territory legislation in differentiating between independent contractors and employees; the improvement of access to information to outline the rights and responsibilities of independent contractors; the need to regulate independent contractors under commercial law; and the improvement of access to different dispute resolution procedures for independent contractors.

During the course of the inquiry, the committee investigated whether labour hire and contracting arrangements are in some instances being used to evade responsibilities, particularly in the area of occupational health and safety. Significant concerns were reported to the committee regarding the increased risk of injury for labour hire workers and independent contractors. Some evidence to the committee stated that workplace health and safety of labour hire workers is not as good as that of direct employees. Evidence to the inquiry also indicated there was confusion about responsibilities between labour hire agencies and host businesses. This uncertainty at times meant that either party may not acknowledge OH&S responsibilities.

Occupational health and safety issues were of huge concern to me, and I believe that is reflected by recommendations 6, 7, 8 and 9. These four recommendations clearly spell out some guidelines for responsibilities in this area. It is important, in my view, that labour hire companies and host businesses have a clear set of national guidelines to protect the safety of independent contractors in the workplace. These four recommendations cover such areas as training for workers by labour hire agencies and host businesses, monitoring and enforcing compliance with occupational health and safety regulations, improving the collection of data on injury rates for independent contractors so comparisons can be made against direct employees and the development of initiatives to ensure greater understanding among independent contractors and host businesses of respective responsibilities in relation to occupational health and safety.

This inquiry was difficult and challenging in the first instance because of the need for greater clarity and consistency in distinguishing between an employee and an independent contractor. There were conflicting views on what constituted a contractor, as distinct from an employee. I felt that it was important to clarify the difference. The committee noted in the report that different definitions of âemployeeâ, âindependent contractorâ and âemployerâ in Commonwealth and state jurisdictions have been the subject of longstanding concern. The report notes that differentiating between independent contractors and employees has required the common law to provide guidance. It was also noted that the courts need to use factors rather than a definition to determine employment status. The huge volume of evidence in this area provided substantial detail on many of these matters, and the evidence is summarised in the report. Careful consideration was given to all the evidence in determining what an independent contractor is, and government members recommended that the Australian government maintain the common law approach to determining employment status and distinguishing between employees and legitimate independent contractors.

Overall, as a committee, each of us wanted to ensure that government did not in any way hinder the growth of independent contractors. It was well recognised that a balance between protections and freedoms for independent contractors had to be reached. As more and more Australians set up businesses that see them delivering services to a host of industries as independent contractors, we as legislators must be mindful of not dampening the entrepreneurial spirit. We must put safeguards in place, but those safeguards must not hinder the growth of the independent contractor in this country.

We must recognise and embrace the cultural change that is happening in Australiaâs labour market. This cultural change is in response to a changing global market, the competitiveness of business and the rise of franchising in this country, but more importantly it is a response to the individual who is choosing how he works and for whom he works. This individual is now taking on board responsibility for his working life. He wants the freedom of working for himself, with the choices that allow him to meet his demands and the demands of family responsibilities, hours of work and income needs. This person wants to be independent; this person does not want to work for an employer. In other words, these people have chosen to work as independent contractors because it suits their lifestyle or income preferences.

The Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations has indicated that in drafting the independent contractors act, which will be introduced into the parliament later this year, he will actively consider the committeeâs report and its recommendations. The minister has further indicated that this government respects the rights of genuine independent contractors to manage their own affairs and to enter into their own agreements with their clients, if that is their preference. The growth of independent contractors certainly warrants the acknowledgement and support of government. Unfortunately for my opposition colleagues, there are now more independent contractors than there are trade union members in the Australian work force. This is a fact that should be acknowledged. It is a stark fact that shows just how much the Australian work force has changed and where it is moving to. As a government we need to protect the rights of independent contractors to work in the way they want, while ensuring the necessary safeguards are put in place so that they are not hindered in delivering the myriad services to industry that are so crucial to the continued economic growth of this country.

To all my colleagues on the committee, and I note there are some opposition members of the committee here this morning, my thanks to each and every one of you for the spirited debate during the course of the inquiry. As the chairman of the committee noted in his tabling speech, even though there was dissent along party lines on some of the recommendations, overall there was unified support for the majority of the report, and there was certainly a huge commitment by all to ensure that a useful and informative report was finally tabled in the parliament. I commend the report to the House.

talk.start.para: âI am pleased to have the opportunity today to make some brief comments in relation to the report entitled Making it work: inquiry into independent contracting and labour hire arrangements, which was tabled in the House very recently. In so doing I open my remarks by first of all putting on the record my thanks to, and my respect for, the committee secretariat attached to this inquiry. I thank each one of them most sincerely for the assistance and guidance they offered to all of us as committee members. I also want to thank all colleagues on the committee, both government and my own colleagues, for the spirit in which the inquiry was conducted. I want to endorse all the comments made by my colleague Brendan OâConnor, the Deputy Chair of the Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation Committee, who spoke earlier this morning. I do not wish to go over his comments again, but I want to endorse particularly his comments in relation to why we agreed on our side of the committee to put in our dissent to some aspects of the report. Members are extremely aware, and I am very aware, that most reports in this place are unanimous. It is does not happen every day that there are dissenting comments, and so they need to be observed as a serious contribution. We believe there are very good reasons for us to have those dissenting comments included. Having endorsed those comments by the deputy chair of the committee I want to talk about one particular aspect of the report this morning. It relates specifically to, in loose terms, the sorts of sham arrangements that can occur in the labour hire industry and to one case in particular.

speech.para: I wish to highlight this one case for a very clear reason, and the previous speaker, the member for McPherson, just mentioned it. While we are talking about this report there is also a debate going on about changes to industrial relations legislation and the Welfare to Work arrangements. There is an interleaving going on between all of these subjects and a connection with this report. The case in point was brought to my attention by my own community in Canberraâa non-government organisation acting on behalf of a client of theirs. I will read some of the very brief submission that was made to the inquiry by this non-government organisation. In part, the submission states:

quote.para: I am bringing this case to your attention for your consideration as it demonstrates the vulnerability of people on the Disability Support Pension in the workplace, when there are not sufficient safeguards to protect their rights. There must be many similar cases across Australia where people on the DSP are subjected to these sorts of practices.

speech.para: Then there is a brief outline of the case. This is also referred to in the report at page 125, paragraph 5.142 and onwards. The case in point concerned a client on DSP for four years who has worked part time as a cleaner since October last year. This person was working 20 hours per week. She rang Centrelink each fortnight and informed them of her income and they adjusted her disability support pension accordingly. The client appears to have a mild intellectual disability. The client was worried about not paying any tax as the employer was not deducting any from her pay.

The NGO rang the cleaning agency involved and was informed that the client was a subcontractor with the agency and that she had agreed to all the terms and had signed a contract. The client, however, said that she remembered signing some paperwork but she was not really sure what it meant, as she is not very good with forms. She was clearly very distressed and worried about possibly losing her job. The NGO subsequently sighted the contract that the client had signed but she had obviously no idea what it meant in relation to her employment. The client says she likes her cleaning job and wants to keep it; she does not understand the implications of being a subcontractor, or know what it even is. She receives a weekly pay packet and does not invoice the agency. They ring her and offer her work each week. She has regular customers that she cleans for. Superannuation, workers compensation insurance, holidays et cetera are all issues that obviously need clarification.

The point here is that this person thought she was workingâand she wasâbut she did not know that she was being employed as a subcontractor with all the implications that brings. It reached the point where she was asking Centrelink to take out the tax. She had to apply for an ABN. She did not even know how to begin to do the paperwork for an ABN, let alone understand the implications of what it meant. The client subsequently brought in the ABN application and, when the NGO officer asked her whether she understood the form at all, she became distressed and said it was all too much for her. At that stage in the proceedings the service involved was working with the client to investigate options for any other work and any issues with regard to the possible tax debt that this person now faces. I am not certain at this stage where that tax debt is up to.

The reason for bringing the matter up is evident. My colleagues on the committee were also very interested in this case. It just shows that when we talk about subcontracting arrangements, employment possibilities and influencing people in a positive way to move from welfare to work, there are many considerations that we must have in mind. It is never quite as simple as many of us would wish it to be. This is not an isolated case. There will have been, will be and will continue to be many instances around the country where people are taken advantage of in circumstances such as this. In my view, there has been an avoidance of obligations on the part of the employerâif we can determine that they are the employer under the arrangements to do with identity and clarification in labour hire circumstances. There has been a move by some people to remove themselves from their obligations in terms of their employer status. People like this woman can get very badly caught up in that.

She ended up, as I have said, an unfortunate client of the Taxation Office, to whom she had a debt. Heaven knows what other circumstances would have flowed from that. I say to the government, in the most genuine and earnest way, that when we are talking about all these issues to do with people on DSP and maybe some who are notâmaybe some who do not have literacy or numeracy skills or have other circumstances to assist themâthere are very vulnerable folk out there who can fall foul through no fault of their own of all these things we are talking about. Nothing would make me happier than to see as many as possible of those people who find themselves in circumstances where they need disability support pension to exist financially have a more fruitful life out in the community participating along with the rest of us, but we cannot just sit back and assume that they all have the wherewithal to do that and we cannot just sit back and assume that all employers will do the right thing by them. The majority of them will, but there will be a hell of a lot of them who will not.

I am really grateful to the committee and to the chair that we were able to put this example prominently in the report and talk about it at some length. If I have any disappointment, it is in the fact that we have some dissent to recommendation 15 in the report. While our dissent is clearly outlined in our dissenting reportâand it has everything to do with industrial relationsâin paragraph 1.23 of our dissenting report, under âOpposition to Recommendation 15â, we say:

quote.para: In the event that the Commonwealth successfully implements a national industrial relations system the Australian Government should first clearly define an âemployeeâ by adopting the definition as outlined earlier in this dissenting report. Further more the Australian government should legislate to prevent forms of disguised employment.

speech.para: This case, and others like it, come under this banner fairly well. I strongly suggest to the minister and to the government that when they make changes they seriously consider these sorts of implications.

As I said a moment ago, this is only one instance. I am grateful to the agency for making the submission available to the committee. I have to say very honestly that I do not believe one member of the committee disagreed with the notion that we were in general terms putting forward about circumstances such as this. I know all members on the committee would agree with meâand they did at the timeâthat this is far from a satisfactory arrangement. My fear is just how many others like this are occurring. It is relevant to this report. I am concentrating my remarks purely on this because I think it is so important, and I hope that the remarks that are being made by members opposite on the adoption of the report by the government will allow the government to consider the comments we have made in our dissenting report and why they are there. This is one example that I would like to draw to the governmentâs attention.

talk.start.para: âI am very pleased to have this opportunity to speak to the report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation titled Making it work: inquiry into independent contracting and labour hire arrangements. I would also like to put on record my appreciation of the opportunity I was given to participate in this inquiry and also thank the secretariat for the fantastic support they provided over the course of the inquiry.

speech.para: The inquiry brought to light not only a number of issues and a number of challenges in independent contracting and labour hire but also a growth of people wanting this level of independence and choice in their working life, which I support. The report highlights the conditions faced by Australiaâs estimated million-plus independent contractors that find themselves under siege by state legislation and union intimidation in many cases and their being poorly served by any federal legal framework under which they can work.

This is of particular concern when you consider that in Australia today a significant proportion of the work force is engaged in independent contracting. Indeed, it is a growing phenomenon. Independent contracting has become a lifestyle choice for what is, according to the figures provided by Independent Contractors of Australia, around 28 per cent of the countryâs labour force. These million or more hardworking men and women are engaged in running home based businesses, providing specialist advice in a range of fields such as marketing consultants, financial consultants, IT professionals, service providers and as subcontractors to the manufacturing, construction and building sectors. They represent a significant sector of our economy. We cannot ignore their needs and the challenges that face them.

The report entitled Making it work that is before you contains a summary of the wide range of views on independent contracting and labour hire arrangements that were expressed to the Standing Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation during the eight days of hearings that were held across Australia and which were contained in more than 70 submissions that were received. During those hearings, we heard evidence that made it clear that people want to have the choice to be independent and benefit from the flexibility that life as an independent contractor will allow. They want to be, in effect, in charge of their own destiny in their working life. They do not want to be employees, they do not want to be tied to a single employer; they want choice, although many of them may work for a single organisation, business or entity for a period of two or three yearsâor more or lessâdepending on what they decide at the time.

With respect to labour hire, where people work as independent contractors for labour hire companies and are placed in such work environments as aged care, health, health care, hospitality or tourism entities and organisationsâor a range of similar service organisationsâwe see that, in cases where they have the option to switch to being a permanent employee, on almost all occasions they choose to remain as a contractor because of the flexibility it affords in their individual circumstances.

That is not always the case, although I am informed that on all occasions these people are given the option of becoming employees if they are going into a long-term arrangement with a client of a labour hire company. Independent contractors in many ways epitomise the entrepreneurial spirit of Australia and contribute to Australiaâs prosperity and the vibrancy of the communities in which they operate.

In his speech last week to the Independent Contractors of Australia, the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, the Hon. Kevin Andrews, described independent contracting as âone of the most important, yet least commented on, shifts in the history of its labour marketâ. I agree with this assessment, and I think there is evidence in the report to support that sentiment as well. From evidence gleaned by the committee at the hearings, and through briefings from such organisations as Independent Contractors and others, it has become apparent that most trade unions are opposed to the rise of independent contractors and are actively engagedâwith the help of some of the Labor controlled state governments that benefit from donations made by unions to the Labor Party coffersâin activities that are designed to force independent contractors back into traditional industrial relations systems. That is not a welcome development and it needs to be addressed. Fundamentally, the Labor Party and the unions seem unable to grasp the concept of independent contractors, because those contractors have little interest in joining the union movement.

In this regard, I am strongly of the view that independent contracting represents a commercial relationship between the parties involved and under no circumstances should they be considered as requiring regulation under state industrial relations or workplace relations regimes. I am totally opposed to state deeming measures which seek to treat independent contractors as employees and which reduce the independence of those contractors through prescriptive legislation. There is a certain hypocrisy involved when these Labor controlled state governmentsâand the unions that support themâtalk about freedom of association when in fact they are actively seeking to reduce the choice and freedom of individuals to operate as independent contractors, putting them back into the industrial relations environment.

In my home state of Western Australia the state government has been seeking to effectively deem independent contractors through its industrial relations legislation by expanding the definition of what constitutes an employee to include, as examples, outworkers, labour hire workers and contract cleaners.

In Queensland, section 275 of the Queensland Industrial Relations Act 1999 gives the Queensland Industrial Relations Commission the power to declare persons who work under a contract for service to be an employee. Evidence from the ACCI suggested that removing deeming of individual contractors or employers from the Australian system of labour laws and precluding the operation of state deeming provisions should be supported. I support these propositions.

The Making it work report tabled 16 recommendations that were supported by the majority of committee members; however, only nine of those were supported by all parties. A further seven minority report recommendations were tabled by the Labor Party members. These alternatives are certainly not supported by the majority of committee members.

It is refreshing to see that at least on a number of recommendations there has been cross-party support; however, the differences identified are fundamental and occur in a number of what I believe to be crucial areas. There is certainly cross-party support for recommendations made in relation to statistical data collection, improvements in work safety, achieving consistency in terms of workersâ compensation systems and the development of educational resources.

Sadly, but perhaps predictably, the recommendations made in the report which Labor members have declined to support are the very ones that are crucial to ensuring the flexibility of working arrangements enjoyed by independent contractors. Labor, it seems, because of their Tweedledum and Tweedledee relationship with the unions, want to continue to frustrate the use of independent contractors in order to drag them back into the grasp of rigid state controlled workplace relations systems, with many claims of sham arrangements.

As part of the report, the committee strongly recommended that the Australian government maintain the common law approach to determine employment status and to distinguish between employees and legitimate independent contractors. The common law approach is the commonsense approach and has the overwhelming support of the independent contractors of Australia. The Independent Contractors of Australia describe this approach as the bedrock of Independent Contracting. This is not an opinion shared by Labor. The minority report suggests an alternative approach and trots out, in the words of the ICA:

quote.para: ... an incoherent shambles that would create massive commercial confusion and effectively dump known and stable commercial legal systems and relationships.

speech.para: The Labor alternative amounts to a tacit banning of independent contracting and labour hire. Remarkably, it also flies in the face of the acceptance by the International Labour Organisation of the legitimacy of independent contracting.

The majority recommendations in the Making it work report are designed to ensure that independent contractors can be treated on a commercial basis as small businesses and thereby take advantage of a whole raft of commercial law protections and remedies offered to other enterprises. Unions that attack and deride the role of the independent contractor do so for self-serving purposes.

Conservative estimates put the number of independent contractors at around 1.1 million and growing, while the ICA figures suggest that there may be as many as 1.9 million independent contractors. If that is the case, they now outnumber union membership, which has been on the decline for many years while, in contrast, the independent contractorsâ star has been rising. The union movement, in concert with its Labor Party mates, would love to force union membership upon them. Indeed, Labor controlled state governments have introduced legislation to include specific provisions into their industrial relations laws to enable unions to treat independent contractors as though they were employees.

Independent contractors add enormous value to the Australian economy and their growth is very much an unheralded success story. But that success has meant that independent contractors have become the target of what is predatory action by the unions and Labor controlled state governments that seek to legislate in the industrial relations system where no regulation is sought by either the contractors or their clients.

It is my belief that a partyâs freedom to contract must be upheld and that independent contractors need greater certainty in commercial relationships. The majority party recommendations of this report, when taken in concert with the proposed independent contractors act, will ensure that these important tenets are upheld and protected. They will, for example, also prevent unions from seeking orders from the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to impose unreasonable constraintsâconstraints that have no place in todayâs economic realityâon the freedom of Australiaâs independent contractors to work in Australian workplaces.

There is no doubt that labour hire and independent contracting arrangements should continue to develop and grow, providing both flexibility and opportunities for workers and business in the growing and increasingly diverse Australian economy. I commend the report to the House.

talk.start.para: âI rise to support the recommendations made in the dissenting report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation report entitled Making it work: inquiry into independent contracting and labour hire arrangements. Before doing so, I would like to thank the chair for the very constructive role that he played. It was quite obvious from the start of the inquiry that there would never be agreement on a number of the recommendations. This was recognised by previous speakers, including the member for McPherson. I was disappointed by the contribution by the member for Hasluck because he was not cognisant of, did not give consideration to or did not acknowledge the fact that this was the type of inquiry in which, no matter what happens, you are going to have two different views expressed in the report. That probably goes to the heart of the differences between the two sides of parliament when looking at issues like this. It is important to acknowledge that the chair played a very constructive role and was very mindful of the fact that this was the situation. I would like to thank the deputy chair. He played a very important role in drafting the recommendations in the dissenting report. He worked closely with all the members that supported those recommendations.

speech.para: Finally, I would also like to thank the committee secretariat for the work that they did and the support that they gave the committee. I would like to refer to the final point that the deputy chair made in his recommendation: that he found it âdisappointing that the secretariat was not sufficiently resourced to assistâ the members that wished to make a dissenting report. All up, I think that as a committee, given the very difficult circumstances, we worked very well together. Those members that did make the effort to attend most of the hearings and inquiries probably learnt a lot about this subject and were able to fully understand the issues from all perspectives. Even those members supporting the body of the report could understand the concerns of the people who did not agree with it and would never support the recommendations outlined in the report.

Before I go to the body of the dissenting report, I would like to place on record a couple of concerns that I have. My first concern is that the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations released his discussion paper during the inquiry. He actually pre-empted a lot of the findings of the inquiry. I think he sought to influence to some extent the government members that were involved in that inquiry. It really worries me that the discussion paper was released on the day that the committee was conducting hearings in Sydney. We were most concerned by the fact that the minister had released his discussion paper and there was a feeling that, even if it did not influence the members of the committee, it could create the perception that it would.

The second concern I would like to place on the record relates to the final stages of the inquiry when we had representatives from the department attend hearings here in parliament. I think we are served very well by those people who work in most departments. I have found on all the committee hearings I have been involved in that when staff employed by departments attend they try and answer the questions that are put to them by members of the committee. And members of the committee are also mindful that there are certain questions that the department cannot answer. I was absolutely horrified on the last occasion that the department came to meet with the committee, before we went to the final stages of our deliberations, when one staff member blatantly refused to answer any questions put to him. He hedged, he ducked, he weavedâand not only from questions put to him by opposition members of the committee but also from questions put to him by members of the government. I thought that that was a very sad state of affairs, and I found it very disappointing, because it put a lot of pressure on the other staff member that was there. Really, the point of our meeting with departmental officials is to clarify any points that we may have, particularly at the vital stage just before we go into report deliberations. I feel that it is extremely important for me to put that on the record because that was the first time I had encountered it on any committee that I have been involved in in this parliament or, for that matter, in the New South Wales parliament. I was quite disappointed.

There are a number of dissenting recommendations. Firstly, we do agree with recommendations 1, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11 and 13. The recommendations that we disagree with really go to the core differences between the government and the opposition on this issue. The first recommendation that we oppose is recommendation 2, which goes to the definition of what determines employment and what determines independent contracting. The government supports a common law approach whereas we feel, as set out in the dissenting report, the government should provide a new definition of employee and that this definition should clarify the issues and remove the vagaries so as to create certainty for all the parties involved. I thought that that was an eminently sensible approach to take, but unfortunately that was not the majority decision of the committee.

Next I refer to recommendation 3 and, once again, the opposition members did not support that recommendation. We felt that there was a need to define independent contractor. A number of our recommendations went to the fact that we really believed that it was important to have those definitions in place. Recommendation 4 refers back to that vital need for a definition of employee. It is proposed to place the onus on those who seek to be independent contractors to establish that they are genuinely running a business.
