We received a lot of evidence during hearings and through submissions to the committee which showed that that was of great concern to all parties involved in independent contracting or employees. Unfortunately, I feel that this report is not going to address those concerns. I think there will continue to be ambiguity in relation to employees and independent contractors. The common law approach means that people will be forced into situations that could be quite costly. I feel we have let all the parties down.

One thing that became very apparent during the hearings was the impact that the increased casualisation of the work force was having on many workers in Australia. One of the sessions I found most interesting was in Sydney when we received evidence from labour hire companies. I was very surprised to find that it is not unusual for a person to be employed by a labour hire company and work with the same employer for a number of yearsâthree, four or five years. The one that astounded me was the employee, employed by a labour hire company, who had been working for the one company for seven years. To my way of thinking, that cannot be justified. The labour hire company advised the committee that quite often companies seek to employ people through labour hire because it is better for their bottom line and for their reporting requirements. People employed by labour hire companies do not enjoy the same conditions as other employees. That extends to being able to secure loans and mortgages and this pervades all areas of their life. This area needs to be addressed. Employers should not be able to abrogate their responsibility to their workers simply from the point of view of meeting the requirements of their bottom line.

Another area of great concern in relation to labour hire was occupational health and safety. There was considerable confusion in relation to who bore the responsibility for an injured workerâwhether it was the host company, the labour hire agency or a joint responsibility. I believe this issue needs to be addressed. I have come across numerous examples within my own electorate of where this confusion has been evident, where host employers have sought to abrogate their responsibility to injured workers. Probably one of the worst cases I have heard of is a worker who had a steel rod rammed through their leg. The employer arranged for that person to be driven to the hospital because they did not want to involve the WorkCover Authority. They had a very questionable safety record and, by taking the worker to the hospital in private transport, sought to abrogate their responsibility. We really need to have proper legislation in place, not to have a voluntary code of conduct, but mandatory registration of labour hire companies. Labour hire companies recognise that there is a need for registration but we need to make sure that any change fits in with recommendation 23.Â That will make for a better, safe working environment for all concerned.

The other issue relates to the TWUâprobably one of the best presentations I have seen to any committee in this parliament. Drivers presented to the committee their concerns about proposed changes that will prevent them from being members of the TWU. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI would like to support the recommendations of the dissenting members of the Standing Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation. While the majority of the recommendations of the committee were agreed upon unanimously, I trust that the government will take notice of the seven additional recommendations contained in the dissenting report presented by Labor members of the committee.

speech.para: Independent contractors and labour hire arrangements are a growing feature of the Australian workplace, and the evidence suggests that there is going to be some growth for some time to come. It is not about to stopâat least according to the evidence presented to the committee. It provides opportunities for employers to shift workers from being employees to being contractors while in effect remaining, to all intents and purposes, an employee.

Probably the most disappointing thing about the report is that this failed to be taken up in any serious way. While it was acknowledged as an issue by the dissenting Labor members, the government members failed to pick up probably the single most important thing facing people who have been shifted from being employees to being contractors.

The government members have missed a fantastic opportunity to address the concerns of these workers, who are becoming a larger and larger part of the Australian work force. I am a little torn about why this might be the case. On the one hand, it might be that people simply do not understand the concerns of these workers. On the other hand, it is perhaps because government members are actually supportive of the inherent unfairness of the arrangements, given their stance on other industrial issues. But it is most likely to be simply that government members do not care.

The government simply does not care about many workers being forced into positions where they have to accept a contracting arrangement for the convenience of their employers. In most circumstances the employees who have quickly become so-called independent contractors are not facing anything different in terms of their work or their relationship with their employer, but they are certainly facing additional uncertaintyâadditional uncertainty borne out of not being on the books in the same way: as opposed to being on wages, they are there simply as independent contractors.

Of course, it does not stop there. The former employee, now a contractor, also faces considerable on-costs that once were borne by the employer. The contractor is expected to now make provision for their own superannuation, their own compensation premiums and any other insurance that may be required by the employer or by state or federal statute. While members opposite may say this is a fair thing, I have to say that from my perspective, and from that of the people in my electorate, it is completely unfair. The employer is getting all the benefits in the same way that they did before, but they are now able to avoid the additional on-costs associated with the direct hire of employees.

The situation, quite frankly, is probably best described as all care with very little responsibility. In my opinion, this is a key thing that government members missed during this inquiry. Government members had the opportunity to recommend to the minister that, after weighing up all the evidence that was presented to them, there was a case for change. There was the opportunity to adjust what I consider to be these unfair arrangements. There was an opportunity to correct the record in that respect. They had the opportunity to support Laborâs bid to have an unfair situation corrected by recommending changes to the definition of an employee, moving away from a common-law definition and imposing an adjustment to the Workplace Relations Act. Instead, the government members stood firm with the decision to continue the situation in which an employer can get away with removing entitlements, exposing workers to unnecessary and unfair levels of risk, simply by redefining their classification. With the stroke of a pen, everything is removed and nothing is replaced when it comes to many cases of so-called independent contractors.

As the member for Gorton noted in his earlier speech on the report, there are myriad sham arrangements that have been entered into and taken advantage of by making employees contractors. These sham arrangements create a situation of disguising employment and they are simply unfair to workers who are forced to accept them, forced to take all of the risk and most of the costâsometimes for very little or no additional return, I might add. These situations are simply wrong and should be stopped. It is not nearly good enough that they be allowed to continue and that people be allowed to take advantage of them, or at least of the results. The government had the chance to change this, or at least put on the record that it is wrong, by supporting a relatively simple amendment to the definition of âemployeeâ. This could have been easily achieved through an amendment to the definition of employee contained in the Workplace Relations Act, as outlined in recommendation 2 of the dissenting report.

The evidence to the committee was clear. When labour hire and independent contracting arrangements are entered into, the lines become extremely blurred. The lines are blurred not only for the purpose of assigning responsibility but also for the purposes of legal obligations that are created by these arrangements. The blurred lines and changed obligations mean that, at times, workers in these arrangements are far worse off than they ever were when they were direct hire employees. Their protections have been removed, their entitlements have been removed and they have additional on-costs foisted upon them. In most circumstances, when added up, this is all to their detriment.

I note that the evidence to the committee showed that there are also concerns about permanency of arrangements, unreasonableness of working hours and the general treatment of the so-called independent contractor being worse than would have been the case had they remained as direct employees. These are serious issues and they reflect a legitimate concern for those who are being taken advantage of under often unfair arrangements that they had no option other than to accept. I wonder if this is some sort of sign for the future of all other working Australians.

The matters that this report deals with have a direct impact on many of my constituents. I know many of those in Werriwa are certainly concerned about the matters that came before this committee. Recently I had the opportunity to hear from and speak with a number of people who are deeply concerned about the governmentâs approach to independent contractors. These people were not just fearful for their own livelihoods but concerned about the future of their families. During the last sitting fortnight of this parliament, a delegation of independent contractors in the transport industry travelled to Canberra to defend their rights. This group rallied at the front of Parliament House in an effort to bring their plight and their fight to the members of this place. I attended that rally to show my support. Sadly, I have to say, I did not see many members from the opposite side there and that is probably why they are not so willing to participate in this debate.

The transport workers also conducted a forum to which all members and senators were invited. The forum gave all of us here the opportunity to hear directly about their concerns. It also gave us the opportunity to hear from a number of experts, including academics in the field and wives and families of these contracted transport workers. While generally productive, the forum was interrupted by the member for OâConnor, who, it would seem, could not help himself when presented with an opportunity to put himself in front of a TV camera.
A division having been called in the House of Representativesâ

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veteransâ Affairs, in writing, on 12 May 2005:

item.para: When and how extensively has Dapsone been used within the Australian Defence Force.
What side effects does Dapsone have.
Have tests ever been conducted in Australia to measure the side effects of Dapsone and have the results of these tests been made public; if so, where.
Have tests been conducted and results not been made public; if so, why.
Has Dapsone been linked to cancer.
Do U.S. Veteransâ studies show a link between Dapsone and brain tumours.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

quote.para: The following answers are provided based on information available to the Department of Veteransâ Affairs.

item.para: The use of Dapsone as an anti-malarial was restricted to Vietnam. In Vietnam, Dapsone was first used in September 1967 when it became a drug used to treat active malaria. From November 1968 it was used as a malaria prevention drug. This continued until February 1970. During this time it is estimated that 23,400 persons took the drug.
Dapsone has a wide range of side effects. These include nausea, vomiting, headache and insomnia. Severe side effects include agranulocytosis, a condition in which the white blood cells die.

and (4) No tests have been made on Dapsone by DVA. The Department of Veteransâ Affairs commissioned several studies on the possible health effects of Dapsone. The largest of these was a cancer incidence study, which was released by the then Minister for Veteransâ Affairs in 1992. All studies were based on record searches, not testing of individuals. Two smaller record searches were also made, one of which was concerned with the side effects of Dapsone. They have been available to the public via the library of the Department of Veteransâ Affairs since 1994. Two case reports were published in the Medical Journal of Australia in 1970 and 1971.
No. There were suggestions of a carcinogenic effect in some reports several decades ago, but these have not been supported by more recent material. Dapsone is today not regarded as carcinogenic.
The Department of Veteransâ Affairs is not aware of any US studies that show a link between brain tumours and Dapsone.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, in writing, on 9 August 2005:

item.para: Can he confirm whether a scoping study is under way or has been undertaken on the possible sale of Medibank Private.
Is the Government considering the sale of Medibank Private; if so, can he explain what benefits its sale would generate for its members.
What capital does the Commonwealth have invested in Medibank Private.
What proportion of the current assets of Medibank Private are derived from the contributions of its members.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Finance and Administration has supplied the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.para: The Australian Government undertook a scoping study into the future ownership options for Medibank Private Limited (Medibank Private) in the 2002-03 financial year.

On 16 August 2005 the Minister for Finance and Administration, Senator the Honourable Nick Minchin, announced the Australian Government had decided to review its ownership of Medibank Private and will update the 2003 scoping study. The scoping study update is expected to be completed by the end of this year.

The Government is reviewing its ownership of Medibank Private through an update of the 2003 scoping study. The update will include a consideration of the effects of a potential sale on Medibank Privateâs customers.
The Commonwealth has $85,000,100 in paid up capital in Medibank Private as at 30 June 2005.

There is no direct correlation between Current Assets and Member Contributions. Member Contributions are treated as revenue in the year they are received with any surplus derived from the financial year being recorded as Retained Earnings in the Balance Sheet. Total Current Assets for 2003-04 were $1.0 billion and Total Member Contributions for 2003-04 were $2.4 billion.
